X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
body:
At today's most excellent developers BOF at the Austin conference, we  
discussed producing more and better developer documentation.  At the  
reception, a few of you mentioned to me that you would be interested  
in helping make it so.  I of course have no idea who what was (sorry  
- too much excitement!).

Please send me an email if you are willing to help pull together  
world-class developer documentation for Sakai.  I'll get the project  
organized.

Thanks!

(And if you are not down here in Austin, you are missing the fun (and  
ice storm)).

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu

body:
At one of the sessions this week in Austin, the assembled developers  
spontaneously burst into song and sang about Carol Dippel who has  
been the QA lead for the entire Sakai project phase.

Amazingly someone had the foresight to grab a camera and record it.

http://www-personal.umich.edu/~csev/media/2005/carol/carol.htm

/Chuck

body:
Sorry if I am a bit off topic for the list, however trying to get the
most experience at once as well as the best answer.



I am working on a CAS implementation, and I want to make sure I
understand the existing documentation I have found.  I have worked in
customizing Sakai for use with the LDAP systems which of course I had to
develop some code for.  However based on the documentation at:



http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/ENTR/CASifying+Sakai



Do I understand it correctly, that when setting up CAS with Apache using
a mod_cas configuration that I do NOT need to make changes or update any
existing Sakai code?  If so, how is the userid passed into Sakai?  Is
that done because of setting 'container.auth=true' in the
sakai.properties file?  As well as the changes in the login.vm?



Thanks in advance.



Kevin

subject: re: lms/vle rants/comments

Cc: "Masson, Patrick" <Patrick.Masson@suny.edu>,
	Patrick Carmichael <patrick@caret.cam.ac.uk>
X-From: postmaster@collab.sakaiproject.org Fri Dec 09 15:51:56 2005
Return-path: <postmaster@collab.sakaiproject.org>
Received: from girlinterrupted.mr.itd.umich.edu ([141.211.14.73])
	by ciao.gmane.org with esmtp (Exim 4.43)
	id 1EkjVd-0003lU-QX
	for gccsd-sakai-dev@m.gmane.org; Fri, 09 Dec 2005 15:46:06 +0100
Received: FROM mahimahi.ds.itd.umich.edu (mahimahi.ds.itd.umich.edu [141.211.253.162])
	BY girlinterrupted.mr.itd.umich.edu ID 439998AC.540D9.30848 ; 
	 9 Dec 2005 09:46:04 -0500
Received: from mahimahi.ds.itd.umich.edu ([127.0.0.1])
          by mahimahi.ds.itd.umich.edu (JAMES SMTP Server 2.1.3) with SMTP ID 1020
          for <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>;
          Fri, 9 Dec 2005 09:43:14 -0500 (EST)
Received: from saam1.sysadm.suny.edu (ns-map.ds.itd.umich.edu [141.211.253.192])
	by mahimahi.ds.itd.umich.edu (Postfix) with ESMTP id AAC9614023
	for <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>; Fri,  9 Dec 2005 09:43:14 -0500 (EST)
Received: from scenm1.sysadmin.suny.edu ([141.254.1.215])
 by sysadm.suny.edu (PMDF V6.2 #30588)
 with ESMTP id <01LWCRDJ4J2E0004WI@sysadm.suny.edu> for
 sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org; Fri, 09 Dec 2005 09:44:14 -0500 (EST)
To: John Norman <john@caret.cam.ac.uk>,
	sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft Exchange V6.0.6603.0
Thread-Topic: LMS/VLE rants/comments
Thread-Index: AcX8DyZ3lFYRKl4wQm6UNi17qriurgAtEXDwAAHtoDA=
content-class: urn:content-classes:message
X-MS-Has-Attach: 
X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: 
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/5>
body:
Yup, I think this is spot-on. Either/or, in reality, is actually neither
and both. We've had many discussions internally at SUNY about just how
loose our coupling can be. You start from either end and you work toward
the middle. But as a teaching and learning person, as a person who is
going to live in this app every day, I feel a strong sense of personal
urgency to put the issue of the long tail of learning applications as a
core design concern (which is why, by the way, that I think this
discussion belongs on the dev list and not the advocacy list). This is
not an issue of making your LMS cooler or sexier or more interesting.
It's about making it more *useful*. Regardless of whether "LMS" or "VLE"
is your preferred term, there is an "L" in there somewhere. 

Look, I'm a teacher. I don't care whether you guys decide to use flux
capacitor or an oscillating overthruster. I just want a good environment
to teach in. And my perspective as a teacher is that this long tail
issue is really, really important. Any LMS design that doesn't take it
very seriously as a core design requirement, IMHO, is not really
addressing the "L" the way it needs to be addressed in next-generation
learning environments.

I would add that, from my perspective, this debate also isn't really
about Sakai vs. something else. SUNY has particular needs which favor a
particular implementation strategy. That's a relatively local concern of
one institution. In the biggest picture, SUNY doesn't matter that much.
Neither does Sakai. What matters is that the global community is in the
midst of thinking through next-generation learning environment design.
As John points out, we agree on a lot. But the devil is in the details.

Kindest regards,
Michael

______________________________

Michael Feldstein
Assistant Director, Blended Learning
email: Michael.Feldstein@suny.edu
phone: 518-443-5476
cell: 917-921-8895


-----Original Message-----
From: John Norman [mailto:john@caret.cam.ac.uk] 
Sent: Friday, December 09, 2005 8:32 AM
To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Cc: Masson, Patrick; 'Patrick Carmichael'
Subject: RE: LMS/VLE rants/comments


I should chip in her as Dan's PHB :)

Our strategy at Cambridge is to try and get the best of both worlds. I
am dismayed by the either/or tone of many discussions on this topic. If
you start from a monolithic place you will find yourself wanting/needing
to be loosening things up. If you start from a very loosely coupled
place you will find yourself wanting to provide some coordination
(broker service in SUNY plans I think).

Although the Sakai project and the SUNY design (and others) are at
different places on the spectrum I hope we can have conversations that
lead to learning from each other and conversion, or at least an
understanding of when one approach is better than another and when it is
not.

John

PS and from my point of view Dan is free to continue to voice his
opinions. He has had an interesting experience of building a custom LMS
for a multi-departmental course based on Wiki technology before joining
CARET.

But perhaps some of this belongs on the strategy and advocacy list
rather than Dev?

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Dan Sheppard [mailto:dan@caret.cam.ac.uk]
> Sent: 08 December 2005 15:48
> To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> Cc: Masson, Patrick; Patrick Carmichael
> Subject: LMS/VLE rants/comments
> 
> Concerning Patrick Masson's and (to a certain extent) Ian Dolphin's 
> comments on LMSes in general (beyond intergration with repositories).
> 
> (I'll post the summary of the responses I received concerning 
> Repository/VLE integration to here and sepp-library in a moment).
> 
> I should say from the start that I'm primarily a developer, and don't 
> pretend to speak from anyone other than myself, though I'm trying to 
> reflect what I believe is strategy amongst my immediate managers, 
> where I know it!
> 
> I mentioned that VLEs are seen here, in some ways, as a sepcial case 
> of VREs, or that VREs are a more primary purpose. I agree with Ian in 
> a dislike for this jargon, and I'm sorry for lasping into it! What I 
> really mean (I think) is that at a research-led University, much of 
> our teaching in terms of styles of interaction, is derivative of, or 
> based upon, how research is performed, rather than teaching as it 
> might be seen as an adaptation of school teaching to a different 
> demographic.
> 
> I know that sounds vague, but things like group size, formality of 
> "courses", open access to learning resources, the degree of direction 
> and self-motivation, and so on, have real practical implications on 
> any system we might deliver to campus.
> 
> A collegiate University also has incredibly complex reporting and 
> responsibility structure, which impacts on any top-down type approach.

> Essentially, nobody has the whole picture of a researcher or student's

> learning experience other than that person themselves. That's part of 
> the reason, I think, that we're after a system which focuses on the 
> individual first, then their researching role, and then their teaching

> role, and allowing people to exchange their various roles in different

> contexts with ease.
> 
> It's these concerns which are the outstanding pressures, as I see it, 
> in choosing a learning system. I think that many of these issues are 
> reflected in Oxford University's report on the choice of Bodington 
> (fine-grained access control, no course registration, etc).
> 
> The real 'selling' point of Sakai, as I see it, at the moment as a 
> tool is its community and adopters, rather than its codebase. And a 
> large number of research-led (comparatively) resource-rich 
> Universities are adopting it, some completely committed to it at least

> in the medium-term, and so we can be reasonably sure that where needs 
> of research-led Universities are not met by Sakai, then they will be 
> forthwith, and Sakai won't move in a direction incompatible with this 
> use (not that this will be its exclusive use!).
> 
> Also, it currently does the job tolerably well: group management can 
> be easily delegated, it accomodates small informal teaching groups, 
> navigation between many fragmented informal components
> 
> This is why, I think, we have interests in, for example, the JISC VRE 
> Sakai work.
> 
> We've spoken a lot recently here, internally, about approaches to 
> providing resources along those lines, and the SUNY LMOS model 
> (mentioned by name!) was the other leading contender.
> 
> I don't disagree with any of the downsides to using an integrated LMS 
> that Patrick raised. Core tools are often behind the state-of-the-art,

> and need to be integrated into a VLE. It could be argued that a set of

> enterprise-type services (single-sign-on auth, LDAP, common navigation

> 'frame', etc) can be used to support a set of tools.
> 
> Part of the problem we find, though, is that many of the enterprise 
> tools are not suited to an environment like this (it's difficult, for 
> example, for LDAP, to capture the creative anarchy of the way many 
> research and tutorial groups tend to assemble and disperse).
> 
> Users also seem, in practice, to react positively to the consistent 
> navigation and style provided by these tools. The more vociferous 
> users, those who have more issues with the presentation of identity, 
> may react against the blandly repetitive styling and the attribution 
> issues raised. But the majority, as far as I can tell, react 
> positively to simple navigation around a single server  (rather than 
> the >1000 we must have here at the moment, each with their own tweaks 
> and ideosynchrosies). I realise that the navigation and branding 
> issues are distinct, but they're highly entwined.
> 
> Also, as more tools are added, the problem starts to escalate with an 
> assembly of interoperating tools (as O(n^2)), but remain linear (O(n))

> with each tool which is added to an LMS framework (obviously this is a

> simplification). Also, it becomes simple to develop "mix-and-match" 
> tools from services already in the framework because of their 
> comonalities.
> 
> As the issues you raise concerning lock-in become apparent there are 
> starting to be standards developed which allow "external" 
> applications, like IMS launch, though they're currently a little 
> immature.
> 
> Another advantage to a deployer at the moment, of course, is that 
> Sakai exists! Personally, if I were given a good integrated, styled, 
> LMOS, with excellent delegated user management, and plenty of tools, I

> would be very pleased, but I've yet to see anything approaching this 
> at the present time. But good luck in developing such!
> 
> Personally, I agree that there's currently no VLE/LMS which I could be

> comfortable as describing as "good": just some which are heading in 
> the right direction, and really very few extant alternatives.
> 
> Dan.
> 
> ----------------------

> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development 
> site. You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > 
> Preferences.

> From: Dan Sheppard [mailto:dan@caret.cam.ac.uk]
> Sent: 08 December 2005 15:48
> To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> Cc: Masson, Patrick; Patrick Carmichael
> Subject: LMS/VLE rants/comments
> 
> Concerning Patrick Masson's and (to a certain extent) Ian Dolphin's
> comments on LMSes in general (beyond intergration with repositories).
> 
> (I'll post the summary of the responses I received concerning
> Repository/VLE integration to here and sepp-library in a moment).
> 
> I should say from the start that I'm primarily a developer, and don't
> pretend to speak from anyone other than myself, though I'm trying to
> reflect what I believe is strategy amongst my immediate managers, where
> I know it!
> 
> I mentioned that VLEs are seen here, in some ways, as a sepcial case of
> VREs, or that VREs are a more primary purpose. I agree with Ian in a
> dislike for this jargon, and I'm sorry for lasping into it! What I
> really mean (I think) is that at a research-led University, much of our
> teaching in terms of styles of interaction, is derivative of, or based
> upon, how research is performed, rather than teaching as it might be
> seen as an adaptation of school teaching to a different demographic.
> 
> I know that sounds vague, but things like group size, formality of
> "courses", open access to learning resources, the degree of direction
> and self-motivation, and so on, have real practical implications on any
> system we might deliver to campus.
> 
> A collegiate University also has incredibly complex reporting and
> responsibility structure, which impacts on any top-down type approach.
> Essentially, nobody has the whole picture of a researcher or student's
> learning experience other than that person themselves. That's part of
> the reason, I think, that we're after a system which focuses on the
> individual first, then their researching role, and then their teaching
> role, and allowing people to exchange their various roles in different
> contexts with ease.
> 
> It's these concerns which are the outstanding pressures, as I see it, in
> choosing a learning system. I think that many of these issues are
> reflected in Oxford University's report on the choice of Bodington
> (fine-grained access control, no course registration, etc).
> 
> The real 'selling' point of Sakai, as I see it, at the moment as a tool
> is its community and adopters, rather than its codebase. And a large
> number of research-led (comparatively) resource-rich Universities are
> adopting it, some completely committed to it at least in the
> medium-term, and so we can be reasonably sure that where needs of
> research-led Universities are not met by Sakai, then they will be
> forthwith, and Sakai won't move in a direction incompatible with this
> use (not that this will be its exclusive use!).
> 
> Also, it currently does the job tolerably well: group management can be
> easily delegated, it accomodates small informal teaching groups,
> navigation between many fragmented informal components
> 
> This is why, I think, we have interests in, for example, the JISC VRE
> Sakai work.
> 
> We've spoken a lot recently here, internally, about approaches to
> providing resources along those lines, and the SUNY LMOS model
> (mentioned by name!) was the other leading contender.
> 
> I don't disagree with any of the downsides to using an integrated LMS
> that Patrick raised. Core tools are often behind the state-of-the-art,
> and need to be integrated into a VLE. It could be argued that a set of
> enterprise-type services (single-sign-on auth, LDAP, common navigation
> 'frame', etc) can be used to support a set of tools.
> 
> Part of the problem we find, though, is that many of the enterprise
> tools are not suited to an environment like this (it's difficult, for
> example, for LDAP, to capture the creative anarchy of the way many
> research and tutorial groups tend to assemble and disperse).
> 
> Users also seem, in practice, to react positively to the consistent
> navigation and style provided by these tools. The more vociferous users,
> those who have more issues with the presentation of identity, may react
> against the blandly repetitive styling and the attribution issues
> raised. But the majority, as far as I can tell, react positively to
> simple navigation around a single server  (rather than the >1000 we must
> have here at the moment, each with their own tweaks and
> ideosynchrosies). I realise that the navigation and branding issues are
> distinct, but they're highly entwined.
> 
> Also, as more tools are added, the problem starts to escalate with an
> assembly of interoperating tools (as O(n^2)), but remain linear (O(n))
> with each tool which is added to an LMS framework (obviously this is a
> simplification). Also, it becomes simple to develop "mix-and-match"
> tools from services already in the framework because of their
> comonalities.
> 
> As the issues you raise concerning lock-in become apparent there are
> starting to be standards developed which allow "external" applications,
> like IMS launch, though they're currently a little immature.
> 
> Another advantage to a deployer at the moment, of course, is that Sakai
> exists! Personally, if I were given a good integrated, styled, LMOS,
> with excellent delegated user management, and plenty of tools, I would
> be very pleased, but I've yet to see anything approaching this at the
> present time. But good luck in developing such!
> 
> Personally, I agree that there's currently no VLE/LMS which I could be
> comfortable as describing as "good": just some which are heading in the
> right direction, and really very few extant alternatives.
> 
> Dan.
> 
> ----------------------
> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab
> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development site.
> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace >
> Preferences.

body:
I think some things might only work in an iframe.  The same thing 
happened to me with a Firefox sidebar to launch single Sakai tools in 
the main browser window.  Most things worked, but chat didn't work, 
unless you manually clicked refresh a lot.

-steve

Yuji Shinozaki wrote:

>I am trying out Chuck's neat little "sakai-launcher" portlet, and I
>noticed that those sessions generated via SakaiPortalLogin.jws
>don't show up in users present nor in chat.  Although you can actually
>participate in a chat (kind of a ghost in the machine).  I also notice
>that the chat is not auto-refreshing (which may be an unrelated bug).
>
>I will dig deeper and file a jira (or two) as I collect info on this bug.
>
>yuji

body:
BTW some of the thinking Dan articulated came from an exercise where we
said: Let's take the position the Sakai is a really bad idea and look for
what we like about it. If we apply the same thinking to the SUNY design and
others we find lots of great things and even conclude that the concepts are
not that far apart if we layer on top of current positions, the expected
trajectory of the projects.

John

> -----Original Message-----
> From: John Norman [mailto:john@caret.cam.ac.uk]
> Sent: 09 December 2005 13:32
> To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> Cc: 'Masson, Patrick'; 'Patrick Carmichael'
> Subject: RE: LMS/VLE rants/comments
> 
> I should chip in her as Dan's PHB :)
> 
> Our strategy at Cambridge is to try and get the best of both worlds. I am
> dismayed by the either/or tone of many discussions on this topic. If you
> start from a monolithic place you will find yourself wanting/needing to be
> loosening things up. If you start from a very loosely coupled place you
> will
> find yourself wanting to provide some coordination (broker service in SUNY
> plans I think).
> 
> Although the Sakai project and the SUNY design (and others) are at
> different
> places on the spectrum I hope we can have conversations that lead to
> learning from each other and conversion, or at least an understanding of
> when one approach is better than another and when it is not.
> 
> John
> 
> PS and from my point of view Dan is free to continue to voice his
> opinions.
> He has had an interesting experience of building a custom LMS for a
> multi-departmental course based on Wiki technology before joining CARET.
> 
> But perhaps some of this belongs on the strategy and advocacy list rather
> than Dev?
> 
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Dan Sheppard [mailto:dan@caret.cam.ac.uk]
> > Sent: 08 December 2005 15:48
> > To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> > Cc: Masson, Patrick; Patrick Carmichael
> > Subject: LMS/VLE rants/comments
> >
> > Concerning Patrick Masson's and (to a certain extent) Ian Dolphin's
> > comments on LMSes in general (beyond intergration with repositories).
> >
> > (I'll post the summary of the responses I received concerning
> > Repository/VLE integration to here and sepp-library in a moment).
> >
> > I should say from the start that I'm primarily a developer, and don't
> > pretend to speak from anyone other than myself, though I'm trying to
> > reflect what I believe is strategy amongst my immediate managers, where
> > I know it!
> >
> > I mentioned that VLEs are seen here, in some ways, as a sepcial case of
> > VREs, or that VREs are a more primary purpose. I agree with Ian in a
> > dislike for this jargon, and I'm sorry for lasping into it! What I
> > really mean (I think) is that at a research-led University, much of our
> > teaching in terms of styles of interaction, is derivative of, or based
> > upon, how research is performed, rather than teaching as it might be
> > seen as an adaptation of school teaching to a different demographic.
> >
> > I know that sounds vague, but things like group size, formality of
> > "courses", open access to learning resources, the degree of direction
> > and self-motivation, and so on, have real practical implications on any
> > system we might deliver to campus.
> >
> > A collegiate University also has incredibly complex reporting and
> > responsibility structure, which impacts on any top-down type approach.
> > Essentially, nobody has the whole picture of a researcher or student's
> > learning experience other than that person themselves. That's part of
> > the reason, I think, that we're after a system which focuses on the
> > individual first, then their researching role, and then their teaching
> > role, and allowing people to exchange their various roles in different
> > contexts with ease.
> >
> > It's these concerns which are the outstanding pressures, as I see it, in
> > choosing a learning system. I think that many of these issues are
> > reflected in Oxford University's report on the choice of Bodington
> > (fine-grained access control, no course registration, etc).
> >
> > The real 'selling' point of Sakai, as I see it, at the moment as a tool
> > is its community and adopters, rather than its codebase. And a large
> > number of research-led (comparatively) resource-rich Universities are
> > adopting it, some completely committed to it at least in the
> > medium-term, and so we can be reasonably sure that where needs of
> > research-led Universities are not met by Sakai, then they will be
> > forthwith, and Sakai won't move in a direction incompatible with this
> > use (not that this will be its exclusive use!).
> >
> > Also, it currently does the job tolerably well: group management can be
> > easily delegated, it accomodates small informal teaching groups,
> > navigation between many fragmented informal components
> >
> > This is why, I think, we have interests in, for example, the JISC VRE
> > Sakai work.
> >
> > We've spoken a lot recently here, internally, about approaches to
> > providing resources along those lines, and the SUNY LMOS model
> > (mentioned by name!) was the other leading contender.
> >
> > I don't disagree with any of the downsides to using an integrated LMS
> > that Patrick raised. Core tools are often behind the state-of-the-art,
> > and need to be integrated into a VLE. It could be argued that a set of
> > enterprise-type services (single-sign-on auth, LDAP, common navigation
> > 'frame', etc) can be used to support a set of tools.
> >
> > Part of the problem we find, though, is that many of the enterprise
> > tools are not suited to an environment like this (it's difficult, for
> > example, for LDAP, to capture the creative anarchy of the way many

> >

> > those who have more issues with the presentation of identity, may react
> > against the blandly repetitive styling and the attribution issues
> > raised. But the majority, as far as I can tell, react positively to
> > simple navigation around a single server  (rather than the >1000 we must
> > have here at the moment, each with their own tweaks and

> > distinct, but they're highly entwined.
> >

> > assembly of interoperating tools (as O(n^2)), but remain linear (O(n))

Yuji Shinozaki wrote:

>About the presence issue, it seems there are use cases for logging
>in with presence and those for logging in without presence.  Perhaps
>the webservices methods should have that option.
>
>  
>
Yuji,

Can you add this as a feature request in Jira under the web services 
component?

Thanks,
Steve

body:
I am trying out Chuck's neat little "sakai-launcher" portlet, and I
noticed that those sessions generated via SakaiPortalLogin.jws
don't show up in users present nor in chat.  Although you can actually
participate in a chat (kind of a ghost in the machine).  I also notice
that the chat is not auto-refreshing (which may be an unrelated bug).

I will dig deeper and file a jira (or two) as I collect info on this bug.

yuji

body:
The portlet pulls in the "worksite" iframe, so that is a situation where
you would want the refresh to work.  Incidentally, refresh does work in
gallery and portal (full) mode, I believe.

The chat tool exhibits the same behavior in the mercury portal (but that
isn't that surprising).

About the presence issue, it seems there are use cases for logging
in with presence and those for logging in without presence.  Perhaps
the webservices methods should have that option.

yuji
----



On Fri, 9 Dec 2005, Steven Githens wrote:

> I think some things might only work in an iframe.  The same thing
> happened to me with a Firefox sidebar to launch single Sakai tools in
> the main browser window.  Most things worked, but chat didn't work,
> unless you manually clicked refresh a lot.
>
> -steve

body:
Kevin Carpenter wrote:

> Do I understand it correctly, that when setting up CAS with Apache 
> using a mod_cas configuration that I do NOT need to make changes or 
> update any existing Sakai code?  If so, how is the userid passed 
> into Sakai?  Is that done because of setting 'container.auth=true' 
> in the sakai.properties file?  As well as the changes in the 
> login.vm?

If you are using mod_cas, you only need to make the changes to 
httpd.conf, Tomcat, and the login.vm UI as listed. Sakai will use the 
value of REMOTE_USER as the userid. The login.vm changes are optional 
but make it easy for you to still login as "admin" if needed.

(For those interested, the xlogin.* properties introduced in 2.0.0+ 
were partially inspired by some of UI work done in conjunction with 
CASification.)

If you want to use a servlet filter, the steps are similar but 
different. I have a 1.5 instance running with a servlet filter, so 
feel free to contact me if you go this way.

Seth

body:
I keep getting this memory error after a clean boot and clean install of
2.1 on Windows 2003 server. I have tried various settings as suggested
with the JVM values. I get these errors after about 5-10 clicks on links
after a clean start. Page will tend to be blank in body, I then look at
STD log and see this error.  The server I am running on has 2GB memory.
Any ideas?

Sakai does not run well in Windows. We used to run it on Windows 2003. No matter how we optimize it, it gave us the "OutOfMemory" error. We have since switched to Linux, and the problem is gone.

Victor

with the JVM values. I get these errors after about 5-10 clicks on links
after a clean start. Page will tend to be blank in body, I then look at
STD log and see this error. The server I am running on has 2GB memory.
Any ideas?

sakai-src/providers/component/src/webapp/WEB-INF/components.xml) and
some basic schema of the corresponding LDAP directory as an
example?

I'm really stuck right now :(

Regards,
Winston
On 11/29/05, Winston Wu <winstonw.tw@gmail.com> wrote:

> >
> > Hi,
> >
> > I'm not sure how you're testing, but in this configuration, Sakai will _also_
> > authenticate according to the user records stored in the mysql database, i.e.
> > you can use an LDAP password or the internal password.
> >

> >
> > Cheers

> where would the data except authentication infomation of the user be

>
> I suppose the answer should be MySQL? If my supposition is right, will

> problem.

> Best Regards,
> Winston Wu

body:
Dan,

Are you starting Tomcat as a service?  Where are the JVM values being set?  I  have seen this problem solved on a Windows 2003 server by setting JVM values in Control Panel->System->Advanced->Environment Variables.  Tomcat is installed as a service.

Set JAVA_OPTS and CATALINA_OPTS to "-Xmx512M -Xms512M" (or higher as necessary) under System variables.

Andrew


-----Original Message-----
From:	Cotton, Dan [mailto:dgcotton@ucdavis.edu]
Sent:	Sat 12/10/2005 11:55 PM
To:	sakai-dev
Cc:	
Subject:	Memory error with 2.1

I keep getting this memory error after a clean boot and clean install of
2.1 on Windows 2003 server. I have tried various settings as suggested
with the JVM values. I get these errors after about 5-10 clicks on links
after a clean start. Page will tend to be blank in body, I then look at
STD log and see this error.  The server I am running on has 2GB memory.
Any ideas?

body:
I put up the code in contrib for the VT sakai 2.1 providers during the
conference (sorry for the delay for those who I have talked to about
this).

You can get the code here:
https://source.sakaiproject.org/contrib/virginiatech/providers/

A quick listing of the providers:
1) One provider to enforce confidentiality of user data by obscuring
part or all of the field from users like other students but allow the
data to be visible to instructors or maintainers in the site
2) One provider to allow for whitelisting or blacklisting users and
assigning them a level of access when they enter the system
3) One provider to handling caching of data from the institutional
repository (database cache and memory cache using ehcache)
4) Two providers to access the VT LDAP as an example (one gets all user
data and one gets only public user data)

The providers work together and talk to each other using spring so that
the parts (like caching) can be easily removed or added. Current
structure is:
WhitelistProvider -> ConfidentialProvider -> CacheProvider ->
LDAPprovider
See the javadocs for more info.

I also put up the whitelist tool which is a tool to add or remove users
from the whitelist and set their level of access. The tool is written
using JSF and hibernate. It requires the WhitelistProvider to be in the
providers dir before it will compile when building sakai.
https://source.sakaiproject.org/contrib/virginiatech/whitelist/

Feel free to check out this code if any of it sounds helpful (or if you
think you can make it better). I am happy to integrate changes from
others back into the code.

-AZ

--
Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech

body:
Thanks everyone. It does appear to be just a tar compatibility problem, and
the resulting files should be uneffected. Most of my 2.1 problems went away
when I moved over to a MySQL db.



-----Original Message-----
From: Seth Theriault [mailto:slt@columbia.edu] 
Sent: 08 December 2005 18:54
To: Andrew Poland
Cc: Jon Higham; 'sakai-dev'
Subject: Re: Sakai 2.1 - lone zero block error


Andrew Poland wrote:

% When extracting tar files created with Ant's tar task, tar logs a 
% warning like 'tar: A lone zero block at *'. While all the file 
% contents is extracted correctly this message causes confusion for 
% lots of users. The reason for the message is that tar expects TWO 
% empty records marking the end of the archive but Ant is writing only 
% ONE.

This bug has its root in the different implementations of tar, most 
notably the difference between GNU tar and POSIX-compliant tar. Lots 
of details at:

http://www.gnu.org/software/tar/manual/html_chapter/tar_8.html#SEC134

As a practical matter, the messages are simply annoying.

Seth

X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/20>
body:
I should mention that we have a version that works for Sakai 2.01 as
well but I only posted the 2.1 version since I figured everyone would be
switching. If anyone wants the 2.01 version, let me know.
-AZ

--
Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech

>

body:
Not sure if you guys were at the Austin conference and attended the UI
discussions, but I think the doc would be great to have in Confluence...
as an actual page.  I've looked for something like this for a while, but
haven't come across it before now.  If it's in Confluence, it'd be
searchable, printable, editable, etc.

/*******************************************
* Jeff Beeman
*******************************************/

-----Original Message-----
From: Gonzalo David Silverio [mailto:gsilver@umich.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, December 07, 2005 11:21 AM
To: Victor Yu
Cc: 'sakai-dev'
Subject: Re: Sakai logo

Victor,

This document:

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/docs/architecture/sakai_
skin_portal.doc

gives you several possibilities of how to do that.

-- Gonzalo Silverio <gsilver@umich.edu>

---------------------

On Wed, 7 Dec 2005, Victor Yu wrote:

> Does anyone know how to replace the sakai logo located at the upper
left corner with our own?
>
> Victor
>
> John Leasia <jleasia@umich.edu> wrote:
> Editing the site template realms will only affect sites created after
> that edit. So if you are having problems with an existing site, it has
> it's own realm now, and you need to edit that realm (it will be listed
> as site/ in the realm editor). Maybe the site's realm doesn't
> have the right permissions if you are still having problems.
> I think you have the right settings below.
> John
>
> Jon Higham wrote:
>
>> Thanks. This is what I've done with the realms.
>>
>> For maintain I have checked:
>> gradebook.editAssignments
>> gradebook.gradeAll
>> gradebook.gradeSection
>>
>> For access I have checked
>> gradebook.viewOwnGrades
>>
>> This is for both the site and the site.template realms. Please let me
know
>> if this is right, or you can think of something else.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: John Leasia [mailto:jleasia@umich.edu]
>> Sent: 07 December 2005 17:20
>> To: Jon Higham
>> Cc: daisyf@stanford.edu; 'sakai-dev'
>> Subject: Re: Sakai 2.1 Samigo
>>
>>
>> Check the same way Daisy suggested (editing the realm) but check that
>> the Gradebook related permissions are set properly. Each tool has
it's
>> own permissions, and maybe your role permissions aren't set properly
for
>> that site's realm.
>> John
>>
>> Jon Higham wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>> Thanks. This has allowed Access permission users to complete the
>>> Quizzes, but I still can't view the scores in the Gradebook. I tried
>>> ticking the check boxes for the gradebook options too.
>>>
>>> Any other suggestions?
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> -----Original Message-----
>>> From: Daisy Flemming [mailto:daisy.flemming@gmail.com]
>>> Sent: 07 December 2005 15:53
>>> To: Jon Higham
>>> Cc: sakai-dev
>>> Subject: Re: Sakai 2.1 Samigo
>>>
>>>
>>> Hi Jon,
>>>
>>> Can you check this for me? Login as admin/admin, select Realms,
select
>>> the project site in question. Under the Role Id, select "access",
check
>>> that the two checkboxes are checked
>>>
>>> assessment.submitAssessmentForGrade
>>>
>>> assessment.takeAssessment
>>>
>>> As for "maintain" role, you want to check the rest of the boxes
except
>>> these two above.
>>>
>>> Then login with an access acct and an maintain acct to make sure
>>> everything works accordingly.
>>>
>>> Then you want to check the realm "!site.template" to make sure that
the
>>> setting is set up correctly. So future project sites will inherit
the
>>> settings.
>>>
>>> Let me know if that works. Thanks.
>>>
>>> BTW: If you can give me an url to ur server, I can check for u too.
>>>
>>> Daisy
>>>
>>> On 12/7/05, Jon Higham wrote:
>>>
>>> If I publish a Quiz from Tests & Quizzes, it cannot be viewed by
anyone
>>> with Access permissions under Tests & Quizzes. As a user with Access
>>> permissions I can connect to the Quiz via the "Published Assessment
>>> URL" but then, as Administrator I cannot access scores properly - I
can
>>> see who has attempted the Quiz (Submission Status), but cannot
retrieve
>>> their scores (Total Scores).
>>>
>>> Any suggestions, please?
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Jon Higham
>>> eServices
>>> University of Hull
>>>
>>> [see attachment: "message0.html", size: 1390 bytes]
>>>
>>>
>>> Attachments:
>>>
>>> message0.html
>>>
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/3ac6e540-52e6-
>>> 4c1e-
>>> 00fc-ba5bcbead966/message0.html

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/21>
body:
The group formerly knows as the SEPP Library group is now the Sakai  
Library group.  The group decided to open its membership up - now you  
can simply go to the Membership tab and join the "Library" group if  
you are interested in libraries and repositories.

The mail alias is now

sakai-library@collab.sakaiproject.org

The old address (sepp-library) will continue to work.

Sorry for so many copies of this.

/Chuck

body:
Hi,
I didn't see this mentioned in JIRA after a quick search, but I apologize 
if this is old news to some of you. During the past week or two I've been 
unable to use the collab site (after login) when I access it with Internet 
Explorer (I believe this happened after Sakai 2.1.0 was installed there). 
The site logs me out immediately after login (perhaps 10 seconds later, 
after choosing the particular Sakai site I want to see), so I have no 
chance of accessing resources or doing anything at all. I'm using IE on 
Windows 2000. I wonder if this is also the experience of other Windows 
users, or whether it is just my particular configuration... I haven't seen 
this problem with other browsers.
-Patricia

Patricia Goldweic
pgoldweic@northwestern.edu

----------------------

You might be right in that it may be a browser problem. However, I believe 
you saw my name show up in the 'users present' window because I opened up a 
Firefox session after I was unable to do anything with IE. This session was 
open until just a couple of minutes ago, since I had forgotten to close it. 
Also, I've been accessing several different Sakai 2.1.0 with this same IE 
browser with no problems whatsoever... only the collab site seems to be 
giving me trouble.
-Patricia
At 01:54 PM 12/12/2005, Zeckoski, Aaron wrote:
>I am not having any problems getting in and staying in with IE 6 on
>windows XP. I notice that you are listed in the "users present" window
>as of 2:54 pm EST so maybe you are still in the site but the browser is
>doing something weird?
>-AZ
>

body:
Hi!
I'm trying to add a helper to create links to sakai resources in 
RWiki. I was told that I should use the "File-Picker" for this, but I'm 
kinda stuck as to what this is and how to use it. The only references I 
can find to a "file-picker" are to do with SAK-1624 and it's reversal. 
Is there a common way to do add attachments in Sakai, and if so how do 
non-JSF, non-legacy tools do so?

Thanks,
andy

-- 
Andrew Thornton
andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk

body:
Andrew,

A discussion of helpers in general is located in the following document
on the sakai collab site:
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1097928811887-22636/
Architecture%20Docs/Sakai%202/sakai_tool.pdf

The trick is to get the helper tool by its Id and call the "help" method
on that.  This will cause a forward to happen.  A helper should always
go back to your tool's servlet for each request it needs to make, this
means that your servlet should be helper aware meaning it should know
what requests to forward on to the helper.  The basic syntax is as
follows:

ToolSession toolSession = SessionManager.getCurrentToolSession();
ActiveTool helperTool = ActiveToolManager.getActiveTool(helperId);
// put state info in toolSession to communicate with helper

// this is the forward call
helperTool.help(req, res, context, toolPath);

An example of a servlet that does this is 
org.sakaiproject.tool.syllabus.SyllabusFilePickerServlet

This is a jsf servlet, but the concept should be similar.

When the tool is finished, it will redirect to the URL specified in:

toolSession.setAttribute(helperTool.getId() + Tool.HELPER_DONE_URL, 
returnUrl);

As for the file picker specifically, the attributes necessary to
communicate with it are found in the class:
org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.filepicker.FilePickerHelper

The descriptions should be in the javadocs there.

I hope that helps.  If not, please let me know.

John


-----Original Message-----
From: Andrew Thornton [mailto:andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk] 
Sent: Monday, December 12, 2005 7:23 AM
To: sakai-dev
Subject: File Picker for non-legacy tools

Hi!
I'm trying to add a helper to create links to sakai resources in 
RWiki. I was told that I should use the "File-Picker" for this, but I'm 
kinda stuck as to what this is and how to use it. The only references I 
can find to a "file-picker" are to do with SAK-1624 and it's reversal. 
Is there a common way to do add attachments in Sakai, and if so how do 
non-JSF, non-legacy tools do so?

Thanks,
andy

-- 
Andrew Thornton
andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk

body:
Manchester Metropolitan is leading the development of a toolkit to 
provide a course service. This work can be found at 
http://www.jisc.ac.uk/index.cfm?name=elfref_mmu&src=alpha and 
http://www.elframework.org/projects/xcri. The specification is being 
coordinated with U.S. software firms and PESC and SIF. This will become 
one of the JISC services using XML, SOAP, and WSDL. Note this 
specification can answer the course questions, but not the collaboration 
questions, worksite sponsorships, or a general search of metadata which 
may answer "kayaking" (unless Kayak was in the name of the worksite 
sponsor).

Someone at the University of Essex may be able to better answer your 
question about collaborations. They are planning work on the use of the 
FOAF (friend of a friend) protocol to identify "collaborations." This 
builds on their Chimera project http://www.essex.ac.uk/chimera/index.html.

A collaboration network could be built from course enrollments 
(including sections and projects) and any address the user may have in 
their collaboration tools. Because collaboration is coming from other 
research, a separate collaboration service built on the Chimera work may 
be preferable.

jim farmer


Yuji Shinozaki wrote:

>Is there any taxonomy of worksites?  Or any accessible meta data about
>worksites that can be used to organize them?
>
>What I would like to be able to answer are these types of questions:
>
>What are my Courses?
>What are my Collaborations?
>What are my Courses for the Spring Term 2003?
>What are my Courses this semester?
>What are my Physics courses?
>What are my Ad Hoc Collaborations?
>What are all the worksites sponsored by the Campus Democrats?
>What worksites concern Kayaking?
>
>I have scanned the architecture documents and can't seem to find anything
>specifically addressing this question.  Please point me in the right
>direction if this documentation exists.
>
>If this type of course meta-data does not exist, are their plans for
>implementing it?
>
>Yuji Shinozaki	                        Computer Systems Senior Engineer
>ys2n@virginia.edu			Advanced Technologies Group
>(434)924-7171				Information Technology & Communication
>http://www.people.virginia.edu/~ys2n    University of Virginia

body:
Sorry I missed this in the conference flurry, Jon. John Leasia did a great 
job of stepping in to explain what was going on. The only things I'd add are:

1) You can find an explanation of the new permissions and suggestions for 
upgraders in the file:

gradebook/xdocs/ReleaseNotes-2.1.0.txt

2) As noted there, the 2.1 (and after) equivalents for the 2.0 "maintain" 
permission are "editAssignments" and "gradeAll". This is what course site 
members in the "instructor" role should receive by default in 
out-of-the-box Sakai. The "gradeSection" permission means that the user can 
only grade students who share a section with them. It's meant for GSIs, 
teaching assistants, and other people who might have grading capabilities 
assigned to them for particular sections of a course site, but not for the 
whole site.

Ray

At 07:29 AM 12/7/2005, Jon Higham wrote:

>Thanks. This is what I've done with the realms.
>
>For maintain I have checked:
>gradebook.editAssignments
>gradebook.gradeAll
>gradebook.gradeSection
>
>For access I have checked
>gradebook.viewOwnGrades
>
>This is for both the site and the site.template realms. Please let me know
>if this is right, or you can think of something else.

body:
Victor,

Please avoid making generalized statements like this. There are plenty
of developers building/testing Sakai on Windows without trouble, and
there are even schools in pilots/production on Windows. Sounds like
you failed to give the JVM more perm gen space, which is heavily
documented as something to watch out for (on any platform).

thanks,

Dave

On 12/11/05, Victor Yu <vyu2@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Sakai does not run well in Windows. We used to run it on Windows 2003. No matter how we optimize it, it gave us the "OutOfMemory" error. We have since switched to Linux, and the problem is gone.
>
> Victor
>

body:
Windows installations can be complicated by whether they're installed as a
service or not, and I think it was Luke Fernandez who noted that he had
trouble getting suggested JAVA_OPTS settings to work if he set them as an
environment variable rather than through the Tomcat properties GUI.  As Dave
notes, this does sound like a permanent generation problem.

Our Windows install documentation is however admittedly weak, and could use
more input from those people actually working with it out there.  If some
clear resolution of this can be achieved, a comment somewhere in:
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8851

... would be much appreciated.

~Clay

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/32>
body:
Please note an additional update step needed for Oracle and MySQL  
Sakai 2.0 database conversion to 2.1.  The conversion scripts in the  
release are missing this step; the correct version is available in  
the Sakai trunk:

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/docs/updating/ 
sakai_2_0-2_1_mysql_conversion.sql

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/docs/updating/ 
sakai_2_0-2_1_oracle_conversion.sql

If you have already run the conversion, you can apply this additional  
step (good for both dbs):

UPDATE GB_GRADABLE_OBJECT_T SET NOT_COUNTED=0 WHERE NOT_COUNTED IS  
NULL AND POINTS_POSSIBLE IS NOT NULL;

This is covered in the Jira:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-3123

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu

body:
Is there any taxonomy of worksites?  Or any accessible meta data about
worksites that can be used to organize them?

What I would like to be able to answer are these types of questions:

What are my Courses?
What are my Collaborations?
What are my Courses for the Spring Term 2003?
What are my Courses this semester?
What are my Physics courses?
What are my Ad Hoc Collaborations?
What are all the worksites sponsored by the Campus Democrats?
What worksites concern Kayaking?

I have scanned the architecture documents and can't seem to find anything
specifically addressing this question.  Please point me in the right
direction if this documentation exists.

If this type of course meta-data does not exist, are their plans for
implementing it?

Yuji Shinozaki	                        Computer Systems Senior Engineer
ys2n@virginia.edu			Advanced Technologies Group
(434)924-7171				Information Technology & Communication
http://www.people.virginia.edu/~ys2n    University of Virginia

With the disclaimer that I know next to nothing about JVM tuning I've
found the settings as displayed in the attached screen shots get rid of
the out of memory exceptions when I start up Tomcat through the icon in
the system tray or alternatively when I start Tomcat up through
MyEclipse.  Note that the approach is different when starting it up
directly versus through MyEclipse.  I'm running it on a laptop with 1
gig of RAM on XP Pro.  

Cheers,

Luke

body:
Does anybody know where the audio for the Austin presentations is being
posted or where it will be posted if it hasnt yet been? 

I'm particularly interested in reviewing Ray Davis's JSF presentation
and Zach Thomas's presentation.

I don't see them at
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/winterconf2005/Sessions

Cheers,

Luke

body:
Thanks for the response.  But perhaps I should provide some scope to my
question.  I am talking more in terms of:  given an out-of-the-box
installation of sakai, what would I have to implement in order to:

1. identify a worksite as being a "course" or a "collaboration" or a "hoe
down" or a "singles mixer" or any other arbitrary classification.

2. sort worksites according to those classifications, hopefully with some
notion of hierachy.

3. access this information in order to use it to provide navigational
structure or cues.

The use case is reimplementing the site navigation so that a user can more
easily navigate to "My Photography course", "My research group's
Retigeranic Acid Synthesis discussion group", "The Chess Club", "The
Campus Campaign to Rename Utah" without having to scroll through a list of
say 30 (or 300) worksites that they are a member of.  Rather they would
select "My Research -> Retigeranic Acid Sythesis" or "My Clubs ->
Political -> Campaign to Rename Utah".

Our focus right now is on "ad hoc" collaborations and not courses,
although that will follow.

If this is not possible, should it be?

yuji
----

On Mon, 12 Dec 2005, Jim Farmer wrote:

> Manchester Metropolitan is leading the development of a toolkit to
> provide a course service. This work can be found at
> http://www.jisc.ac.uk/index.cfm?name=elfref_mmu&src=alpha and
> http://www.elframework.org/projects/xcri. The specification is being
> coordinated with U.S. software firms and PESC and SIF. This will become
> one of the JISC services using XML, SOAP, and WSDL. Note this
> specification can answer the course questions, but not the collaboration
> questions, worksite sponsorships, or a general search of metadata which
> may answer "kayaking" (unless Kayak was in the name of the worksite
> sponsor).
>
> Someone at the University of Essex may be able to better answer your
> question about collaborations. They are planning work on the use of the
> FOAF (friend of a friend) protocol to identify "collaborations." This
> builds on their Chimera project http://www.essex.ac.uk/chimera/index.html.
>
> A collaboration network could be built from course enrollments
> (including sections and projects) and any address the user may have in
> their collaboration tools. Because collaboration is coming from other
> research, a separate collaboration service built on the Chimera work may
> be preferable.
>
> jim farmer
>
>
> Yuji Shinozaki wrote:
>
> >Is there any taxonomy of worksites?  Or any accessible meta data about
> >worksites that can be used to organize them?
> >
> >What I would like to be able to answer are these types of questions:
> >
> >What are my Courses?
> >What are my Collaborations?
> >What are my Courses for the Spring Term 2003?
> >What are my Courses this semester?
> >What are my Physics courses?
> >What are my Ad Hoc Collaborations?
> >What are all the worksites sponsored by the Campus Democrats?
> >What worksites concern Kayaking?
> >
> >I have scanned the architecture documents and can't seem to find anything
> >specifically addressing this question.  Please point me in the right
> >direction if this documentation exists.
> >
> >If this type of course meta-data does not exist, are their plans for
> >implementing it?
> >
> >Yuji Shinozaki	                        Computer Systems Senior Engineer
> >ys2n@virginia.edu			Advanced Technologies Group
> >(434)924-7171				Information Technology & Communication
> >http://www.people.virginia.edu/~ys2n    University of Virginia
> >

body:
Yuji,
You can create any type of worksite you want. The Admin Sites tool has a 
field for site type - if you were to type something in there other than 
course or project, you'd then have a new type. But to have that type be 
presented as a selection in Worksite setup when you choose at the 
beginning what type of site you want to create, you need to edit the 
sakai.sitesetup.xml file (at 
/trunk/sakai/legacy/tools/src/webapp/tools/sakai.sitesetup.xml) and add 
the new type.

Then you would also need to edit tool registration files to add that new 
type, so that a given tool shows up as one that can be selected to 
include in that type of site when it is created.

There are some notes (just ppt slides at this point) in this 
presentation that may help.
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/download/attachments/9638/Configuring+Sakai+Austin.ppt

Then to sort, each user in their My Workspace can use the Worksite Setup 
tool to sort their list of sites by type.

There has been talk of implementing a hierarchy in Sakai that would be 
useful in navigating through sites.. I'm not sure if it would help in 
navigating through types of sites though.

John

>
>3. access this information in order to use it to provide navigational

>
>The use case is reimplementing the site navigation so that a user can more
>easily navigate to "My Photography course", "My research group's
>Retigeranic Acid Synthesis discussion group", "The Chess Club", "The
>Campus Campaign to Rename Utah" without having to scroll through a list of
>say 30 (or 300) worksites that they are a member of.  Rather they would
>select "My Research -> Retigeranic Acid Sythesis" or "My Clubs ->
>Political -> Campaign to Rename Utah".
>
>Our focus right now is on "ad hoc" collaborations and not courses,
>although that will follow.
>
>If this is not possible, should it be?
>
>yuji
>----

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/39>
body:
And site types can be addressed in the rendering, providing different 
looks for different site types. See Appendix B of:


https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/tags/sakai_2-1-0/docs/architecture/sakai_skin_portal.doc

- Gonzalo
<https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/tags/sakai_2-1-0/docs/architecture/sakai_skin_portal.doc>
John Leasia wrote:

> Yuji,
> You can create any type of worksite you want. The Admin Sites tool has 
> a field for site type - if you were to type something in there other 
> than course or project, you'd then have a new type. But to have that 
> type be presented as a selection in Worksite setup when you choose at 
> the beginning what type of site you want to create, you need to edit 
> the sakai.sitesetup.xml file (at 
> /trunk/sakai/legacy/tools/src/webapp/tools/sakai.sitesetup.xml) and 
> add the new type.
>
> Then you would also need to edit tool registration files to add that 
> new type, so that a given tool shows up as one that can be selected to 
> include in that type of site when it is created.
>
> There are some notes (just ppt slides at this point) in this 
> presentation that may help.
> http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/download/attachments/9638/Configuring+Sakai+Austin.ppt 
>
>
> Then to sort, each user in their My Workspace can use the Worksite 
> Setup tool to sort their list of sites by type.
>
> There has been talk of implementing a hierarchy in Sakai that would be 
> useful in navigating through sites.. I'm not sure if it would help in 
> navigating through types of sites though.
>
> John
>
> Yuji Shinozaki wrote:
>
>> Thanks for the response.  But perhaps I should provide some scope to my
>> question.  I am talking more in terms of:  given an out-of-the-box
>> installation of sakai, what would I have to implement in order to:
>>
>> 1. identify a worksite as being a "course" or a "collaboration" or a 
>> "hoe
>> down" or a "singles mixer" or any other arbitrary classification.
>>
>> 2. sort worksites according to those classifications, hopefully with 
>> some
>> notion of hierachy.
>>
>> 3. access this information in order to use it to provide navigational
>> structure or cues.
>>
>> The use case is reimplementing the site navigation so that a user can 
>> more
>> easily navigate to "My Photography course", "My research group's
>> Retigeranic Acid Synthesis discussion group", "The Chess Club", "The
>> Campus Campaign to Rename Utah" without having to scroll through a 
>> list of
>> say 30 (or 300) worksites that they are a member of.  Rather they would
>> select "My Research -> Retigeranic Acid Sythesis" or "My Clubs ->
>> Political -> Campaign to Rename Utah".
>>
>> Our focus right now is on "ad hoc" collaborations and not courses,
>> although that will follow.
>>
>> If this is not possible, should it be?
>>
>> yuji
>> ----
>>
>> On Mon, 12 Dec 2005, Jim Farmer wrote:
>>
>>  
>>
>>> Manchester Metropolitan is leading the development of a toolkit to
>>> provide a course service. This work can be found at
>>> http://www.jisc.ac.uk/index.cfm?name=elfref_mmu&src=alpha and
>>> http://www.elframework.org/projects/xcri. The specification is being
>>> coordinated with U.S. software firms and PESC and SIF. This will become
>>> one of the JISC services using XML, SOAP, and WSDL. Note this
>>> specification can answer the course questions, but not the 
>>> collaboration
>>> questions, worksite sponsorships, or a general search of metadata which
>>> may answer "kayaking" (unless Kayak was in the name of the worksite
>>> sponsor).
>>>
>>> Someone at the University of Essex may be able to better answer your
>>> question about collaborations. They are planning work on the use of the
>>> FOAF (friend of a friend) protocol to identify "collaborations." This
>>> builds on their Chimera project 
>>> http://www.essex.ac.uk/chimera/index.html.
>>>
>>> A collaboration network could be built from course enrollments
>>> (including sections and projects) and any address the user may have in
>>> their collaboration tools. Because collaboration is coming from other
>>> research, a separate collaboration service built on the Chimera work 
>>> may
>>> be preferable.
>>>
>>> jim farmer
>>>
>>>
>>> Yuji Shinozaki wrote:
>>>
>>>   
>>>
>>>> Is there any taxonomy of worksites?  Or any accessible meta data about
>>>> worksites that can be used to organize them?
>>>>
>>>> What I would like to be able to answer are these types of questions:
>>>>
>>>> What are my Courses?
>>>> What are my Collaborations?
>>>> What are my Courses for the Spring Term 2003?
>>>> What are my Courses this semester?
>>>> What are my Physics courses?
>>>> What are my Ad Hoc Collaborations?
>>>> What are all the worksites sponsored by the Campus Democrats?
>>>> What worksites concern Kayaking?
>>>>
>>>> I have scanned the architecture documents and can't seem to find 
>>>> anything
>>>> specifically addressing this question.  Please point me in the right
>>>> direction if this documentation exists.
>>>>
>>>> If this type of course meta-data does not exist, are their plans for
>>>> implementing it?
>>>>
>>>> Yuji Shinozaki                            Computer Systems Senior 
>>>> Engineer
>>>> ys2n@virginia.edu            Advanced Technologies Group
>>>> (434)924-7171                Information Technology & Communication
>>>> http://www.people.virginia.edu/~ys2n    University of Virginia
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------

>>>> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development

body:
I'm having a problem with sakai 2.1 ... environment is fedora core 4,
mysql 4.1.15, mysql-connector-java-3.0.16-ga-bin, tomcat 5.5.9,  java
1.5.0_05  ( java 1.5 compile required two small changes).  Sakai 2.0.1
ran fine in this environment. In 2.1.0 I can log in as admin, and some
tools work normally, others do not display any content. Logging in as
non-admin users gives the attached error screen, and the following
entries in catalina.out. Looks like  database issue - this kind of error
happens both with the migrated 2.0.1 -> 2.1.0 database and a fresh
database. Has anyone seen anything similar?  Thanks for any light you
can shed on this.

Jim

body:
Some of you may have heard my occasional laments that Oracle ADF Faces (the 
only really rich JSF component library out there) wasn't open source. Well, 
the Oracle JSF team (who have always seemed like good guys) announced in 
Antwerp today that they've gotten permission to donate the library to MyFaces:

http://technology.amis.nl/blog/?p=947

This is great news for open source JSF developers, should you happen to 
know any.  :)

Ray

	for sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org; Tue, 13 Dec 2005 14:06:20 +0000
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.08 [en] (WinNT; U)
To: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
X-Content-Type-Outer-Envelope: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-CARET-Spam-Score: -1.4 (-)
X-CARET-Scan-Signature: d32f40dcde79cee72bb82e0e151a9407
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/40>
body:
Could somebody (Glenn) please tell whether "Direct URLs" 
(as advertised in sakai_tool.pdf of July 12 2005 as "TBD" - is there
are more recent version of this document) are working yet?

Central capability required is to embed info specifying the "URL stub"
that will be passed to a tool as specifying its navigation state into
the global Sakai portal URL - I presume this will be done via 
URL-encoding the entire stub with some attribute name that identifies
the tool instance somehow...

I'd like to get info on global portal URL generation in general - 
I read ominous threats at some point that this had been generified
and that we could no longer always depend on the expected
address/ site / page structure - where is the code which operates
this?

Cheers,
Antranig.

body:
It appears that the only way to access entity objects is via a valid reference object/string for that entity.  Currently, you are not able to get a list of all entities, or entities with certain properties from an EntityProducer.  As a result, I am still forced to grab a list of specific objects from a specific service, such as Assignment objects from the AssignmentService.  Only then can I use them as entities.  Thus my tool is dependent on specific services.

Alternatively (I am making some assumptions here), I can create a helper tool that other tools use or add a dependency to my service within other services in order to pass entity references.  Now that my service has these references, I can use them to grab entities without dependency on other services.  This alternative, however, forces other tools to use my service/helper.

Is there a way to pass references without creating these dependencies?  If not, should there be, or are there other considerations?

Jim

James M Pease - Software Developer - The Living SchoolBook
030 Huntington Hall - Syracuse University - Syracuse, NY 13244
315-443-3450

Hello, Everyone
It is nice to see most of you in Austin during the Sakai conference. It 
was a wonderful and successful conference.
Well, we encountered a problem to upgrade to Sakai2.1from v2.0.1. 

The procedure we did:
1. Renamed sakai-src as "sakai-src-bak".
2, DLL sakai2.1 source as sakai-src.
3. Remove .maven/repository.
4. Did "maven clean"
5. Built successful
6. start tomcat, we got this error:
(should mention 2 things: 
-   we use MySQL database and as suggested, using mysql-connector 
v3.1.12 instead of v3.1.11

"defaultTransactionIsolationString@javax.sql.BaseDataSource = 
TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED"  )

subject: utf-8 problem on sakai 2.1 with mysql

body:
I'm looking into problems reported with the UTF-8 characters in =20
Syllabus (and Samingo), which I've reproduced in both Sakai 2.0.1/=20
mysql and Sakai 2.1/mysql. The problem does not exist with HySqlDb. I =20
have my suspicions that the problem has something to do with =20
hibernate, but I haven't had the time to completely debug the =20
problem. UTF-8 Characters entered into the Syllbus (e.g. title) are =20
rendered at question marks ("??") after the changes have been saved =20
in MySql. Has anyone else duplicated this problem and/or have any =20
insight into it's cause?

I noticed that JIRA SAK-116  reports this problem is fixed with =20
Oracle by applying the self-described kludge of r3807, but this patch =20
does not affect the problem with MySql.

I've included in this message a thread regarding other UTF-8 problems =20
in 2.0.1/mysql that appear to have been resolved in Sakai 2.1. In =20
case these problems have a common cause, does anyone know what was =20
done to resolve the problems mentioned below in Mike's email?

Thanks,
- Beth

On Oct 22, 2005, at 9:37 PM, Mike Osterman wrote:

> Hi Mike,
>
> I still haven't chased down all of the Unicode gremlins in my =20
> installation. They definitely seem related to MySQL, as the same =20
> codebase works flawlessly when using the default HSQL dB.
>
> The steps I've taken to attempt to remedy the problem are:
> * Ensuring that Tomcat server.xml is configured for UTF-8 on all ports
> * Updated to the latest version of the 3.1.x MySQL connector
> * Updated to the latest version of the 4.x MySQL server for Linux =20
> (MySQL.com pre-built RPM for RHEL3)
> * Exported all my tables, recreated the database with the correct =20
> default charset, and then reimported the tables.
>
> UTF-8 works in many places, but the few I've found that don't and =20
> are reproducible time after time are:
> * Admin workspace Pages tool - when attempting to rename Pages with =20
> accented characters, edits appear to be taking until the site edit =20
> is saved (at which point I'm assuming the object in memory is saved =20
> to MySQL). The renamed pages show up truncated at the unicode =20
> character. For example, Informaci=F3n becomes Informaci.
> * Assignments tool - using unicode characters in attributes of an =20
> assignment results in truncated XML in the MySQL database at the =20
> location of the first instance of the unicode character. No error =20
> is displayed to the end-user, and the only error in catalina.out is =20
> the resulting SAX XML parser error when redirected from Save to the =20
> listing of assignments. The assignments are not listed in the =20
> general listing. The SAX error is generated for each record with =20
> truncated XML during the iteration of the assignment list.
> * Resources tool - creating a URL resource with accented characters =20
> results in an error on post. For example, creating a URL item with =20
> the title "primer=EA" will result in the message "Alert: The URL =20
> title primer=EA has been used." This can be worked around by adding =20
> the object with no accented characters, then editing the object and =20
> setting the proper accented title and updating. We experience no =20
> problems with accented characters in titles for file uploads.
>
> I've been meaning to hook up a debugger and get to the bottom of =20
> this for some time now. Hopefully I can get to it this week.
>
> Michael Osterman
> Developer, Emerging Technology
> Whitman College
> ostermmg@whitman.edu
> 509-527-5419
>
>
> On Oct 20, 2005, at 3:03 PM, Mike De Simone wrote:
>
>> I haven't seen any updates in a while to this in any of the =20
>> referenced issues: 1688, 2015, 1357.  Does anyone know the state =20
>> of this issue currently?
>>
>> I am unable to create folders in the resources area with, for =20
>> instance, names with Hawaiian characters in their names. Or, more =20
>> correctly, I *can* create the folder, but when I try to access it, =20
>> I get the 'Alert: The collection does not exist" error.  If I look =20
>> in the database, the characters in question appear to have been =20
>> converted to question marks.
>>
>> I am using mysql connector 3.1.10, and have the tomcat URI =20
>> encoding set up (going through Apache, which has the =20
>> AddDefaultCharset UTF-8 directive set).
>>
>>
>> -----------------
>> Mike De Simone
>> Director of Client Support
>> The rSmart Group
>> 602-840-7300 x106
>> icq: 161896611
>>
>>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: Mike Osterman [mailto:ostermmg@whitman.edu]
>> Sent: Saturday, September 17, 2005 9:47 AM
>> To: sakai-dev
>> Cc: sakai-dev
>> Subject: Re: UTF-8 problem on Sakai 2.0.1 with MySQL
>>
>> James,
>>
>> I can verify this identical behavior with the correct 3.1.x
>> connector. Assignment XML is truncated in the database and the
>> assignment is not listed. I get log errors as the assigment list
>> iterates through the record set and hits each "bad" record.
>>
>> We also have intermittent problems with the Resources tool as well
>> when using Unicode characters in the title, though I haven't seem
>> system-wide instability with the tool as a result.
>>
>> I have anecdotal evidence from pilot testers that creating the
>> resource with non-Unicode characters first, then editing and adding
>> the Unicode characters at that point, it works. I have yet to verify
>> this behavior myself.
>>
>> Michael Osterman
>> Developer, Emerging Technology
>> Whitman College
>> ostermmg@whitman.edu
>> 509-527-5419
>>
>>
>> On Sep 13, 2005, at 11:27 AM, James Williamson wrote:
>>
>>
>>> Hi folks,
>>>
>>> We looked into this problem a bit and filed an issue report in Jira
>>> (SAK-2015). Below are our notes on this issue.
>>>
>>> Discovered in Assignments and Resources
>>> Manifestation - Assignments:
>>> - If a user creates an assignment with a Unicode character in the
>>> Title field, the assignment does not show up in the list of
>>> assignments
>>> - The catalina.out log reveals a XML parsing error.
>>> - The MySQL database field contains an incomplete XML file that
>>> ends at the point where the Unicode character was found.
>>>
>>> Manifestation - Resources:
>>> - If a file upload contains a foreign character in the file name,
>>> the Resources tool may become unstable throughout the system and be
>>> unavailable to all sites.
>>>
>>> Comments
>>> - When the form used by the "New Assignment" page is processed, it
>>> generates an entire XML file and stores it in the database.
>>> - Examples are from the from assignment_content table. Other tables
>>> tables may be affected as well.
>>>
>>> Example good record:
>>> <?xml version=3D"1.0" encoding=3D"UTF-8"?>
>>> <content allowattach=3D"true"
>>> context=3D"b32cfe66-9ecc-4cba-0043-1e0df90222c1"
>>> datecreated=3D"20050826171605824" groupproject=3D"true" honorpledge=3D"=
1"
>>> id=3D"54293ba9-f85d-4d17-80ca-bbdd837754aa" indivgraded=3D"false"
>>> instructions=3D"SMOpcsOpIGlzIGEgbsOpdyBzdHJpbmcu
>>> "
>>> instructions-html=3D"SMOpcsOpIGlzIGEgbsOpdyBzdHJpbmcu
>>> "
>>> lastmod=3D"20050826171605824" numberofattachments=3D"0"
>>> numberofauthors=3D"0" releasegrades=3D"false" scaled_maxgradepoint=3D"0=
"
>>> submissiontype=3D"3" title=3D"Foreign Title" typeofgrade=3D"1">
>>> <properties>
>>> <property enc=3D"BASE64" name=3D"CHEF:creator" value=3D"YWRtaW4=3D
>>> "/>
>>> <property enc=3D"BASE64" name=3D"CHEF:modifiedby" value=3D"YWRtaW4=3D
>>> "/>
>>> <property enc=3D"BASE64" name=3D"DAV:getlastmodified"
>>> value=3D"MjAwNTA4MjYxNzE2MDgxMzU=3D
>>> "/>
>>> <property enc=3D"BASE64" name=3D"DAV:creationdate"
>>> value=3D"MjAwNTA4MjYxNzE2MDU4MjQ=3D
>>> "/>
>>> </properties>
>>> </content>
>>>
>>> Example bad record:
>>> <?xml version=3D"1.0" encoding=3D"UTF-8"?>
>>> <content allowattach=3D"true"
>>> context=3D"b32cfe66-9ecc-4cba-0043-1e0df90222c1"
>>> datecreated=3D"20050826171447016" groupproject=3D"true" honorpledge=3D"=
1"
>>> id=3D"ac84f7f7-e5a2-47aa-0090-eb72fe7b073b" indivgraded=3D"false"
>>> instructions=3D"VGhpcyBpcyBhIGZvcmVpZ24tbMO4w7hraW5nIHDDqmPDvGNlIG9mIH=
=20
>>> TD
>>> qXh0Lg=3D=3D
>>> "
>>> instructions-
>>> html=3D"VGhpcyBpcyBhIGZvcmVpZ24tbMO4w7hraW5nIHDDqmPDvGNlIG9mIHTDqXh0Lg=
=20
>>> =3D=3D
>>>
>>>
>> "
>>
>>> lastmod=3D"20050826171447016" numberofattachments=3D"0"
>>> numberofauthors=3D"0" releasegrades=3D"false" scaled_maxgradepoint=3D"0=
"
>>> submissiontype=3D"3" title=3D"Foreign Titl
>>>
>>> - Note that in the "bad record" that the data is truncated at the
>>> point where the original field data was "Foreign Titl=E9"
>>> - The "instructions" and "instructions-html" data values are being
>>> BASE64 encoded and thus are not vulnerable to this error.
>>> - The "title" data is stored as-entered by the user.
>>> - The data from the entire "New Assignment" form is being
>>> serialized into XML string and then stored in the database.
>>> - Upon retrieval of the data for display (as when refreshing the
>>> screen immediately after submission), the catalina.out log file
>>> shows the error and the new Assignment does not display in the list
>>> of Assignments. There is no warning to the user.
>>> - The error is: "WARN: readDocumentFromString:
>>> org.xml.sax.SAXParseException: XML document structures must start
>>> and end within the same entity." and "[Fatal Error] :8:67: XML
>>> document structures must start and end within the same entity."
>>> - The character set for the MySQL table is UTF-8 and we are using
>>> MySQL connector 3.1.
>>>
>>> Some additional comments:
>>>
>>> - Some of the data in the XML file is automatically pulled from
>>> Sakai. Some of this auto-generated data stored in the "property"
>>> element is repeated in the parent "content" element, albeit in an
>>> encoded fashion. Compare, for example,
>>> datecreated=3D"20050826171605824" with <property enc=3D"BASE64"
>>> name=3D"DAV:creationdate" value=3D"MjAwNTA4MjYxNzE2MDU4MjQ=3D
>>> "/> .
>>>
>>> - Some user-entered data within the "content" element is encoded
>>> but other user-entered data also within the "content" element is
>>> not encoded. Compare, for example,
>>> instructions=3D"SMOpcsOpIGlzIGEgbsOpdyBzdHJpbmcu
>>> " with title=3D"Foreign Title"
>>>
>>> Best regards, and we hope this helps,
>>>
>>> Jim
>>>
>>>
>>> On Sep 6, 2005, at 3:19 AM, Torben Bruun wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>> Hi,
>>>>
>>>> We're running Sakai 2.0.1 on Debian Linux with MySQL. We're having
>>>> problems with Danish letters - for instance if trying to add a
>>>> resource containing danish letters in the URl or in the name of
>>>> resource.
>>>>
>>>> MySQL database is created using
>>>>
>>>> create database sakai default character set utf8;
>>>>
>>>> show variables in mysql gives
>>>>
>>>> |
>>>> | character_set_client            | utf8 |
>>>> | character_set_connection        | utf8 |
>>>> | character_set_database          | utf8 |
>>>> | character_set_results           | utf8 |
>>>> | character_set_server            | utf8 |
>>>> | character_set_system            | utf8 |
>>>> | character_sets_dir              | /usr/share/mysql/charsets/ |
>>>> | collation_connection            | utf8_general_ci |
>>>> | collation_database              | utf8_general_ci |
>>>> | collation_server                | utf8_general_ci
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> We've applied fix for SAK-1688 conserning using setBytes instead
>>>> of setCharacters.
>>>>
>>>> In Tomcat server.xml we've added
>>>>
>>>> <Connector port=3D"443" maxHttpHeaderSize=3D"8192"
>>>> URIEncoding=3D"UTF-8" ......
>>>>
>>>> We're running Apache in front of Tomcat. Apache is set to default
>>>> character set utf-8.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> Does anyone have an idea about , why we still get problems with
>>>> danish characters ?
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> kind regards
>>>>
>>>> Torben Bruun
>>>>

>>>> collab.sakaiproject.org) from the Sakai Development site.
>>>> You can modify how you receive notifications at MyWorkspace >
>>>> Preferences.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>

body:
Hi,
I have been looking at the SectionManager API and other section-related 
API's. I noticed that the addSection() .. method description mentions 
that this adds a section to a parent course section.

What is the method that is responsible for adding sections to a site ?  
addSection() method seems to me that it would need that a CourseSection 
to already exist before further sections can be added.

Suppose I create a site as follows

SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);

This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course site/project site.

Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can perform 
this function.

Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.

Regards,
Vishwak Rajgopalan
UC Merced

body:
Hi all,

I am wondering if Sakai developers considering to implement "password
forgotten" feature like it in many other sites, e.g. Yahoo groups. When
the user click on the "Password forgotten" link, Sakai will send a copy
of the user's password to this user's email account. This feature prove
to be helpful tool for Sakai/sites administrators. It will be so much
easier to administering a site.

Anyone have any ideas where I may find some sample codes if I want to
try to code myself?

Thanks,
William Chang

----------------------
