body:
Thanks Glenn. After we cleaned up Tomcat, it works. Is that true if the 
file has the same name, maven won't overwrite the old file?

We got an error when the "htt://sakai.unl.edu:8080/portal" started. At the 
main site, it displays "The page cannot be displayed", but on the same 
page  "Gateway" link works, by clicking "Gateway" I can access the main 
page and login.

Do you know what is this problem and how to solve it? I guess somewhere 
site mapping not correct, but we did not modify anything in 
sakai.properties file except things related to MySQL database setting.

Thanks
Grace





"Glenn R. Golden" <ggolden@umich.edu> 
12/14/2005 06:21 PM

To
Grace Wang <gwang3@unlnotes.unl.edu>
cc
sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
Subject
Re: Error to run Sakai 2.1 with MySQL






I think the problem here is shown in this error message (see below) - note 
the class it is attempting to set.  This is not correct, since for Sakai 
2.1 we use a different DataSource class.  I'm not sure how you have ended 
up with this situation; perhaps from customizations to the kernel's 
sakai.properties, perhaps a bad mixing of 2.0 and 2.1 runtime artifacts.

The file in sakai/kernel/db-components/src/webapp/WEB-INF/components.xml 
is where the DataSource is declared in Sakai.  It reads like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE beans PUBLIC "-//SPRING//DTD BEAN//EN" "
http://www.springkernel.org/dtd/spring-beans.dtd">

<beans>

<!-- Base DataSource for all pooled database connections -->
<!-- See http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dbcp/configuration.html -->
<bean id="javax.sql.BaseDataSource" abstract="true"
class="org.apache.commons.dbcp.SakaiBasicDataSource"
destroy-method="close">

Note the class is a Sakai one, SakaiBasicDataSource, not the Apache one, 
BasicDataSource.  Somehow in your runtime, the older definition still 
seems to be in play - otherwise the error message would have read:

'defaultTransactionIsolationString' of bean class 
[org.apache.commons.dbcp. SakaiBasicDataSource]: Bean...

I recommend the following.  Install a clean new Tomcat, so you have no 
chance of having some Sakai 2.0 jars or wars lying around.  Make sure you 
are using completely unmodified Sakai source.  Clean your maven repo 
(again).  Build, deploy, and put in place your sakai.properties with your 
proper MySQL settings, etc.

At this point, there's no way you can get a message like below.
- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu


On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:01 PM, Grace Wang wrote:

'defaultTransactionIsolationString' of bean class  
[org.apache.commons.dbcp.BasicDataSource]: Bean property  
'defaultTransactionIsolationString' is not writable or has an invalid  
setter method: Does the parameter type of the setter match the return 

[see attachment: "message0.html", size: 5069 bytes]

body:
Did you happen to read my message from Dec 13?  In it, I explained that:

"UC Merced has chosen to expose an API that, by default, is not exposed 
in the shared Component Manager... The API is deliberately not exposed 
because we anticipate that it will either be removed in the next version 
of sakai, or it will be so radically changed that it will essentially be 
a different API."

The SectionManager API can be exposed by uncommenting the SectionManager 
bean definition in its components.xml.  We don't recommend this (see 
above), but it will allow you to proceed with approach #1 as you've 
described it.

Josh

Nuno Fernandes wrote:

> Hi All,
>
> I am currently implementing a Quartz Job to synchronize an internal DB 
> with the Sakai DB (users, sites, sections,...) through the Sakai API.
> Everything synchronizes ok except for the section tasks as I am having 
> trouble accessing the SectionManager API (I have read the lattest 
> discussion on SectionManager)
> I tried with the following approaches while attempting access to the 
> SessionManager object:
> 1) SectionManager sm = (SectionManager) 
> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager"); 
> // as suggested by Steven Githens and Josh Holtzman
> 2) SectionManager sm = new SectionManagerImpl(); // the implementation 
> class, not the preferable way...
>
> Both compiled ok with Maven but revealed unsuccessful to me at runtime:
> Approach 1) returned me:
> WARN: get(org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager): 
> org.springframework.beans.factory.NoSuchBeanDefinitionException: No 
> bean named 'org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager' is defined
> Approach 2) returned me:
> java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: 
> org/sakaiproject/component/section/sakai21/SectionManagerImpl
>
> I've configured project.xml in order to resolve the following 
> dependencies:  sakai-session, sakai-tool, sakai-sections-api, 
> sakai-component and sakai-sections-comp-shared-sakai21
> Maven doesn't complain while compiling since this object is instantied 
> dynamically at runtime (although it probably should complain with 
> approach 2??).
>
> Is this a missing dependency at project.xml?
> Anyone with the same problem who can help me with directions?
>
> Thanks in advance,
> Nuno Fernandes.
>
>
> Steven Githens wrote:
>
>> Vishwak,
>>
>> I've been using the following methods in my local sakaiscript to do 
>> this:
>>
>>
>> private static SectionAwareness getSA()
>> {
>> return (SectionAwareness) 
>> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionAwareness");
>> }
>>
>> private static SectionManager getSM()
>> {
>> return (SectionManager) 
>> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager");
>> }
>>
>> public static String addSection(String siteid, String title,
>> String category, int maxEnrollments, String location,
>> String startTime, String endTime,
>> boolean monday, boolean tuesday, boolean wednesday, boolean thursday,
>> boolean friday, boolean saturday, boolean sunday)
>> {
>> try {
>> SectionManager sm = getSM();
>> Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
>> String courseUuid = course.getUuid();
>> //TODO: Add String conversions for times
>> CourseSection cs = sm.addSection(courseUuid, title, category,
>> new Integer(maxEnrollments), location, null, null, monday,
>> tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday, sunday);
>> if (cs != null)
>> return Jws.formatSuccess();
>> else
>> return "<error/>";
>> }
>> catch (Exception e) {
>> return Jws.formatException(e);
>> }
>> }
>>
>> // public ParticipationRecord addSectionMembership(String userUid, 
>> Role role, String sectionUuid)
>> public static String addSectionMembership(String siteid, String 
>> sectiontitle, String userid, String role)
>> {
>> try {
>> // 1.  Get the sectionUuid
>> SectionManager sm = getSM();
>> //Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
>> //if (course != null)
>> //    System.out.println("SWG course not null");
>> //else
>> //    System.out.println("SWG course is null");
>>
>> List sections = sm.getSections(siteid);
>> //System.out.println("SWG sect2: " + sections2.size());
>> //List sections = sm.getSections(course.getUuid());
>> //System.out.println("SWG sect: " + sections.size());
>>
>> String sectionUuid = "";
>> for (Iterator i = sections.iterator(); i.hasNext();)
>> {
>> CourseSection cs = (CourseSection) i.next();
>> if (cs.getTitle().equals(sectiontitle))
>> {
>> sectionUuid = cs.getUuid();
>> //System.out.println("section" + sectiontitle + " matches: " + 
>> sectionUuid);
>> }
>> }
>> // 2. Get the userUid??
>> String userUid = userid;
>>
>> if (role.equals("instructor"))
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.INSTRUCTOR, sectionUuid);
>> else if (role.equals("ta"))
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.TA, sectionUuid);
>> else if (role.equals("student"))
>> {
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.STUDENT, sectionUuid);
>> }
>> else
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.NONE, sectionUuid);
>>
>> }
>> catch (Exception e) {
>> e.printStackTrace();
>> return Jws.formatException(e);
>> }
>>
>> return Jws.formatSuccess();
>> }
>>
>> Vishwak Rajgopalan wrote:
>>
>>> Hi,
>>> I have been looking at the SectionManager API and other 
>>> section-related API's. I noticed that the addSection() .. method 
>>> description mentions that this adds a section to a parent course 
>>> section.
>>>
>>> What is the method that is responsible for adding sections to a site 
>>> ?  addSection() method seems to me that it would need that a 
>>> CourseSection to already exist before further sections can be added.
>>>
>>> Suppose I create a site as follows
>>>
>>> SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);
>>>
>>> This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course site/project 
>>> site.
>>>
>>> Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
>>> siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
>>> course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
>>> SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can 
>>> perform this function.
>>>
>>> Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.
>>>
>>> Regards,
>>> Vishwak Rajgopalan

body:
Maria Lorna Kunnath wrote:
> To Charles and Sakai Collab Group:
>
> I designed a Telemedicine course (for an Instructor at UCDHS) and uploaded it on Sakai via the 'Resources' tab.  The course was built on MS Producer realizing that  'Melete' Course Builder is not able to handle a bundle of different files to enable the seamless loading of the course.  The problem with putting it on the 'Resources' directory is that when a user (learner) logs in, all the other subfiles also appear within the same window making it necessary for the user to scroll through multiple files just to find the major course file.  At its current condition this method is cumbersome and would prefer that a user simply goes to a Module or Course tab and be able to click the Telemedicine course, with the course loading instantly (without subfiles appearing which by the way at its current state could be moved, deleted or modified by anyone having access).
>
> Any suggestions?  Is there another tool I can use?  Does sakai have this capability built in already which I'm unaware of?  Thanks and I appreciate your help.
>   
I don't know what format MS Producer is producing, but if it's a set of 
HTML files with its own navigation structure, you can just add a Web 
Content tool pointing to the index page inside the Resources collection 
(e.g. a URL like /access/content/group/siteid/module1/index.html).

Regards
Stephen

-- 
Stephen Marquard, Learning Technologies Co-ordinator
Centre for Educational Technology, University of Cape Town
http://www.cet.uct.ac.za
Email: marquard@ched.uct.ac.za IM: xmpp:marquard@ched.uct.ac.za
Phone: +27-21-650-5037 Cell: +27-83-500-5290

beans through Spring.

>>> CourseSection to already exist before further sections can be added.
>>>
>>> Suppose I create a site as follows
>>>
>>> SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);
>>>
>>> This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course site/project 
>>> site.
>>>
>>> Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
>>> siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
>>> course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
>>> SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can 
>>> perform this function.
>>>
>>> Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.
>>>
>>> Regards,
>>> Vishwak Rajgopalan
>>> UC Merced
>>>

body:
Files with the same name will be replaced, but the files from 2.0 and  
2.1 have different names, mostly.  It's very very important to keep  
your Tomcat very very clean when working with changing software like  
the TRUNK or different Sakai versions.

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu


On Dec 15, 2005, at 11:16 AM, Grace Wang wrote:

> Thanks Glenn. After we cleaned up Tomcat, it works. Is that true if  
> the
> file has the same name, maven won't overwrite the old file?
>
> We got an error when the "htt://sakai.unl.edu:8080/portal" started.  
> At the
> main site, it displays "The page cannot be displayed", but on the same
> page  "Gateway" link works, by clicking "Gateway" I can access the  
> main
> page and login.
>
> Do you know what is this problem and how to solve it? I guess  
> somewhere
> site mapping not correct, but we did not modify anything in
> sakai.properties file except things related to MySQL database setting.
>
> Thanks
> Grace
>
>
>
>
>
> "Glenn R. Golden" <ggolden@umich.edu>
> 12/14/2005 06:21 PM
>
> To
> Grace Wang <gwang3@unlnotes.unl.edu>
> cc
> sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
> Subject
> Re: Error to run Sakai 2.1 with MySQL
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I think the problem here is shown in this error message (see below)  
> - note
> the class it is attempting to set.  This is not correct, since for  
> Sakai
> 2.1 we use a different DataSource class.  I'm not sure how you have  
> ended
> up with this situation; perhaps from customizations to the kernel's
> sakai.properties, perhaps a bad mixing of 2.0 and 2.1 runtime  
> artifacts.
>
> The file in sakai/kernel/db-components/src/webapp/WEB-INF/ 
> components.xml
> is where the DataSource is declared in Sakai.  It reads like this:
>
> <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
> <!DOCTYPE beans PUBLIC "-//SPRING//DTD BEAN//EN" "
> http://www.springkernel.org/dtd/spring-beans.dtd">
>
> <beans>
>
> <!-- Base DataSource for all pooled database connections -->
> <!-- See http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dbcp/configuration.html -->
> <bean id="javax.sql.BaseDataSource" abstract="true"
> class="org.apache.commons.dbcp.SakaiBasicDataSource"
> destroy-method="close">
>
> Note the class is a Sakai one, SakaiBasicDataSource, not the Apache  
> one,
> BasicDataSource.  Somehow in your runtime, the older definition still
> seems to be in play - otherwise the error message would have read:
>
> 'defaultTransactionIsolationString' of bean class
> [org.apache.commons.dbcp. SakaiBasicDataSource]: Bean...
>
> I recommend the following.  Install a clean new Tomcat, so you have no
> chance of having some Sakai 2.0 jars or wars lying around.  Make  
> sure you
> are using completely unmodified Sakai source.  Clean your maven repo
> (again).  Build, deploy, and put in place your sakai.properties  
> with your
> proper MySQL settings, etc.
>
> At this point, there's no way you can get a message like below.
> - Glenn
>
> Glenn R. Golden
> Sakai Framework Architect
> University Of Michigan
> ggolden@umich.edu
>
>
> On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:01 PM, Grace Wang wrote:
>
> 'defaultTransactionIsolationString' of bean class
> [org.apache.commons.dbcp.BasicDataSource]: Bean property
> 'defaultTransactionIsolationString' is not writable or has an invalid
> setter method: Does the parameter type of the setter match the return
>
> [see attachment: "message0.html", size: 5069 bytes]
>
>
> Attachments:
>
> message0.html
> http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/ 
> 483264d5-1153-4bfe-8079-afe5f8b0fba4/message0.html

body:
Glenn,

Thanks again. The problem has been solved.
But the issue is even after we cleaned Tomcat, the problem was still 
there. We also removed maven\repository directory as suggested. Then we 
found under maven\cache, there are two directories: one is sakai-2.0 and 
another is sakai-2.1. Somehow, when maven runs, it picked up information 
from sakai-2.0 instead of sakai-2.1. After we manually deleted 
maven\cache\sakai-2.0. Re-built, it works.

Is it something we should document into installation Guide? It only 
mentioned to remove maven\repository directory, not mention remove 
maven\cache\sakai-2.0 if doing upgrade.

Regards
Grace




"Glenn R. Golden" <ggolden@umich.edu> 
12/15/2005 10:34 AM

To
Grace Wang <gwang3@unlnotes.unl.edu>
cc
sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
Subject
Re: "Page cannot be displayed" - HTTP 404






Files with the same name will be replaced, but the files from 2.0 and 
2.1 have different names, mostly.  It's very very important to keep 
your Tomcat very very clean when working with changing software like 
the TRUNK or different Sakai versions.

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu

body:
Nuno,

You probably need to go into your Sakai installation at:

sakai/components/sakai-sections-shared-foo-something/components.xml

and uncomment the <bean> entry for SectionManager and restart Sakai.

-Steve

Nuno Fernandes wrote:

> Hi All,
>
> I am currently implementing a Quartz Job to synchronize an internal DB 
> with the Sakai DB (users, sites, sections,...) through the Sakai API.
> Everything synchronizes ok except for the section tasks as I am having 
> trouble accessing the SectionManager API (I have read the lattest 
> discussion on SectionManager)
> I tried with the following approaches while attempting access to the 
> SessionManager object:
> 1) SectionManager sm = (SectionManager) 
> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager"); 
> // as suggested by Steven Githens and Josh Holtzman
> 2) SectionManager sm = new SectionManagerImpl(); // the implementation 
> class, not the preferable way...
>
> Both compiled ok with Maven but revealed unsuccessful to me at runtime:
> Approach 1) returned me:
> WARN: get(org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager): 
> org.springframework.beans.factory.NoSuchBeanDefinitionException: No 
> bean named 'org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager' is defined
> Approach 2) returned me:
> java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: 
> org/sakaiproject/component/section/sakai21/SectionManagerImpl
>
> I've configured project.xml in order to resolve the following 
> dependencies:  sakai-session, sakai-tool, sakai-sections-api, 
> sakai-component and sakai-sections-comp-shared-sakai21
> Maven doesn't complain while compiling since this object is instantied 
> dynamically at runtime (although it probably should complain with 
> approach 2??).
>
> Is this a missing dependency at project.xml?
> Anyone with the same problem who can help me with directions?
>
> Thanks in advance,
> Nuno Fernandes.
>
>
> Steven Githens wrote:
>
>> Vishwak,
>>
>> I've been using the following methods in my local sakaiscript to do 
>> this:
>>
>>
>> private static SectionAwareness getSA()
>> {
>> return (SectionAwareness) 
>> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionAwareness");
>> }
>>
>> private static SectionManager getSM()
>> {
>> return (SectionManager) 
>> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager");
>> }
>>
>> public static String addSection(String siteid, String title,
>> String category, int maxEnrollments, String location,
>> String startTime, String endTime,
>> boolean monday, boolean tuesday, boolean wednesday, boolean thursday,
>> boolean friday, boolean saturday, boolean sunday)
>> {
>> try {
>> SectionManager sm = getSM();
>> Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
>> String courseUuid = course.getUuid();
>> //TODO: Add String conversions for times
>> CourseSection cs = sm.addSection(courseUuid, title, category,
>> new Integer(maxEnrollments), location, null, null, monday,
>> tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday, sunday);
>> if (cs != null)
>> return Jws.formatSuccess();
>> else
>> return "<error/>";
>> }
>> catch (Exception e) {
>> return Jws.formatException(e);
>> }
>> }
>>
>> // public ParticipationRecord addSectionMembership(String userUid, 
>> Role role, String sectionUuid)
>> public static String addSectionMembership(String siteid, String 
>> sectiontitle, String userid, String role)
>> {
>> try {
>> // 1.  Get the sectionUuid
>> SectionManager sm = getSM();
>> //Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
>> //if (course != null)
>> //    System.out.println("SWG course not null");
>> //else
>> //    System.out.println("SWG course is null");
>>
>> List sections = sm.getSections(siteid);
>> //System.out.println("SWG sect2: " + sections2.size());
>> //List sections = sm.getSections(course.getUuid());
>> //System.out.println("SWG sect: " + sections.size());
>>
>> String sectionUuid = "";
>> for (Iterator i = sections.iterator(); i.hasNext();)
>> {
>> CourseSection cs = (CourseSection) i.next();
>> if (cs.getTitle().equals(sectiontitle))
>> {
>> sectionUuid = cs.getUuid();
>> //System.out.println("section" + sectiontitle + " matches: " + 
>> sectionUuid);
>> }
>> }
>> // 2. Get the userUid??
>> String userUid = userid;
>>
>> if (role.equals("instructor"))
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.INSTRUCTOR, sectionUuid);
>> else if (role.equals("ta"))
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.TA, sectionUuid);
>> else if (role.equals("student"))
>> {
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.STUDENT, sectionUuid);
>> }
>> else
>> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.NONE, sectionUuid);
>>
>> }
>> catch (Exception e) {
>> e.printStackTrace();
>> return Jws.formatException(e);
>> }
>>
>> return Jws.formatSuccess();
>> }
>>
>> Vishwak Rajgopalan wrote:
>>
>>> Hi,
>>> I have been looking at the SectionManager API and other 
>>> section-related API's. I noticed that the addSection() .. method 
>>> description mentions that this adds a section to a parent course 
>>> section.
>>>
>>> What is the method that is responsible for adding sections to a site 
>>> ?  addSection() method seems to me that it would need that a 
>>> CourseSection to already exist before further sections can be added.
>>>
>>> Suppose I create a site as follows
>>>
>>> SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);
>>>
>>> This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course site/project 
>>> site.
>>>
>>> Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
>>> siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
>>> course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
>>> SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can 
>>> perform this function.
>>>
>>> Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.
>>>
>>> Regards,
>>> Vishwak Rajgopalan
>>> UC Merced
>>>

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/116>
body:
In JIRA issue SAK-3174, Kevin Metcalf reported the following error:

> /root/src/sakai-src/sections/sections-app/src/java/org/sakaiproject/tool/section/decorator/InstructorSectionDecorator.java:168:
> cannot find symbol
> symbol: method compareTo(java.lang.Object)
> Location: classs java.lang.Object
> int managersComparison = 
> managers1.get(0).toString().compareTo(managers2.get(0));

This happens if you try to compile/deploy Sakai with the 1.5 JDK, 
something that is NOT "officially" recommended. For the moment, you 
MUST use 1.4.2 to get full functionality. I think this is noted in the 
release docs but I guess it could be more prominent.

The transition to 1.5 will happen at some point, but there are a few 
issues including this one; it was described by Glenn noted back in a 
November message:

"This is an interesting change in the Java language.  Comparable in 
1.4 defines compareTo(Object), but in 1.5, it is now:

Comparable<String>

Not just Comparable - and instead of the type-generic Object, it needs 
a String."

The entire contents of Glenn's November message pushed into this 
JIRA item. It is available at:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-3174

Of course, there are those who like to run Sakai under 1.5 -- myself 
included. My preliminary tests show that you can do it with 2.1.0, BUT 
it requires you to give up Section Info functionality and make one 
small change to some Samigo code. Feel free to contact me if you would 
like a copy of the message I sent about this to sakai-dev in November.

Seth

body:
Webdav started working this afternoon following Melete install. Perhaps this
helped, perhaps a conincidence? I remember installing Melete in 2.0.1 before
attempting Webdav connection.

Thank you to everyone with their suggestions.



Jon


-----Original Message-----
From: Jon Higham [mailto:j.higham@hull.ac.uk] 
Sent: 14 December 2005 17:15
To: 'Clay Fenlason'; 'sakai-dev'
Subject: RE: Sakai 2.1 webdav



Thanks, but I'm now more confused than before. I don't appear to have either
conf file, and as far as I can see never have although I did have webdav
working with sakai 2.0.1. I have used a fresh Tomcat for Sakai 2.1, however,
the conf directory for 2.1 looks pretty much the same as 2.0.1. The only
thing from Apache I've ever installed was Tomcat 5.5.9 and a Sakai plugin
for it, and web searches for mod_jk.conf mentions communications between
Apache and Tomcat and that it be placed in Apache/conf directory, whereas I
only have a jakarta-tomcat-5.5.9/conf. 

Should I have this file, or have downloaded it, or do I need to download it?
Sorry, I don't know what to do next.


-----Original Message-----
From: khomotso@gmail.com [mailto:khomotso@gmail.com] On Behalf Of Clay
Fenlason
Sent: 14 December 2005 13:50
To: sakai-dev
Subject: Re: Sakai 2.1 webdav


2005/12/7, Jon Higham <j.higham@hull.ac.uk>:
>
> Sorry, how do I check that the dav path is mapped via the
> apache/tomcat?


I don't know that this is your issue, but just to answer this specific
question: it will be configured in apache's conf directory somewhere, either
in httpd.conf, or in mod_jk.conf (preferred).  You'll need settings that
look something like:

JkMount /* ajp13
#JkMount  /portal/* ajp13
#JkMount /dav/* ajp13
#JkMount /access/* ajp13

That first line is just for handing everything from Apache to Tomcat,
including dav.  The commented ones are for doing crazy things like trying to
hand only certain things to Tomcat, and have Apache handle the rest - like
we did.

~Clay



>

body:
I see that there's a new feature that allows deployers to "stealth" 
tools without needing to edit each tool's registration file.

(in sakai.properties, add 
"stealthTools@org.sakaiproject.api.kernel.tool.ActiveToolManager=toolId1,toolId2,etc")

I'm wondering if this should also stealth the help documentation for 
these tools?  If a tool is hidden from view, shouldn't the help for that 
tool also be hidden to minimize confusion for the majority of site 
maintainers who don't have the option of evaluating the tool?  I'm not 
sure whether to add this as a feature request, so I wanted to get some 
input from the community.

Thanks,
Josh

-- 
Josh Holtzman
Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
jholtzman@berkeley.edu
510.643.7380

body:
I was interested to hear if anyone has had success running Sakai on  
Oracle's Express Edition.   Oracle XE is a small-footprint version of  
the 10g database engine which is available as a free download.  It is  
limited to one CPU, up to 1 GB ram, and database sizes up to 4 GB.   
The installation process is pretty much a one click 15 minute  
experience, much more simple than installing 10g Standard Edition.   
Of course with its limitations its not of much use to production  
environments, but it could be useful for demos and developers who  
need to get a quick, simple Oracle instance up for development and  
testing.

I made an attempt to start Sakai against a fresh install of XE and  
ran across some issues with connection pooling.  It appears that XE  
is enforcing a limit on concurrent sessions which Sakai runs into  
half way through startup.  I'm still experimenting with settings on  
both Oracle and Sakai to see if I can make this work, but wanted to  
inquire with the community to see if anyone else was working on this.

If you'd like to download Oracle XE for Windows or Linux, you can do  
so here:


http://www.oracle.com/technology/products/database/xe/index.html



Thanks,
Andrew Poland
Lead Analyst/Programmer
Indiana University

body:
Hi everyone,

During the last QA process, Clay and I asked that a new URL be set up 
to always point to the "release area." It was meant to be 
semi-permanent, easy to remember, and convenient for all types of 
users. Check it out by pointing your favorite Web browser to:

http://www.sakaiproject.org/release

You'll be redirected to the appropriate place.

Now, the same has been done for JIRA and Confluence. If you go to:

http://www.sakaiproject.org/jira
http://www.sakaiproject.org/confluence

you will be redirected to the right place. In addition, if you go to:

http://www.sakaiproject.org/bugs

you will find yourself at the top of the bugs.sakaiproject.org server. 
You can navigate to JIRA and Confluence from there as well.

A note of caution: these are only top-level redirects. To go straight 
to a specific issue or confluence space, you have to use the existing 
URLs.

Seth

body:
Hi All,

I am currently implementing a Quartz Job to synchronize an internal DB 
with the Sakai DB (users, sites, sections,...) through the Sakai API.
Everything synchronizes ok except for the section tasks as I am having 
trouble accessing the SectionManager API (I have read the lattest 
discussion on SectionManager)
I tried with the following approaches while attempting access to the 
SessionManager object:
1) SectionManager sm = (SectionManager) 
ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager"); // 
as suggested by Steven Githens and Josh Holtzman
2) SectionManager sm = new SectionManagerImpl(); // the 
implementation class, not the preferable way...

Both compiled ok with Maven but revealed unsuccessful to me at runtime:
Approach 1) returned me:
WARN: get(org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager): 
org.springframework.beans.factory.NoSuchBeanDefinitionException: No bean 
named 'org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager' is defined
Approach 2) returned me:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: 
org/sakaiproject/component/section/sakai21/SectionManagerImpl

I've configured project.xml in order to resolve the following 
dependencies:  sakai-session, sakai-tool, sakai-sections-api, 
sakai-component and sakai-sections-comp-shared-sakai21
Maven doesn't complain while compiling since this object is instantied 
dynamically at runtime (although it probably should complain with 
approach 2??).

Is this a missing dependency at project.xml?
Anyone with the same problem who can help me with directions?

Thanks in advance,
Nuno Fernandes.


Steven Githens wrote:

> Vishwak,
>
> I've been using the following methods in my local sakaiscript to do this:
>
>
> private static SectionAwareness getSA()
> {
> return (SectionAwareness) 
> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionAwareness");
> }
>
> private static SectionManager getSM()
> {
> return (SectionManager) 
> ComponentManager.get("org.sakaiproject.api.section.SectionManager");
> }
>
> public static String addSection(String siteid, String title,
> String category, int maxEnrollments, String location,
> String startTime, String endTime,
> boolean monday, boolean tuesday, boolean wednesday, boolean thursday,
> boolean friday, boolean saturday, boolean sunday)
> {
> try {
> SectionManager sm = getSM();
> Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
> String courseUuid = course.getUuid();
> //TODO: Add String conversions for times
> CourseSection cs = sm.addSection(courseUuid, title, category,
> new Integer(maxEnrollments), location, null, null, monday,
> tuesday, wednesday, thursday, friday, saturday, sunday);
> if (cs != null)
> return Jws.formatSuccess();
> else
> return "<error/>";
> }
> catch (Exception e) {
> return Jws.formatException(e);
> }
> }
>
> // public ParticipationRecord addSectionMembership(String userUid, 
> Role role, String sectionUuid)
> public static String addSectionMembership(String siteid, String 
> sectiontitle, String userid, String role)
> {
> try {
> // 1.  Get the sectionUuid
> SectionManager sm = getSM();
> //Course course = sm.getCourse(siteid);
> //if (course != null)
> //    System.out.println("SWG course not null");
> //else
> //    System.out.println("SWG course is null");
>
> List sections = sm.getSections(siteid);
> //System.out.println("SWG sect2: " + sections2.size());
> //List sections = sm.getSections(course.getUuid());
> //System.out.println("SWG sect: " + sections.size());
>
> String sectionUuid = "";
> for (Iterator i = sections.iterator(); i.hasNext();)
> {
> CourseSection cs = (CourseSection) i.next();
> if (cs.getTitle().equals(sectiontitle))
> {
> sectionUuid = cs.getUuid();
> //System.out.println("section" + sectiontitle + " matches: " + 
> sectionUuid);
> }
> }
> // 2. Get the userUid??
> String userUid = userid;
>
> if (role.equals("instructor"))
> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.INSTRUCTOR, sectionUuid);
> else if (role.equals("ta"))
> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.TA, sectionUuid);
> else if (role.equals("student"))
> {
> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.STUDENT, sectionUuid);
> }
> else
> sm.addSectionMembership(userUid, Role.NONE, sectionUuid);
>
> }
> catch (Exception e) {
> e.printStackTrace();
> return Jws.formatException(e);
> }
>
> return Jws.formatSuccess();
> }
>
> Vishwak Rajgopalan wrote:
>
>> Hi,
>> I have been looking at the SectionManager API and other 
>> section-related API's. I noticed that the addSection() .. method 
>> description mentions that this adds a section to a parent course 
>> section.
>>
>> What is the method that is responsible for adding sections to a site 
>> ?  addSection() method seems to me that it would need that a 
>> CourseSection to already exist before further sections can be added.
>>
>> Suppose I create a site as follows
>>
>> SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);
>>
>> This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course site/project 
>> site.
>>
>> Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
>> siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
>> course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
>> SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can perform 
>> this function.
>>
>> Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.
>>
>> Regards,
>> Vishwak Rajgopalan
>> UC Merced
>>

body:
Hi Beth,

I did a little "mad computer scientist" experiment with Google language=20
tools.
It appears that it might be possible to do a quick (and obviously=20
faulty) machine translation of properties files into multiple languages.
Although it doesn't sound like much, that could change the task needed=20
for the native language speaker from completely translating them to=20
editorial review and checking.  In general, even if it consistently=20
mistranslates a word, a single search and replace will fix it, which=20
could save time.

For anybody not familiar with the properties format, they consist of=20
key-value pairs with lines  like:
assessment_create=3DCreate a new assessment
etc.

In general it appears that Google leaves the lvalues (left side of the=20
equals sign) alone, and attempts to translate the terms on the right.
If it is confused, it leaves terms alone, as long as there is a=20
character right after the equals sign.  It seems to be hesitant to=20
translate one word rvalue terms in such a setup, but I have found that=20
replacing =3D with "=3Dx " and then replacing it with "=3D" back again does=
=20
the trick.
For example:
cat=3Dx Cat  =20
dog=3Dx Dog  =20
rat=3Dx Rat   =20
pig=3Dx Pig
becomes
"cat=3Dxkatzedog=3Dxhunderat=3Dxrattepig=3Dxschwein" --the only thing that =
is a=20
little ugly is it doesn't seem to preserve line breaks -- so you have to=20
manually fix them up.

It might be worth experimenting with further.
For example if you use these tricks
The following:
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
assessments=3DAssessments
assessment_new=3DNew Assessment
assessment_create=3DCreate a new assessment
assessment_choose=3DChoose Existing Template
assessment_heading=3DSakai Assessment Manager
assessment_import=3DImport assessment
assessment_title=3DTitle
assessment_core=3DCore Assessments
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
translates to (im Googleusch)
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
assessments=3DEinsch=E4tzungen
assessment_new=3Ddas neue Einsch=E4tzung
assessment_create=3Deine neue Einsch=E4tzung
assessment_choose=3Dverursachen, w=E4hlen vorhandene des Einsch=E4tzungsman=
agers
assessment_import=3Dder Schablone
assessment_heading=3DSakai der Importeinsch=E4tzung
assessment_title=3DKerneinsch=E4tzungen des Titels (OK, well,  so this one=
=20
looks a little like core + title.. no bots perfect....)
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D

To avoid insulting anybody, we should flag any such properties files=20
that we put in Subversion with "# warning machine translation, editorial=20
process incomplete" so that nobody tries to use a new translation in=20
production until reviewed by a native speaker.  After one, subtlety=20
keeps lost to all quantity in the machine translation.*

Or we could keep them to ourselves and check them in after=20
fluent-speaker review. ;)

--Ed



*After all a lot of subtlety gets lost in machine translation.




--=20
-------------------------------------------------------------
Ed Smiley   =20
Email:         esmiley@stanford.edu =20

Organization:  Stanford University =20
Relationship:  Staff =20
Profile:       Senior Java Software Developer, Sakai Project. =20
Department:    Academic and Residential Computing =20
Mail Code:     3101 =20
Work Address:  Meyer Library RM 260
Stanford, California, 94305      =20

body:
Hi,
I have read all the messages regarding the SectionManager and I am 
conscious of the future API changes but this will save the work of 
entering hundreds of sections in sites and adding participants to the 
sections. I will be updating my code for reflecting such changes!
Thank you for the directions as they solved my problem and I do access 
the API now!

Thank you again,
Nuno.

>>>> SiteEdit siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(compositeSiteId);
>>>>
>>>> This returns a siteEdit object that represents a course 
>>>> site/project site.
>>>>
>>>> Is there any section - related methods that I can then call on this 
>>>> siteEdit object , so that I can begin to add sections to this 
>>>> course/project site that I have created. The current methods in the 
>>>> SectionManager API's do not seem to have any methods that can 
>>>> perform this function.
>>>>
>>>> Any suggestions on how to go about this would be highly invaluable.
>>>>
>>>> Regards,
>>>> Vishwak Rajgopalan
>>>> UC Merced

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/127>
body:
Here are two late breaking news items for Sakai 2.1:

- Authorization Group Template Role Names
- New conversion needed for the 2.1 production branch (and trunk)


Authorization Group Template Role Names
----------------------------------------------------------

The new Site Group feature in Sakai 2.1 introduces new azg  
(Authorization Group, formally known as 'realm') templates:

- !group.template
- !group.template.course

In order for Site Groups to work properly, these templates must have  
the same roles defines as the cooresponding site azg templates:

- !site.template
- !site.template.course

or, they must have the superset of all the possible role names for  
course and project sites in your system.

Otherwise you will see the following:  add a user to a site group,  
and the user disappears from the group (with various errors in your  
server logs).  Users are given the same role in a site group as they  
have in the site, so the site group must have the same set of roles.   
The templates are used to create new site groups, so should have all  
the possible roles defined that you use in your system.

OOTB (out of the box), Sakai defines these roles for course sites:
- Student
- Instructor
- Teaching Assistant

(Note the case and the space - all is significant)

And for non-course (project) sites:
- access
- maintain

These are defined in the OOTB group templates as well.


New conversion needed for the production branch (and trunk)
------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
-----------

If you are using the Sakai 2.1 production branch ( https:// 
source.sakaiproject.org/svn/branches/sakai_2-1/ ), as of svn r4692,  
there is a new database conversion needed for Tests & Quizzes (Samigo).

These are in the source:

sam/tool/src/sql/oracle/patches/SAK-2862.sql
sam/tool/src/sql/mysql/patches/SAK-2862.sql
sam/tool/src/sql/hsqldb/patches/SAK-2862.sql

For Oracle:

alter table SAM_ASSESSFEEDBACK_T
add (FEEDBACKAUTHORING integer);
alter table SAM_PUBLISHEDFEEDBACK_T
add (FEEDBACKAUTHORING integer);

INSERT INTO SAM_ASSESSMETADATA_T ("ASSESSMENTMETADATAID",  
"ASSESSMENTID","LABEL", "ENTRY")
VALUES(sam_assessMetaData_id_s.nextVal, 1,  
'feedbackAuthoring_isInstructorEditable', 'true');


For MySQL:

alter table SAM_ASSESSFEEDBACK_T
add column  FEEDBACKAUTHORING integer;
alter table SAM_PUBLISHEDFEEDBACK_T
add column  FEEDBACKAUTHORING integer;

INSERT INTO SAM_ASSESSMETADATA_T (ASSESSMENTMETADATAID, ASSESSMENTID,  
LABEL,
ENTRY)
VALUES(NULL, 1, 'feedbackAuthoring_isInstructorEditable', 'true');



- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu

You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > Preferences.

body:
This has been fixed and is available in the 2.1 production branch.   
From the logs:

r4598 | zqian@umich.edu | 2005-12-13 23:17:03 -0500 (Tue, 13 Dec  
2005) | 5 lines

Fix to SAK-111: WS: Add Participants Error Sometimes on Username(s).

Added a checkUserId() call in Validator to bypass the '@' invalid  
resource id char problem.
Change the addUser() in BaseUserDirectory to use checkUserId()  
instead of checkResourceId().
Minor fixes in WS to enhance the format of alert/log messages.

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu

body:
Very cool -- I've used Google for individual words and phrases, but =20
didn't realize it's tendency to ignore the key values to the left of =20
the equal sign.

- Beth

On Dec 15, 2005, at 9:25 PM, Ed Smiley wrote:

> Hi Beth,
>
> I did a little "mad computer scientist" experiment with Google =20
> language tools.
> It appears that it might be possible to do a quick (and obviously =20
> faulty) machine translation of properties files into multiple =20
> languages.
> Although it doesn't sound like much, that could change the task =20
> needed for the native language speaker from completely translating =20
> them to editorial review and checking.  In general, even if it =20
> consistently mistranslates a word, a single search and replace will =20
> fix it, which could save time.
>
> For anybody not familiar with the properties format, they consist =20
> of key-value pairs with lines  like:
> assessment_create=3DCreate a new assessment
> etc.
>
> In general it appears that Google leaves the lvalues (left side of =20
> the equals sign) alone, and attempts to translate the terms on the =20
> right.
> If it is confused, it leaves terms alone, as long as there is a =20
> character right after the equals sign.  It seems to be hesitant to =20
> translate one word rvalue terms in such a setup, but I have found =20
> that replacing =3D with "=3Dx " and then replacing it with "=3D" back =20
> again does the trick.
> For example:
> cat=3Dx Cat   dog=3Dx Dog   rat=3Dx Rat    pig=3Dx Pig
> becomes
> "cat=3Dxkatzedog=3Dxhunderat=3Dxrattepig=3Dxschwein" --the only thing tha=
t =20
> is a little ugly is it doesn't seem to preserve line breaks -- so =20
> you have to manually fix them up.
>
> It might be worth experimenting with further.
> For example if you use these tricks
> The following:
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
> assessments=3DAssessments
> assessment_new=3DNew Assessment
> assessment_create=3DCreate a new assessment
> assessment_choose=3DChoose Existing Template
> assessment_heading=3DSakai Assessment Manager
> assessment_import=3DImport assessment
> assessment_title=3DTitle
> assessment_core=3DCore Assessments
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
> translates to (im Googleusch)
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
> assessments=3DEinsch=E4tzungen
> assessment_new=3Ddas neue Einsch=E4tzung
> assessment_create=3Deine neue Einsch=E4tzung
> assessment_choose=3Dverursachen, w=E4hlen vorhandene des =20
> Einsch=E4tzungsmanagers
> assessment_import=3Dder Schablone
> assessment_heading=3DSakai der Importeinsch=E4tzung
> assessment_title=3DKerneinsch=E4tzungen des Titels (OK, well,  so this =
=20
> one looks a little like core + title.. no bots perfect....)
> =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
>
> To avoid insulting anybody, we should flag any such properties =20
> files that we put in Subversion with "# warning machine =20
> translation, editorial process incomplete" so that nobody tries to =20
> use a new translation in production until reviewed by a native =20
> speaker.  After one, subtlety keeps lost to all quantity in the =20
> machine translation.*
>
> Or we could keep them to ourselves and check them in after fluent-=20
> speaker review. ;)
>
> --Ed
>
>
>
> *After all a lot of subtlety gets lost in machine translation.
>
>
>
>
> --=20
> -------------------------------------------------------------
> Ed Smiley    Email:         esmiley@stanford.edu       =20
> Organization:  Stanford University  Relationship:  Staff  =20
> Profile:       Senior Java Software Developer, Sakai Project.  =20
> Department:    Academic and Residential Computing  Mail Code:     =20
> 3101  Work Address:  Meyer Library RM 260
>               Stanford, California, 94305       =20
> -------------------------------------------------------------
>

body:
Hi All,

A question from maven luddite; I made some changes to providers and  
now want to redeploy, I know I could
maven sakai but it takes  15 minutes on my machine. What goal so that  
maven would only compile and deploy the
providers or src code that has changed.


Thanks,

body:
A preview of the new Message Center Tool has been added to the svn  
trunk HSQL and Oracle instances at http://nightly2.sakaiproject.org.   
You use the New Account feature on the gateway page to create  
yourself an account, then login, create yourself a site and use Site  
Info to add the tool to your site.

Nightly2 is rebuilt automatically every 4 hours.  The database may be  
wiped at any time and accounts and sites will be erased periodically.

Andrew

body:
You can set your directory to your provider module, and do maven bld  
dpl.  That will re-build and re-deploy just the artifacts of your  
provider.

Tomcat should not be running.

- Glenn

University Of Michigan

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/146>
body:
Hi -- The requirements process was not ratified by the board, but was =20
rolled into the Sakai Community Practice (SCP) work. I do not expect =20
that it will have immediate impact on defining this upcoming release, =20
except in how the requirements that get placed there will serve to =20
inform the projects that are underway. For example, there are several =20
gradebook requirements there that the Grade book working group will =20
take into account as it plans its Spring deliverable. It would be =20
great if we were able to wrap of the SCP work so that the =20
requirements group could, as Chuck stated, get ahead.

There are only three requirements registered right now. The more that =20
are posted, the more likelihood that they will be useful toward =20
getting good sense of community priorities and resources.

I have no idea what is in the May 15 release. I only know that we are =20
planning on hosting our gradebook wg and will be continuing to expand =20
the feature set to fulfill the original requirements and others that =20
have risen to the top since 2.0.  No locking. Only open. However, =20
contributing institutions will have more influence.

I hope that the SCP will make this easier across the board.

Mara

On Dec 16, 2005, at 11:46 AM, Charles Severance wrote:

> Clay,
>
> All of these process will impact the 2.2 release.  Absolutely =20
> nothing is set in stone for the release.  It all depends on what =20
> the community decides to do.
>
> As we move forward, we (Sakai Foundation) will begin to track =20
> activity and resources across the community and report that back to =20
> the community.  This is not to "give orders" to people and force =20
> them to do things - but instead to make sure that we are all aware =20
> of what is going on - hopefully with clear understanding (and =20
> advance notice) of what is going on, it can trigger important =20
> discussions within the community about things that are in progress.
>
> The requirements DG needs to focus on informing the rest of the =20
> community about requirements and if a strong case is made for =20
> requirements, then hopefully resources will flow towards those =20
> requirements in time to make a 2.2 release.   With a freeze date of =20
> May 15, the Requirements DG will need to move pretty quickly to get =20
> "ahead" of the project development teams.
>
> /Chuck
>
> On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:16 PM, Clay Fenlason wrote:
>
>
>> Is there a high-level view of how community requirements and =20
>> practices will
>> inform the priorities for this release, or does the evolutionary =20
>> emphasis
>> mean that it's pretty much locked and loaded, as an extension of =20
>> 2.1 work?
>>
>> ~Clay
>>
>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>> From: Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu>
>> Date: 14 d=E9c. 2005 16:22
>> Subject: Sakai 2.2 Schedule - High level
>> To: sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
>>
>> The Sakai 2.2. schedule is really very approximate at this point, but
>> here is a rough plan of timing.
>>
>> The OSP project is expecting to do a release of Sakai+OSP sometime in
>> the Feb-Mar timeframe.  We hope that this uses the Sakai maintenance
>> branch rather than requiring a full release of Sakai.
>>
>> If the OSP release goes to plan, the next Sakai release will be the
>> 2.2 release and is roughly targetted for code-freeze May 15 and
>> Delivery July 15.
>>
>> These dates may change as new issues come up, but the high level view
>> is that we have 5-6 months until the next signficant Sakai release.
>>
>> For tool developers and Sakai deployers the 2.2 release will be
>> evolutionary rather than revolutionary.  The "difference" will be on
>> the order of the difference between 2.0 and 2.1.  Some things will
>> change but we will avoid anything that would require major rewrites
>> of your tools, services, web service code, or providers.
>>
>> For those Fall deployers who need lots of time, we hope to be nearly
>> feature and schema frozen by May 15 - you will be able to take a tag
>> of Sakai at that time to begin your 2.2 work.
>>
>> As always - this is always subject to change based on how things go
>> in the community and as issues come up.
>>
>> /Chuck
>>

body:
Just to clarify, do the following from your command line:
1) [Stop Tomcat]
2) cd [sakai src dir]
3) cd providers
4) maven sakai
5) [Start Tomcat]

We had problems in sakai 2.0.1 with providers where we had to do a full
recompile or things would not work but it seems ok in sakai 2.1.
-AZ

--
Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech

body:
Clay,

All of these process will impact the 2.2 release.  Absolutely nothing =20
is set in stone for the release.  It all depends on what the =20
community decides to do.

As we move forward, we (Sakai Foundation) will begin to track =20
activity and resources across the community and report that back to =20
the community.  This is not to "give orders" to people and force them =20
to do things - but instead to make sure that we are all aware of what =20
is going on - hopefully with clear understanding (and advance notice) =20
of what is going on, it can trigger important discussions within the =20
community about things that are in progress.

The requirements DG needs to focus on informing the rest of the =20
community about requirements and if a strong case is made for =20
requirements, then hopefully resources will flow towards those =20
requirements in time to make a 2.2 release.   With a freeze date of =20
May 15, the Requirements DG will need to move pretty quickly to get =20
"ahead" of the project development teams.

/Chuck

On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:16 PM, Clay Fenlason wrote:

> Is there a high-level view of how community requirements and =20
> practices will
> inform the priorities for this release, or does the evolutionary =20
> emphasis
> mean that it's pretty much locked and loaded, as an extension of =20
> 2.1 work?
>
> ~Clay
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu>
> Date: 14 d=E9c. 2005 16:22
> Subject: Sakai 2.2 Schedule - High level
> To: sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
>
> The Sakai 2.2. schedule is really very approximate at this point, but
> here is a rough plan of timing.
>
> The OSP project is expecting to do a release of Sakai+OSP sometime in
> the Feb-Mar timeframe.  We hope that this uses the Sakai maintenance
> branch rather than requiring a full release of Sakai.
>
> If the OSP release goes to plan, the next Sakai release will be the
> 2.2 release and is roughly targetted for code-freeze May 15 and
> Delivery July 15.
>
> These dates may change as new issues come up, but the high level view
> is that we have 5-6 months until the next signficant Sakai release.
>
> For tool developers and Sakai deployers the 2.2 release will be
> evolutionary rather than revolutionary.  The "difference" will be on
> the order of the difference between 2.0 and 2.1.  Some things will
> change but we will avoid anything that would require major rewrites
> of your tools, services, web service code, or providers.
>
> For those Fall deployers who need lots of time, we hope to be nearly
> feature and schema frozen by May 15 - you will be able to take a tag
> of Sakai at that time to begin your 2.2 work.
>
> As always - this is always subject to change based on how things go
> in the community and as issues come up.
>
> /Chuck
>

body:
We had a demo of Sakai 2.1 running for 25 users on Wednesday. It appears
that one user attempted a quiz and stopped Sakai, although it worked okay
after killing all java processess on the server and a full restart. Full
error details attached.

ERROR: Servlet.service() for servlet jsp threw exception (2005-12-14
14:14:21,362
http-8080-Processor19_org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[loc
alhost].[/samigo].[jsp])
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate component ID
'tableOfContentsForm:_id42:part' found in view.
ERROR: Servlet.service() for servlet Faces Servlet threw exception
(2005-12-14 14:14:21,372
http-8080-Processor19_org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[loc
alhost].[/samigo].[Faces Servlet])
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate component ID
'tableOfContentsForm:_id42:part' found in view.
ERROR: Servlet.service() for servlet sakai.samigo threw exception
(2005-12-14 14:14:21,375
http-8080-Processor19_org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[loc
alhost].[/samigo].[sakai.samigo])
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate component ID
'tableOfContentsForm:_id42:part' found in view.

Could this be related to the issue raised in Glenn Golden's recent Sakai 2.1
Development News email?

Regards,



Jon Higham
eServices
University of Hull

body:

tried to edit message on Sakai2.1. I verified 
/tomcat/webapps/sakai-rwiki/tools/sakai.rwiki.xml has removed the 
comments. And I logged in as an administrator give the instructor the 
permission for all rwiki related functions, but still got this error 
message when sign in as an instructor. Is this a bug? It seems like 
similar bug with SAK-2465. Just need confirm this.

But need noticed, it worked once, then stopped working.

Any thoughts?

Thanks for that. I had suspected the errors in the previous email because
they were the beginning of the errors during the demonstration session.
Attached is were I think it actually failed. It appears to be an out of
memory issue following use of gradebook, but I don't know what causes this.


Regards,



-----Original Message-----
From: Daisy Flemming [mailto:daisy.flemming@gmail.com] 
Sent: 16 December 2005 15:29
To: Jon Higham; Lydia Li; Ed Smiley
Cc: sakai-dev
Subject: Re: samigo error


Hi Jon,

The error that u attached is a JSF error created when preparing teh dispaly
for a question but it shouldn't stopped Samigo nor Sakai functioning. This
error is not related to Glenn's news. I am not sure what it is that cause
the server to hang. Do you see any other errors after that? 

Glenn: any suggestions?

Lydia & Ed: we should probably find time to clean up those errors.

Daisy

I am attempting to write a script that would create roster/user/

for the above purpose?

Thanks a lot.

Regards,

body:
I've checked in a new, cool feature into subversion that allows users  
to dynamically change their language locale (without affecting other  
users). Kudos go to Tatsuki Sugiura for developing the ResourceLoader  
class that implements this. Details can be found at http:// 
collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1117804916661-111798/ 
sakai-dynamic-locales.doc.

All legacy tools have been converted to use the new ResourceLoader  
class, _but_ work still needs to be done to implement these changes  
in the following tools:

sakai/sample-tools/
sakai/gradebook
sakai/metaobj/
sakai/rwiki/
sakai/sam/
sakai/sections/
# sakai/tbd/  (any future tools should use the ResourceLoader too)

The changes are lightweight and easy to do -- I just don't feel I'm  
the best person to implement and test these, since I don't have prior  
experience using/modifying these tools. So I send this humble request  
to the hordes of Sakai developers out there who would be in a better  
position than me to make these changes. Please let me know if you  
have any questions -- I'd be happy to help.

If you want to see how it works, build the current version from the  
trunk, go to Preferences and change your language to "Dutch" (which  
is the most complete translation to date).

- Beth

----------------------

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 16 Dec 2005 15:53:44.0877 (UTC) FILETIME=[E4FC85D0:01C60258]
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-15; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/135>
body:
Glenn mentioned SAK-2909 and -3099 in earlier postings. They are related with performance problems 
on Oracle. It appears to be a solution for Oracle *install* problems as well. We had problems with 
10g and 9i. But when we applied the fixes mentioned by Glenn we got it running. So, in addition to 
the install documentation you need to apply these two solutions.

Glenn, tell me if I'm wrong.

Victor Maijer
University of Amsterdam

========================================================================
JIRA-snippet SAK-2909:

The way to set the default transaction isolation level is different. It is an override property now, 
rather than a placeholder property. Set it in sakai.properties like this:

defaultTransactionIsolationString@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED

* * *

For Oracle, we (CTools at University of Michigan) found it best for performance to leave the 
validation query and isolation level default unset. To get these values unset now, put this in you 
sakai.properties file:

# for best oracle performance
validationQuery@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=
testOnBorrow@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=false
defaultTransactionIsolationString@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=

=========================================================================
JIRA-snippet SAK-3099:

While bringing up Sakai Collab with the 2.1.0 software, we discovered a performance problem with the 
Oracle configuration. Database connection pooling is not working properly.

for 2.1.0 users, If you are using Oracle you can avoid this problem by editing the 
kernel/db-components components.xml file, and remove the following configuration:

<!-- The default read-only state of connections created by this pool. -->
<property name="defaultReadOnly">
<value>false</value>
</property>

By leaving the "defaultReadOnly" setting *unset*, the database pooling will again work properly.

If you are working from source, you can edit it before you build and deploy:

sakai/kernel/db-components/src/webapp/WEB-INF/components.xml

If you are working with the binary, you can edit the deployed file from the components package 
(usually found in tomcat/components, but you may have placed them elsewhere). Do this while Sakai is 
*not* running:

tomcat/components/sakai-db-components/WEB-INF/components.xml

When you catch up with a Sakai version that has this fixed, your change to this file will no longer 
be necessary (but can be left in place).









----------------------

body:
It is at least a good reminder that results - whether it be development
plans or arriving at agreement on practices - need to be achieved in very
short order in order to have an impact for our schools in 2006.  There is a
fair degree of momentum behind 2.2 already, it's going to define Sakai in
2006 for us, and, what's more, will provide the "first impression" many of
our faculty will have, since we launch in the Fall.  I think that's the
ribbon-cutting period for a large number of other schools as well.  If
you'll excuse me, I need to go submit some requirements :)

~Clay

2005/12/16, Mara Hancock <mara@media.berkeley.edu>:
>
> Hi -- The requirements process was not ratified by the board, but was
> rolled into the Sakai Community Practice (SCP) work. I do not expect
> that it will have immediate impact on defining this upcoming release,
> except in how the requirements that get placed there will serve to
> inform the projects that are underway. For example, there are several
> gradebook requirements there that the Grade book working group will
> take into account as it plans its Spring deliverable. It would be
> great if we were able to wrap of the SCP work so that the
> requirements group could, as Chuck stated, get ahead.
>
> There are only three requirements registered right now. The more that
> are posted, the more likelihood that they will be useful toward
> getting good sense of community priorities and resources.
>
> I have no idea what is in the May 15 release. I only know that we are
> planning on hosting our gradebook wg and will be continuing to expand
> the feature set to fulfill the original requirements and others that
> have risen to the top since 2.0.  No locking. Only open. However,
> contributing institutions will have more influence.
>
> I hope that the SCP will make this easier across the board.
>
> Mara
>
> On Dec 16, 2005, at 11:46 AM, Charles Severance wrote:
>
> > Clay,
> >
> > All of these process will impact the 2.2 release.  Absolutely
> > nothing is set in stone for the release.  It all depends on what
> > the community decides to do.
> >
> > As we move forward, we (Sakai Foundation) will begin to track
> > activity and resources across the community and report that back to
> > the community.  This is not to "give orders" to people and force
> > them to do things - but instead to make sure that we are all aware
> > of what is going on - hopefully with clear understanding (and
> > advance notice) of what is going on, it can trigger important
> > discussions within the community about things that are in progress.
> >
> > The requirements DG needs to focus on informing the rest of the
> > community about requirements and if a strong case is made for
> > requirements, then hopefully resources will flow towards those
> > requirements in time to make a 2.2 release.   With a freeze date of
> > May 15, the Requirements DG will need to move pretty quickly to get
> > "ahead" of the project development teams.
> >
> > /Chuck
> >
> > On Dec 14, 2005, at 5:16 PM, Clay Fenlason wrote:
> >
> >
> >> Is there a high-level view of how community requirements and
> >> practices will
> >> inform the priorities for this release, or does the evolutionary
> >> emphasis
> >> mean that it's pretty much locked and loaded, as an extension of
> >> 2.1 work?
> >>
> >> ~Clay
> >>
> >> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> >> From: Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu>
> >> Date: 14 d=E9c. 2005 16:22
> >> Subject: Sakai 2.2 Schedule - High level
> >> To: sakai-dev <sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org>
> >>
> >> The Sakai 2.2. schedule is really very approximate at this point, but
> >> here is a rough plan of timing.
> >>
> >> The OSP project is expecting to do a release of Sakai+OSP sometime in
> >> the Feb-Mar timeframe.  We hope that this uses the Sakai maintenance
> >> branch rather than requiring a full release of Sakai.
> >>
> >> If the OSP release goes to plan, the next Sakai release will be the
> >> 2.2 release and is roughly targetted for code-freeze May 15 and
> >> Delivery July 15.
> >>
> >> These dates may change as new issues come up, but the high level view
> >> is that we have 5-6 months until the next signficant Sakai release.
> >>
> >> For tool developers and Sakai deployers the 2.2 release will be
> >> evolutionary rather than revolutionary.  The "difference" will be on
> >> the order of the difference between 2.0 and 2.1.  Some things will
> >> change but we will avoid anything that would require major rewrites
> >> of your tools, services, web service code, or providers.
> >>
> >> For those Fall deployers who need lots of time, we hope to be nearly
> >> feature and schema frozen by May 15 - you will be able to take a tag
> >> of Sakai at that time to begin your 2.2 work.
> >>
> >> As always - this is always subject to change based on how things go
> >> in the community and as issues come up.
> >>
> >> /Chuck
> >>

body:
Andrew,

What's the ID of this tool?  Is it the sakai.messageforums?


Thanks,
Steve


Andrew Poland wrote:

> A preview of the new Message Center Tool has been added to the svn  
> trunk HSQL and Oracle instances at http://nightly2.sakaiproject.org.   
> You use the New Account feature on the gateway page to create  
> yourself an account, then login, create yourself a site and use Site  
> Info to add the tool to your site.
>
> Nightly2 is rebuilt automatically every 4 hours.  The database may be  
> wiped at any time and accounts and sites will be erased periodically.
>
> Andrew
>

body:
I add the following information for future generations of sakai 
developers who google the words "maven bus error sakai" when they have 
a similar problem:

This error occurred on MacOSX 10.3.9.  I had already tried starting 
with a new tomcat and a clean maven repo, but when Chuck suggested 
that, I tried again.  On the third try, it succeeded.

Thanks.

Jim



Quoting Jim Eng <jimeng@umich.edu>:

> I'm getting the following error when trying to checkout from trunk:
>
> java:compile:
> [echo] Compiling to 
> /Volumes/UserHome/jimeng/dev20/sakai/admin-tools/preferences/target/classes
> [echo] ==========================================================
>
> NOTE: Targetting JVM 1.4, classes
> will not run on earlier JVMs
>
> ==========================================================
> [javac] Compiling 1 source file to 
> /Volumes/UserHome/jimeng/dev20/sakai/admin-tools/preferences/target/classes
> /Volumes/UserHome/jimeng/maven-1.0.2/bin/maven: line 162:   824 Bus 
> error               "$JAVACMD" $MAVEN_OPTS 
> -Djavax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory=org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserFactoryImpl -Djavax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory=org.apache.xerces.jaxp.DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl "-Djava.endorsed.dirs=${MAVEN_ENDORSED}" -classpath "${MAVEN_HOME}/lib/forehead-${FOREHEAD_VERSION}.jar" "-Dforehead.conf.file=${MAVEN_HOME}/bin/forehead.conf" "-Dtools.jar=$TOOLS_JAR" "-Dmaven.home=${MAVEN_HOME}" $MAIN_CLASS 
> "$@"
>
> Since I haven't seen an error message quite like this before, I'm 
> wondering if anybody has any advice.
>
> Thanks.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> Jim Eng
> jimeng@umich.edu
> 734-645-4123

body:
Many thanks; that is exactly what I need.

Amit

On Dec 18, 2005, at 9:40 AM, Luke FERNANDEZ wrote:

> Sakai 2.1 includes Web services that, among other things, create and
> update users, create sites, and add enrollments.  There is a 20 minute
> quick start guide on using these located in the docs/webservices  
> folder.
>
> Cheers,
>
> Luke
>
>
>>>> Amit Kumar <amitku@uiuc.edu> 12/16/05 3:21 PM >>>
>>>>
> Hi All,
>
> I am attempting to write a script that would create roster/user/
> course information in Sakai from our custom data model.
> Has anyone done this and could they share code snippets. I understand
> the data models are specific, but
> my intention is to get familiarized with the API.
>
> Any pointers to the API/tools source code would help as well. Any web
> services that Sakai exposes that I could use
> for the above purpose?
>
> Thanks a lot.
>
> Regards,
> Amit

matter of minutes.  It also has a very nice Unicon skin.

body:
FYI.

/Chuck

Begin forwarded message:

> From: Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu>
> Date: December 18, 2005 7:31:59 PM EST
> To: portal <portal@collab.sakaiproject.org>
> Subject: Sakai Portlet Version 2.0
>
> Sakai Portlet v0.2
>
> I went to Bloomington, Indiana last week and with Marlon Pierce's  
> help, started working on the Sakai JSR-168 portlet again.  A really  
> great steak from Zagreb always gets the juices flowing - Marlon  
> said I could not have any steak until I had an initial version done  
> - so motivation was high.
>
> Now four days later, I have an even better release with a bunch of  
> usable features.  I attach some PowerPoint and source for you to  
> take a look at.  Here is a set of new stuff:
>
> -  Added Gallery Portlet
> - Added a tree view portlet that shows all of your sites and tools
> - Moving the code into SVN (when I get a good network connection)
> - Configuration flexibility
> - Added proxy portlets for common Sakai tools:
> Announcements (sakai.announcements)
> Assignments (sakai.assignment)
> Chat Room (sakai.chat)
> Discussion (sakai.discussion)
> Gradebook (sakai.gradebook.tool)
> Email Archive (sakai.mailbox)
> Membership (sakai.membership)
> Message Forums (sakai.messageforums)
> Preferences Tool (sakai.preferences)
> Presentation (sakai.presentation)
> Profile (sakai.profile)
> Resources (sakai.resources)
> Wiki (sakai.rwiki)
> Tests & Quizzes (sakai.samigo)
> Roster (sakai.site.roster)
> Schedule (sakai.schedule)
> Site Info (sakai.siteinfo)
> Syllabus (sakai.syllabus)
>
> This basically means that you can drop a Samigo into a JSR-168  
> portal after a few details have been handled.
>
> I attach some PowerPoint and the source - it has also been checked  
> into SVN.
>
> There is stillo more work to do before these are perfect - a rough  
> design of the next steps for synchronizing site-level authZ between  
> the portal and Sakai is included in the PowerPoint.
>
> /Chuck
>
>
> [see attachment: "sakai_portlet_v03.ppt", size: 1519104 bytes]
>
>
>
> [see attachment: "portlet_v12.tar", size: 266240 bytes]
>
>
>

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/167>
body:
Grace Wang wrote:
> I got "permission denied. You do not have the correct permission." when I 
> tried to edit message on Sakai2.1. I verified 
> /tomcat/webapps/sakai-rwiki/tools/sakai.rwiki.xml has removed the 
> comments. And I logged in as an administrator give the instructor the 
> permission for all rwiki related functions, but still got this error 
> message when sign in as an instructor. Is this a bug? It seems like 
> similar bug with SAK-2465. Just need confirm this.
> 
> But need noticed, it worked once, then stopped working.
> 
> Any thoughts?

I suspect that the wiki page you are trying to edit has the group 
permissions to update disabled on the page. A simple way to find this 
out is to look at the info tab for that page and check the 
Enable/Disabled row. If the Update and Admin columns have 'no' in them 
then unless your instructor role has rwiki.superadmin it won't be able 
to edit the page.

Now, if the instructor has the site.edit permission, just below the 
permissions block you should see:

"You may edit site permissions"

You could then give the instructor role "rwiki.superadmin" and they 
would never need to look at the permissions screen again.

A safer solution would be to login as a user that does have permission 
to update that page -- I suspect the owner will have permission, either 
that or use the sakai admin -- and change the page permissions to enable 
the instructor role to update the page.

HTH

andy

-- 
Andrew Thornton
andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk / andrew@cbcl.co.uk

----------------------

body:
Grace Wang wrote:
> I got "permission denied. You do not have the correct permission." when I 
> tried to edit message on Sakai2.1. I verified 
> /tomcat/webapps/sakai-rwiki/tools/sakai.rwiki.xml has removed the 
> comments. And I logged in as an administrator give the instructor the 
> permission for all rwiki related functions, but still got this error 
> message when sign in as an instructor. Is this a bug? It seems like 
> similar bug with SAK-2465. Just need confirm this.
> 
> But need noticed, it worked once, then stopped working.
> 
> Any thoughts?

I suspect that the wiki page you are trying to edit has the group 
permissions to update disabled on the page. A simple way to find this 
out is to look at the info tab for that page and check the 
Enable/Disabled row. If the Update and Admin columns have 'no' in them 
then unless your instructor role has rwiki.superadmin it won't be able 
to edit the page.

Now, if the instructor has the site.edit permission, just below the 
permissions block you should see:

"You may edit site permissions"

You could then give the instructor role "rwiki.superadmin" and they 
would never need to look at the permissions screen again.

A safer solution would be to login as a user that does have permission 
to update that page -- I suspect the owner will have permission, either 
that or use the sakai admin -- and change the page permissions to enable 
the instructor role to update the page.

HTH

andy

-- 
Andrew Thornton
andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk / andrew@cbcl.co.uk

body:
Quoth Yuji Shinozaki:
>Is there a complete procedure or recipe for setting up a sakai 2.1
>development environment in Eclipse 3.1 (specifically on WinXP) someplace?
>I can find bits and pieces of the procedure, but they tend to be
>incomplete or seemingly out-dated.

Yuji:

I've attached the howto file I put together for myself and my fellow 
developers at the Yale Center for Language Study when we were having a hard 
time with 2.0. The file is geared toward getting everything going from 
scratch and so includes info on MySQL and getting the JDK.* While to some 
extent it falls into your out-dated category, I used it myself recently to 
set up a 2.1 dev environment on a laptop. (Sakai is not my primary task, so 
I have not memorized it yet.)

Tk

*I also tried to aim it at a pretty low level, so have mercy on parts that 
may seem insulting. :-)


Trip Kirkpatrick
SysAdmin / Programmer
Center for Language Study

e: trip.kirkpatrick@yale.edu
w: http://www.cls.yale.edu/ 
[see attachment: "sakai_HOWTO.txt", size: 8128 bytes]


Attachments:

sakai_HOWTO.txt
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/5ff5a22c-64b4-4cba-007d-1ca949855dd2/sakai_HOWTO.txt

body:
Thanks that looks useful, but we are looking for getting a developement
environment in Eclipse.  We already have our development deployment
running on linux and can build and configure from the commandline.  We
just need to bring it into Eclipse to do real development work.

It looks like the Zach Thomas talk from the Austin conference will be
ideal when it gets online.

yuji
----

body:
Hi,

Not sure if this has been reported or not, I cant find anything in Jira=20
about it. Please point me in the right direction if I=A8m wrong.

In test and quizzes, one of our teachers have fill in the blanks=20
questions with acceptable variations of the correct answers (like=20
{case1|case2|case3}). When the students has done the test some (not all)=20
student results are doubled compared to the dessignated point.

This behaviour is close:=20
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-2683, but it seems as it is=20
the "piped" ( | ) answer key and not the wildcards that somehow is=20
messed up for us...

Magnus

body:
Sakai-dev:



Our file system is AFS, with user quotas already established.  How does one
limit the file storage for users in Sakai given our scenario?  In the Sakai
Installation pages on collab, the sakai.properties parameters are defined
for course file storage.  I know that file storage can be configured in
sakai.properties by providing volumes, such as:



bodyVolumes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingService =
v1,v2,v3

>From the installation FAQ
(http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal/site/1097928811887-22636/page/1112037
051114-93040):

"Files will be stored under each volume in a way so that there are not too
many in any one folder. The folder structure we use is:

YYYY/DDD/HH/id, where YYYY=year, DDD=day of year, HH=hour of day, and the
1111...=an id-based file name

for example, 2005/070/03/3223479379834-2343"

My question(s) are: 

1.      How do we configure Sakai to utilize our existing file storage
setup?

2.      How do we limit Sakai users from adding large files (outside of the
global file upload size limitations in Sakai)?

3.      Is the format above determined by Environment variables, properties,
etc.?  Is it configurable?

Thanks in advance,

Scott

Scott Amerson

Programmer

IET Middleware Team

530.757.8314



[see attachment: "message0.html", size: 7408 bytes]

message0.html
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/4dce6c1e-ddba-489e-803a-7c3c817e124b/message0.html

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/179>
body:
I don't think I've seen this documented anywhere, so forgive me if I 
simply missed the memo.

At UC Berkeley we run Oracle 9.2, and I naively thought that using the 
9.2 JDBC driver made good sense.  What we found was that this driver was 
unable to properly perform the auto-ddl table generation at startup, and 
was throwing errors when reading the realm tables.

Switching to the latest 10g driver solved these problems.  Thanks to 
Lance Speelmon for pointing this out.

If this is in fact missing from the install docs, I'd vote for adding it!

Cheers,
Josh

-- 
Josh Holtzman
Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
jholtzman@berkeley.edu
510.643.7380

body:
We're in the process of using setting up a file server to store 
resources content for sakai for our app servers on RHEL 3.
It appears that majority of you are using AFS.
Is anyone using NFS? Also, is there a reason to use AFS over NFS?
We would prefer to err on the side of caution and use something that 
is tried and true.
Has anyone observed any issues with either one?
Any help will be much appreciated.
Kyong

> On Dec 19, 2005, at 4:29 PM, Josh Holtzman wrote:

>> I don't think I've seen this documented anywhere, so forgive me if  I 
>> simply missed the memo.
>>
>> At UC Berkeley we run Oracle 9.2, and I naively thought that using  
>> the 9.2 JDBC driver made good sense.  What we found was that this  
>> driver was unable to properly perform the auto-ddl table generation  
>> at startup, and was throwing errors when reading the realm tables.
>>
>> Switching to the latest 10g driver solved these problems.  Thanks  to 
>> Lance Speelmon for pointing this out.
>>
>> If this is in fact missing from the install docs, I'd vote for  
>> adding it!
>>
>> Cheers,
>> Josh
