X-Content-Type-Outer-Envelope: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
To: Scott Amerson <sdamerson@ucdavis.edu>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.746.2)
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/178>
body:
When you use a file system like AFS for Sakai, you must have another  
AFS user that *is* Sakai - you cannot use your end users' AFS space  
for their files.  The AFS space that Sakai sees must be permitted to  
your Sakai server, and you must do tricks to make sure your AFS  
tokens that give Sakai permission to write to the space stay active.

You can limit the storage per site with a quote, and you can set the  
max upload size per file.

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu


On Dec 19, 2005, at 6:38 PM, Scott Amerson wrote:

> Sakai-dev:
>
>
>
> Our file system is AFS, with user quotas already established.  How  
> does one
> limit the file storage for users in Sakai given our scenario?  In  
> the Sakai
> Installation pages on collab, the sakai.properties parameters are  
> defined
> for course file storage.  I know that file storage can be  
> configured in
> sakai.properties by providing volumes, such as:
>
>
>
> bodyVolumes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingServ 
> ice =
> v1,v2,v3
>
> From the installation FAQ
> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal/site/1097928811887-22636/ 
> page/1112037
> 051114-93040):
>
> "Files will be stored under each volume in a way so that there are  
> not too
> many in any one folder. The folder structure we use is:
>
> YYYY/DDD/HH/id, where YYYY=year, DDD=day of year, HH=hour of day,  
> and the
> 1111...=an id-based file name
>
> for example, 2005/070/03/3223479379834-2343"
>
> My question(s) are:
>
> 1.      How do we configure Sakai to utilize our existing file storage
> setup?
>
> 2.      How do we limit Sakai users from adding large files  
> (outside of the
> global file upload size limitations in Sakai)?
>
> 3.      Is the format above determined by Environment variables,  
> properties,
> etc.?  Is it configurable?
>
> Thanks in advance,
>
> Scott
>
> Scott Amerson
>
> Programmer
>
> IET Middleware Team
>
> 530.757.8314
>
>
>
> [see attachment: "message0.html", size: 7408 bytes]
>
>
> Attachments:

> message0.html

body:
Stephen Marquard wrote:

> - Failing the above (probably a somewhat complex change, I wonder if 
> WSRP would help here?), it should be possible to use an alternate CSS 
> for displaying tools within the desktop view, for example to eliminate 
> the tool borders, etc. Perhaps this could be enabled by providing an 
> alternate CSS reference in the tool output (tooldesktop.css or 
> something) which the desktop app could use in preference to the 
> standard browser tool css.
>
> - It should be possible to do all this in XUL (for Firefox) which 
> would make it cross-platform as well...
>
Yeah XUL!  ;)
Including custom *.css in the plug-in or other desktop portion would be 
pretty cool.

As a short term fix, it's pretty easy to get rid of the top iframe with 
the toolbar.  I guess you loose the Reset and Help button, but those 
could probably be grafted on somewhere else desktopish.

-steve


-- 
Steven Githens, Chicago IL
s-githens@northwestern.edu
http://www.githens.org

body:
Steven Githens wrote:

>
> As a short term fix, it's pretty easy to get rid of the top iframe 
> with the toolbar.  I guess you loose the Reset and Help button, but 
> those could probably be grafted on somewhere else desktopish.
>
Oops, meant to say that it's easy with a little JavaScript to get rid of it.

body:
Hi Shane,

Before I get too far, the OSS disclaimer:

The current status of Web Services for Sakai is pretty standard Open 
Source fare.  Things are taking a while to bake, and even longer for 
them to get documented. Getting involved at this point will definatley 
involve digging through code, as there's nothing remotely close to nice 
MSDNish documentation. This could actually be pretty valuable for a 
senior CS student, but probably not since there are more fun things to 
do during a senior year.

This isn't meant to be excuse, but an honest depiction of the current 
situation.  For the meantime you'll need to roll up your hacking sleeves 
and dig in.

On to the points:
1.  I fear that there is not much documentation except my 
O'Reilly-wannabe-freeflowing english, and maybe a few other tidbits 
laying around.  :)

I think Glenn is organizing a documentation project so perhaps something 
will come of that.

There are not a substantial amount of web services yet, and they are 
changing quickly.  It's a relatively new thing inside of Sakai. 
Personally I'm shooting for having it coelecse into a nice framework 
around Sakai 2.2.

2. These sorts of client-binding API's are definately the subject of 
daydreams. I've started to work on something like this for Python and 
JavaScript because that's what I want to use personally.  We *might* 
have good enough autogenerators eventually to automatically create these 
libraries for other languages, but most likey it will just show up from 
somebody who really wants Java Delegates.

As far as examples, some of this is actually my fault perse, as people 
do send me stuff on occasion and it takes me quite a while to get it 
into subversion, and even then it's not very organized. However, I 
haven't recieved any actual sample clients written in Java. ;)

Everything you point out is pretty important, it just takes a long time 
to get it done.

Discussion on the best way to proceed is always encouraged.  We have a 
web service list on collab too.

-Steve

(who's been awake for a while, so this email may not have flowed well)

Shane O'Sullivan wrote:

>There are two points to this post:
>
>1. Web services documentation for Sakai seems to be very lacking
>2. Web services delegates would be very useful
>
>Firstly, I was looking for documentation on what web services are available
>for Sakai, and was unable to find much at all.  Specifically what I was
>looking for was:
>- What web services are available?
>- What are the available methods?
>- What are the pre and post conditions of these methods?
>- Are there any example web service clients, specifically in Java?  I've
>noticed some talk of a VB.NET client called the Sakai Apple Desktop, but
>can't find much of anything about it. Is the source available?
>
>Is there any documentation available that answers these questions?  And by
>documentation, I mean structured documentation, not free-form English. If
>so, could someone please point me to it.  If not, it would be a very good
>idea to do some comprehensive documentation on these subjects.  I believe
>there is a lot of potential for non-browser based clients for Sakai, but it
>is difficult to do anything at all if it is necessary to go searching
>through the code base for .jws files, and reading source code to write a
>client.  It should simply be a matter of reading the documentation and
>writing the code for accessing the Web Services - knowledge of Java should
>not necessarily be a prerequisite.
>
>Secondly, I feel it would be very useful to have a set of Web Services
>delegates for any applications that come as standard with the Sakai core.  I
>understand that using Web Services with Apache Axis is a relatively simple
>procedure, however the code is completely repetitive, and it requires Java
>developers to learn how Apache Axis works (not a bad thing in and of itself,
>but it does take time and might put off some people).  Also, every coder
>writing Java code to access Sakai web services will write essentially the
>same thing, albeit with small differences which increase the possibility of
>errors.  I feel it would make more sense to standardise the client-side code
>used to access the web services with some simple Java classes that do all
>the Web-Service-specific coding.  This will also facilitate the sharing of
>client-side code amongst developers.
>
>As a small aside, the main reason I post this is because I tried to convince
>some 4th year Computer Science students to take on a final-year project to
>write a Java-based Sakai Web Service client, but the lack of information and
>the perceived lack of  serious support for non-browser access to Sakai put
>them off.  I can only imagine that this occurence is not unique, and that a
>lot of useful work on Sakai is not being done for the same reason.
>
>So, what do people think?
>
>Thanks
>
>Shane O'Sullivan
>[see attachment: "message0.html", size: 2947 bytes]
>

body:
Ok, I am running the 1.5 to 2.0 script and get the following error:

ERROR 1267 (HY000) at line 23: Illegal mix of collations
(latin1_swedish_ci,COERCIBLE) and (utf8_general_ci,IMPLICIT) for
operation 'concat'

Can't seem to get past this

-----Original Message-----
From: Charles Severance [mailto:csev@umich.edu] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 10:37 AM
To: Cotton, Dan
Cc: sakai-dev
Subject: Re: Update db 1.5.1 to 2.1

Generally the approach is to convert through each intermediate release
and be careful.

You should do 1.5.1 -> 2.0 and then 2.0 -> 2.1

You should make nice backups at each step and make sure to do a light
test with 2.0 during the middle step to make sure it all looks fine.

/Chuck

On Dec 20, 2005, at 1:26 PM, Cotton, Dan wrote:

> Are there any scripts for updating a Sakai 1.5.1 MYSql db to 2.1?
>
> -Dan

version)??

application at /portal/, tomcat log shows java.sql.SQLException (Column

The same version in MySQL works fine!!

Any idea?


Atentamente,

Juan David Vergara Perez

body:
It is mentioned in the readme that the 10g driver should be used for Oracle,
but the information is not nearly as prominent as it should be

"The version of the JDBC driver (or connector) is also important. For MySQL
the 3.1.10 connector should be used, while for Oracle the 10g driver should
be used..."

Burying that sort of information in the middle of the paragraph is just
begging for it to be missed, and I think there are other bits that also
deserve to be highlighted better (like all the things you may need to do to
upgrade an existing installation).  It's not enough to just squeeze the
information in somewhere.  I need to find some way to make thinks clearer
without using an excessive amount of asterisks, exclamation marks, and
capital letters.

~Clay

2005/12/19, Josh Holtzman <jholtzman@berkeley.edu>:
>
> Ahh... I wasn't looking at the release docs on the web... I was looking
> at the install docs in the source:
>
>
> https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/branches/sakai_2-1/docs/install/readme_source.txt
>
> Thanks for the pointer,
> Josh
>
> Thomas Amsler wrote:
>
> > Josh,
> >
> > It's actually in the doc:
> >
> > http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/release/2.1.0/dbconfig.html
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Thomas Amsler
> > Programmer
> > IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
> > tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
> > tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
> > W: (530) 754-5198
> > M: (916) 803-2226
> >
> >
> >
> > On Dec 19, 2005, at 4:29 PM, Josh Holtzman wrote:
> >
> >> I don't think I've seen this documented anywhere, so forgive me if  I
> >> simply missed the memo.
> >>
> >> At UC Berkeley we run Oracle 9.2, and I naively thought that using
> >> the 9.2 JDBC driver made good sense.  What we found was that this
> >> driver was unable to properly perform the auto-ddl table generation
> >> at startup, and was throwing errors when reading the realm tables.
> >>
> >> Switching to the latest 10g driver solved these problems.  Thanks  to
> >> Lance Speelmon for pointing this out.
> >>
> >> If this is in fact missing from the install docs, I'd vote for
> >> adding it!
> >>
> >> Cheers,
> >> Josh
> >>
> >> --

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.746.2)
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/202>
body:
Daphne -

I completely agree with your thoughts here.  Part of the goal of this  
little exploration is to end up with *Far better* UI approaches.   
Dragging and dropping is just one possibility :)

One feature I would love is for Resources to actually be expandable  
including folders, files, etc and then just drag and drop files back  
and forth.

Also this has the potential for making a REALLY accessible interface  
given that every single piece of the screen outside the browser part  
is completely under the programmer/designer's control.

/Chuck

On Dec 20, 2005, at 12:29 PM, Daphne Ogle wrote:

> This is interesting.  And thinking about all the  
> interactions...like drag and drag...that could we can implemented  
> with a desktop version is really exciting.
> I know this isn't about the UI but I've seen this navigation  
> structure twice now so I wanted to share some thoughts before we  
> get too far down the road.  I like that this structure allows more  
> space for the content and clearly displays the hierarchy.  The  
> thing we loose with this type of structure is the sense of place.   
> A course or project site is a virtual space where members "get  
> together".  Tree structures are typically used for file  
> organization.  Sakai is much more than a bunch of files.  Just  
> thinking out loud a bit here.
>
> -Daphne

body:
Folks, just an little explanation.

I had network problems last two days and thought the Version 03  
message got stuck in my outbox late last night at 2AM - but it really  
got delivered without me knowing.

thinking the message never went out and with a fresh cup of Java this  
morning, I decided to add some features (see the nifty right click  
features on the tree view) and then re-send the message with a  
version 04 of the message and software.

So you saw two versions of the same message - one 8 hours later.  The  
best version of the code is the 04 - the one I just sent.

The software nicely deinstalls and reinstalls so if you used the 03  
edition - just uninstall 03 and reinstall 04.

/Chuck


On Dec 20, 2005, at 1:09 PM, Charles Severance wrote:

> Folks,
>
> I got started playing with the Sakai Portlet, and then moved on to  
> my VB Desktop.  I extended the VB desktop to handle sites and  
> pages, made much better use of tree view, made a neat "in-window"  
> browser - kind of like my own little iTunes for Sakai.
>
> This is becoming an pretty usable way to navigate around Sakai.  It  
> runs really crisply because any navigation between sites is local  
> on your desktop and only the right hand side is a browser.  This  
> tool has potential to do some very nice accessibility operations  
> because everything in the tree view is something that is an app so  
> we could highly customize its accessible behaviour.
>
> Sorry for Apple folks - Now we need to update the Apple Sakai  
> Desktop.  But I might get motivated to get better at Cocoa and  
> replicate this functionality in Cocoa.
>
> The key bit of fun is the new getToolsDom method in the  
> SakaiSite.jws web service.  This new program demands this file be  
> updated either from trunk or from this message.  Of course web  
> services must be turned on too.
>
> This needs a 2.1 Sakai, with updated SakaiSite.jws, and web  
> services to run.   Nightly2 runs from trunk and has web services  
> enabled so you can play with this widget using nightly2.
>
> I attach: two tantalizing screen shots, the install package  
> (includes VB.NET source), and the updated Web Service.
>
> /Chuck
>
> <sakai-desktop-login.jpg>
>
> <sakai-desktop-view.jpg>
>
>
> <SakaiDesktop_v04.msi>
> <SakaiSite.jws>

body:
On Dec 20, 2005, at 12:53 PM, Stephen Marquard wrote:

> I've just installed this, and also think it's exciting! I believe  
> it's important to have a couple of alternate UIs around as  
> reference implementations (and hopefully in production too) so that  
> we keep a broad picture of all the possible uses for Sakai tools  
> and content.

Part of my goal here is to write code in a few languages and send it  
around to (a) make sure that we have cool web services rich enough to  
make this easy and (b) sample source code that folks can hack.  So  
now we have a nice implementation in Java (JSR-168 portlet) and VB to  
retrieve and display sites.  My next move (with enough time) is to  
take the Java code from the JSR-168 portlet and move it to a Cocoa  
Java application and release a Mac version so I can start using this  
as my way to see Sakai rather than a browser.  Maybe my Xmas present  
to myself will be 20 hours of uninterrupted coding time :)

> I'd like to see similar interfaces in XUL, Flash and for mobile  
> devices.

Me too :)

> I agree about the initial loss of 'place' (maybe because the  
> presence indicator is missing) but can also think of even more  
> exciting ways of integrating presence and user awareness to bring  
> back place & presence - for example positioning chat tools as a  
> tabbed section across the bottom with alert indicators for  
> activity, event notification (new announcements, etc.).

Yes - this can be done.  It might be fun to do - I wanted to do this  
right by using XMLHttpRequest straight from VB - just like the  
browser - rather than hacking it in the iFrame.  It might be cool to  
have little numbers beside each site telling you how many people are  
in each place :)   Clicking on the numbers sends them a Sakai IM..

Turns out that Chat does not work well (you need to manually refresh)  
when it is "alone" and the Sakai Ajax background code is not  
happening.  This is a bug in Chat - I need to file a Jira.

> These desktop clients could also be using a variety of connection  
> technologies, e.g. web services, webdav, browser display, jabber/ 
> xmpp for pushing events & chat, etc.

Also, think of beginning to add value for things like a placement of  
a Sakai News Tool - we could add the actual RSS reference to the web  
service and then simply display it in a really cool RSS reader rather  
than an RSS reader running on a server in a frame.  Lots and lots of  
fun stuff.

> The CANS project has created some widgets (http:// 
> myclass.missouri.edu/~amelungc/cans/index.php? 
> option=com_content&task=view&id=23&Itemid=2) - another piece of the  
> puzzle. We don't yet have any integrated support for Jabber/XMPP in  
> Sakai for pushing event notifications to clients in a scaleable  
> way, but the possibilities are so appealing that I'm sure that  
> problem won't be left unsolved for too long :-)

The nice thing is that as each puzzle piece arrives, solving the rest  
of the puzzle becomes (a) more appealing and (b) easier :)

/Chuck

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/206>
body:
On Dec 20, 2005, at 2:13 AM, Stephen Marquard wrote:

> Several thoughts occur to me:
>
> - The next step in creating a consistent look & feel would be to  
> make the tool title bar and tool toolbar (Schedule & help / reset  
> icons, Add / Fields / Permissions) part of the desktop app.

First the Title Bar.  This is a bit icky but can be done.  The tool  
bar will be *crazy* hard because it is not simply mimicking what  
Charon does.  So far, everything (including the title bar) is all  
nicely abstracted in Sakai to be Charon's responsiblity - So I can  
mimic Charon.   Getting below to the tool bar would require much more  
discipline on the part of developers of tools and it moves across an  
abstraction layer.

> - Failing the above (probably a somewhat complex change, I wonder  
> if WSRP would help here?), it should be possible to use an  
> alternate CSS for displaying tools within the desktop view, for  
> example to eliminate the tool borders, etc. Perhaps this could be  
> enabled by providing an alternate CSS reference in the tool output  
> (tooldesktop.css or something) which the desktop app could use in  
> preference to the standard browser tool css.

WSRP is not the "express train" - All of these experiments  
(especially the JSR-168 experiment) show the "way" that WSRP needs to  
evolve.  WSRP has a further problem in that it requires some  
discipline on the part of tool writers.   Since WSRP is not 100% done  
- we are not really fully ready to tell developers exactly what they  
should do.  So we need to get WSRP more mature and then work  
backwords to the tools.

> - It should be possible to do all this in XUL (for Firefox) which  
> would make it cross-platform as well...

Yes - Flash too.   And PHP.   And ASP.NET ....  These web services  
are stone simple to use.

/Chuck

body:
Generally the approach is to convert through each intermediate  
release and be careful.

You should do 1.5.1 -> 2.0 and then 2.0 -> 2.1

You should make nice backups at each step and make sure to do a light  
test with 2.0 during the middle step to make sure it all looks fine.

/Chuck

On Dec 20, 2005, at 1:26 PM, Cotton, Dan wrote:

> Are there any scripts for updating a Sakai 1.5.1 MYSql db to 2.1?
>
> -Dan

body:
Shane,

I would add one more standard OSS disclaimer :)

We love it when people help solve these problems.  It is how Stephen  
*became* the web services expert just a few short months ago :)

/Chuck
Sakai Chief Architect

On Dec 20, 2005, at 6:29 AM, Steven Githens wrote:

> Hi Shane,
>
> Before I get too far, the OSS disclaimer:
>
> The current status of Web Services for Sakai is pretty standard  
> Open Source fare.  Things are taking a while to bake, and even  
> longer for them to get documented. Getting involved at this point  
> will definatley involve digging through code, as there's nothing  
> remotely close to nice MSDNish documentation. This could actually  
> be pretty valuable for a senior CS student, but probably not since  
> there are more fun things to do during a senior year.
>
> This isn't meant to be excuse, but an honest depiction of the  
> current situation.  For the meantime you'll need to roll up your  
> hacking sleeves and dig in.
>
> On to the points:
> 1.  I fear that there is not much documentation except my O'Reilly- 
> wannabe-freeflowing english, and maybe a few other tidbits laying  
> around.  :)
>
> I think Glenn is organizing a documentation project so perhaps  
> something will come of that.
>
> There are not a substantial amount of web services yet, and they  
> are changing quickly.  It's a relatively new thing inside of Sakai.  
> Personally I'm shooting for having it coelecse into a nice  
> framework around Sakai 2.2.
>
> 2. These sorts of client-binding API's are definately the subject  
> of daydreams. I've started to work on something like this for  
> Python and JavaScript because that's what I want to use  
> personally.  We *might* have good enough autogenerators eventually  
> to automatically create these libraries for other languages, but  
> most likey it will just show up from somebody who really wants Java  
> Delegates.
>
> As far as examples, some of this is actually my fault perse, as  
> people do send me stuff on occasion and it takes me quite a while  
> to get it into subversion, and even then it's not very organized.  
> However, I haven't recieved any actual sample clients written in  
> Java. ;)
>
> Everything you point out is pretty important, it just takes a long  
> time to get it done.
>
> Discussion on the best way to proceed is always encouraged.  We  
> have a web service list on collab too.
>
> -Steve
>
> (who's been awake for a while, so this email may not have flowed well)
>
> Shane O'Sullivan wrote:
>
>> There are two points to this post:
>>
>> 1. Web services documentation for Sakai seems to be very lacking
>> 2. Web services delegates would be very useful
>>
>> Firstly, I was looking for documentation on what web services are  
>> available
>> for Sakai, and was unable to find much at all.  Specifically what  
>> I was
>> looking for was:
>> - What web services are available?
>> - What are the available methods?
>> - What are the pre and post conditions of these methods?
>> - Are there any example web service clients, specifically in  
>> Java?  I've
>> noticed some talk of a VB.NET client called the Sakai Apple  
>> Desktop, but
>> can't find much of anything about it. Is the source available?
>>
>> Is there any documentation available that answers these  
>> questions?  And by
>> documentation, I mean structured documentation, not free-form  
>> English. If
>> so, could someone please point me to it.  If not, it would be a  
>> very good
>> idea to do some comprehensive documentation on these subjects.  I  
>> believe
>> there is a lot of potential for non-browser based clients for  
>> Sakai, but it
>> is difficult to do anything at all if it is necessary to go searching
>> through the code base for .jws files, and reading source code to  
>> write a
>> client.  It should simply be a matter of reading the documentation  
>> and
>> writing the code for accessing the Web Services - knowledge of  
>> Java should
>> not necessarily be a prerequisite.
>>
>> Secondly, I feel it would be very useful to have a set of Web  
>> Services
>> delegates for any applications that come as standard with the  
>> Sakai core.  I
>> understand that using Web Services with Apache Axis is a  
>> relatively simple
>> procedure, however the code is completely repetitive, and it  
>> requires Java
>> developers to learn how Apache Axis works (not a bad thing in and  
>> of itself,
>> but it does take time and might put off some people).  Also, every  
>> coder
>> writing Java code to access Sakai web services will write  
>> essentially the
>> same thing, albeit with small differences which increase the  
>> possibility of
>> errors.  I feel it would make more sense to standardise the client- 
>> side code
>> used to access the web services with some simple Java classes that  
>> do all
>> the Web-Service-specific coding.  This will also facilitate the  
>> sharing of
>> client-side code amongst developers.
>>
>> As a small aside, the main reason I post this is because I tried  
>> to convince
>> some 4th year Computer Science students to take on a final-year  
>> project to
>> write a Java-based Sakai Web Service client, but the lack of  
>> information and
>> the perceived lack of  serious support for non-browser access to  
>> Sakai put
>> them off.  I can only imagine that this occurence is not unique,  
>> and that a
>> lot of useful work on Sakai is not being done for the same reason.
>>
>> So, what do people think?
>>
>> Thanks
>>
>> Shane O'Sullivan
>> [see attachment: "message0.html", size: 2947 bytes]
>>
>>
>> Attachments:
>>
>> message0.html
>> http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/ 
>> bb168ab7-6942-47f1-00ef-cb943ed9cce5/message0.html

>> Preferences.
>>
>
>
> --

body:
Thanks Steve, thats a really helpful set of documentation.
Ideally I'd like to find some example scripts written in Perl. 
Does anyone have some Perl code examples for adding users etc. that they would be happy to share?

Cheers,

Paul


-----Original Message-----
From: Steven Githens [mailto:s-githens@northwestern.edu]
Sent: Tue 12/20/2005 9:43 AM
To: Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167
Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Subject: Re: how to use Sakaiscript????

Paul,

There is a preliminary tutorial here:

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/docs/webservices/html/

Depending on which language you're using, you may need to know more or 
less about SOAP and actual Web Service Specifications.  If you're using 
a P-Language like Perl or Python (kinda PHP), you need very little 
prerequisite knowledge to get started.

-steve

Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:

>Steve,
>I'm interested in using Sakaiscript to populate our Sakai site with
>users, and subscribe them to courses.
>Unfortunately I know next to nothing about web services, and I haven't
>been unable to locate any Sakaiscript documentation that tells me how to
>use it.
>Is there a guide (preferably one that doesn't assume lots of web
>services knowledge), as to what they need to do to use Sakaiscript? And
>maybe some examples .... How you would actually go about adding users.
>
>Cheers,
>
>Paul

body:
I'm guessing perhaps your client's connection character set and  
collation does not match the charset/collation of your database.

use these to change the connection mode:

set NAMES utf8;
set CHARACTER SET utf8;

(http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/charset-connection.html)


Or change the default character set for your database:

ALTER DATABASE database_name DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8 COLLATE  
utf8_general_ci;



(Make a backup first of course.)

Andrew

On Dec 20, 2005, at 2:16 PM, Cotton, Dan wrote:

> The line generates this error:
>
> Illegal mix of collations (latin1_swedish_ci,COERCIBLE) and
> (utf8_general_ci,IMPLICIT) for operation 'concat'
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Cotton, Dan
> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 11:12 AM
> To: sakai-dev
> Subject: RE: Update db 1.5.1 to 2.1
>
> This line is currently giving me problems:
>
> update SAKAI_SITE_TOOL set REGISTRATION=concat('sakai',
> substr(REGISTRATION,5)) where UPPER(substr(REGISTRATION,1,4))='CHEF';
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Cotton, Dan
> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 11:04 AM
> To: sakai-dev
> Subject: RE: Update db 1.5.1 to 2.1
>
> Has anyone got this to work? I am removing lines that through  
> errors and
> keep getting more.
>
> Attached are the scripts I found on the sakai site for the  
> converisons.
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Cotton, Dan
> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 10:42 AM
> To: Charles Severance
> Cc: sakai-dev
> Subject: RE: Update db 1.5.1 to 2.1
>
> Ok, I am running the 1.5 to 2.0 script and get the following error:
>
> ERROR 1267 (HY000) at line 23: Illegal mix of collations
> (latin1_swedish_ci,COERCIBLE) and (utf8_general_ci,IMPLICIT) for
> operation 'concat'
>
> Can't seem to get past this
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Charles Severance [mailto:csev@umich.edu]
> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 10:37 AM
> To: Cotton, Dan
> Cc: sakai-dev
> Subject: Re: Update db 1.5.1 to 2.1
>
> Generally the approach is to convert through each intermediate release
> and be careful.
>
> You should do 1.5.1 -> 2.0 and then 2.0 -> 2.1
>
> You should make nice backups at each step and make sure to do a light
> test with 2.0 during the middle step to make sure it all looks fine.
>
> /Chuck
>
> On Dec 20, 2005, at 1:26 PM, Cotton, Dan wrote:
>
>> Are there any scripts for updating a Sakai 1.5.1 MYSql db to 2.1?
>>
>> -Dan
>>

body:
Hi,


You could have a look at:

https://www.connect.uct.ac.za/sakaiwiki/index.php/Heritage

Its an example of provisioning from a text file using perl and webservices

Regards

David Horwitz

Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:
> Thanks Steve, thats a really helpful set of documentation.
> Ideally I'd like to find some example scripts written in Perl. 
> Does anyone have some Perl code examples for adding users etc. that they would be happy to share?
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Paul
> 
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Steven Githens [mailto:s-githens@northwestern.edu]
> Sent: Tue 12/20/2005 9:43 AM
> To: Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167
> Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> Subject: Re: how to use Sakaiscript????
> 
> Paul,
> 
> There is a preliminary tutorial here:
> 
> https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/sakai/docs/webservices/html/
> 
> Depending on which language you're using, you may need to know more or 
> less about SOAP and actual Web Service Specifications.  If you're using 
> a P-Language like Perl or Python (kinda PHP), you need very little 
> prerequisite knowledge to get started.
> 
> -steve
> 
> Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:
> 
> 
>>Steve,
>>I'm interested in using Sakaiscript to populate our Sakai site with
>>users, and subscribe them to courses.
>>Unfortunately I know next to nothing about web services, and I haven't
>>been unable to locate any Sakaiscript documentation that tells me how to
>>use it.
>>Is there a guide (preferably one that doesn't assume lots of web
>>services knowledge), as to what they need to do to use Sakaiscript? And
>>maybe some examples .... How you would actually go about adding users.
>>
>>Cheers,
>>
>>Paul

body:
Daphne Ogle wrote:
> This is interesting.  And thinking about all the interactions...like 
> drag and drag...that could we can implemented with a desktop version is 
> really exciting.
> I know this isn't about the UI but I've seen this navigation structure 
> twice now so I wanted to share some thoughts before we get too far down 
> the road.  I like that this structure allows more space for the content 
> and clearly displays the hierarchy.  The thing we loose with this type 
> of structure is the sense of place.  A course or project site is a 
> virtual space where members "get together".  Tree structures are 
> typically used for file organization.  Sakai is much more than a bunch 
> of files.  Just thinking out loud a bit here.

I've just installed this, and also think it's exciting! I believe it's important 
to have a couple of alternate UIs around as reference implementations (and 
hopefully in production too) so that we keep a broad picture of all the possible 
uses for Sakai tools and content.

I'd like to see similar interfaces in XUL, Flash and for mobile devices.

I agree about the initial loss of 'place' (maybe because the presence indicator 
is missing) but can also think of even more exciting ways of integrating 
presence and user awareness to bring back place & presence - for example 
positioning chat tools as a tabbed section across the bottom with alert 
indicators for activity, event notification (new announcements, etc.).

These desktop clients could also be using a variety of connection technologies, 
e.g. web services, webdav, browser display, jabber/xmpp for pushing events & 
chat, etc.

The CANS project has created some widgets 
(http://myclass.missouri.edu/~amelungc/cans/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=23&Itemid=2) 
- another piece of the puzzle. We don't yet have any integrated support for 
Jabber/XMPP in Sakai for pushing event notifications to clients in a scaleable 
way, but the possibilities are so appealing that I'm sure that problem won't be 
left unsolved for too long :-)

Cheers
Stephen

-- 
Stephen Marquard
Learning Technologies Co-ordinator, Centre for Educational Technology
Centre for Higher Education Development, University of Cape Town
Email: marquard@ched.uct.ac.za IM: xmpp:marquard@ched.uct.ac.za
Cell: +27-83-500-5290

body:
After importing a test in Samigo (Sakai 2.1), we receive a blank window. The
import goes through all the steps, it seems, but it returns a blank screen,
regardless if the test was created in (exported from) Sakai 2.0 or 2.1. I
couldn't find a *new* issue on this in Jira (used to be an issue in the
past). Is anyone else experiencing this?

Thanks, 

Vivie

--
Vivian 'Vivie' Sinou
Dean, Learning Technology & Innovations
Foothill College

body:
Hi everybody.

Just in time for Christmas: After a comically difficult voiceover =20
process* the Quicktime version of my conference presentation is =20
available in Confluence.
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/download/attachments/9662/=20
developing_for_sakai.tar.gz

The title is =93Developing for Sakai: Getting Started=94 and is the first =
=20
of what I hope will be a series of Sakai developer-to-developer =20
training materials.

I welcome any feedback or requests for new topics.

ho ho ho,
Zach A. Thomas
Software Engineer
Texas State University
http://www.txstate.edu

* in case you're tempted to try it, I don't recommend recording a =20
full-resolution screen movie with audio of a full-resolution screen =20
movie running in Powerpoint.

body:
Nuno,

The error with the timezone was fixed late yesterday -- I'd refresh 
your checkout. I'm not sure what you mean by a drop-down language 
selector in preferences, can you elaborate?

- Beth

On Dec 21, 2005, at 6:18 AM, Nuno Fernandes wrote:

> Hi Beth,
>
> I followed your indications in order to test the dynamic language 
> preferences. My host is using locale 'pt_PT' and I'm having the 
> following errors:
> - there is no drop-down language selector in preferences;
> - when selecting Timezone I get the exception: "Innapropriate object 
> class for LocaleComparator"
>
> Note: there is no pt resource bundle (yet).
> Anyone having this kind of errors?
>
> Nuno Fernandes.
>
> Beth Kirschner wrote:
>
>> I've checked in a new, cool feature into subversion that allows users 
>>  to dynamically change their language locale (without affecting other 
>>  users). Kudos go to Tatsuki Sugiura for developing the 
>> ResourceLoader  class that implements this. Details can be found at 
>> http:// 
>> collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1117804916661-111798/ 
>> sakai-dynamic-locales.doc.
>>
>> All legacy tools have been converted to use the new ResourceLoader  
>> class, _but_ work still needs to be done to implement these changes  
>> in the following tools:
>>
>> sakai/sample-tools/
>> sakai/gradebook
>> sakai/metaobj/
>> sakai/rwiki/
>> sakai/sam/
>> sakai/sections/
>> # sakai/tbd/  (any future tools should use the ResourceLoader too)
>>
>> The changes are lightweight and easy to do -- I just don't feel I'm  
>> the best person to implement and test these, since I don't have prior 
>>  experience using/modifying these tools. So I send this humble 
>> request  to the hordes of Sakai developers out there who would be in 
>> a better  position than me to make these changes. Please let me know 
>> if you  have any questions -- I'd be happy to help.
>>
>> If you want to see how it works, build the current version from the  
>> trunk, go to Preferences and change your language to "Dutch" (which  
>> is the most complete translation to date).
>>
>> - Beth
>>
>> ----------------------

body:
Late yesterday we changed the default behavior to use a property 
defining available locales within sakai. Try adding the following to 
your sakai.properties file:

# Supported language locales for user preferences
locales = ja_JP, ko_KR, nl_NL, zh_CN

- Beth

body:
Not sure why the login tool is being involved in this case, but here are a 
couple of things that may help you:
1- I've been able to post to servlets included in a webapp for a Sakai tool 
using just the root relative url for the servlet. E.g., if your tool's 
webapp is called 'mytool', then your root relative url would be 
'/mytool/myservlet...'. Of course, you would pass to your servlet whatever 
parameters you need.
2- Don't forget to filter your servlet with Sakai's RequestFilter, as 
explained in the Sakai documentation. Unless you do this, you will lose the 
Sakai session (including current user information).
-Patricia
At 02:45 AM 12/21/2005, Jon Hui wrote:
>Hi all
>
>I have a Sakai tool which hosts an applet, and the applet in turn posts 
>data to a servlet, which is packaged in the tool's war. This was working 
>fine in Sakai 1.0 and 1.5, but now it wouldn't work in Sakai 2.0. The URL 
>of my servlet now invokes Sakai's LoginTool servlet, which would complain 
>of null user ID and password. Even when I added the 'eid' and 'pw' 
>parameters, as required by LoginTool, to the request in my applet, they'll 
>still appear to be null when the request comes to LoginTool.
>
>I wonder if I could somehow post to my servlet without the LoginTool being 
>invoked? Any help would be appreciated.
>
>cheers.
>-Jon
>
>----------------------
>This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab

body:
Chuck

I know, I know :-)  Too many ppl ask , and not enough offer...
Unfortunately, my company prevents me from working on any open source
project without ridiculous amounts of legal approval, so I'll have to remain
one of those lazy people who just try to make work for others :-(

Shane

On 20/12/05, Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu> wrote:
>
> Shane,
>
> I would add one more standard OSS disclaimer :)
>
> We love it when people help solve these problems.  It is how Stephen
> *became* the web services expert just a few short months ago :)
>
> /Chuck
> Sakai Chief Architect
>
> On Dec 20, 2005, at 6:29 AM, Steven Githens wrote:
>
> > Hi Shane,
> >
> > Before I get too far, the OSS disclaimer:
> >
> > The current status of Web Services for Sakai is pretty standard
> > Open Source fare.  Things are taking a while to bake, and even
> > longer for them to get documented. Getting involved at this point
> > will definatley involve digging through code, as there's nothing
> > remotely close to nice MSDNish documentation. This could actually
> > be pretty valuable for a senior CS student, but probably not since
> > there are more fun things to do during a senior year.
> >
> > This isn't meant to be excuse, but an honest depiction of the
> > current situation.  For the meantime you'll need to roll up your
> > hacking sleeves and dig in.
> >
> > On to the points:
> > 1.  I fear that there is not much documentation except my O'Reilly-
> > wannabe-freeflowing english, and maybe a few other tidbits laying
> > around.  :)
> >
> > I think Glenn is organizing a documentation project so perhaps
> > something will come of that.
> >
> > There are not a substantial amount of web services yet, and they
> > are changing quickly.  It's a relatively new thing inside of Sakai.
> > Personally I'm shooting for having it coelecse into a nice
> > framework around Sakai 2.2.
> >
> > 2. These sorts of client-binding API's are definately the subject
> > of daydreams. I've started to work on something like this for
> > Python and JavaScript because that's what I want to use
> > personally.  We *might* have good enough autogenerators eventually
> > to automatically create these libraries for other languages, but
> > most likey it will just show up from somebody who really wants Java
> > Delegates.
> >
> > As far as examples, some of this is actually my fault perse, as
> > people do send me stuff on occasion and it takes me quite a while
> > to get it into subversion, and even then it's not very organized.
> > However, I haven't recieved any actual sample clients written in
> > Java. ;)
> >
> > Everything you point out is pretty important, it just takes a long
> > time to get it done.
> >
> > Discussion on the best way to proceed is always encouraged.  We
> > have a web service list on collab too.
> >
> > -Steve
> >
> > (who's been awake for a while, so this email may not have flowed well)
> >
> > Shane O'Sullivan wrote:
> >
> >> There are two points to this post:
> >>
> >> 1. Web services documentation for Sakai seems to be very lacking
> >> 2. Web services delegates would be very useful
> >>
> >> Firstly, I was looking for documentation on what web services are
> >> available
> >> for Sakai, and was unable to find much at all.  Specifically what
> >> I was
> >> looking for was:
> >> - What web services are available?
> >> - What are the available methods?
> >> - What are the pre and post conditions of these methods?
> >> - Are there any example web service clients, specifically in
> >> Java?  I've
> >> noticed some talk of a VB.NET client called the Sakai Apple
> >> Desktop, but
> >> can't find much of anything about it. Is the source available?
> >>
> >> Is there any documentation available that answers these
> >> questions?  And by
> >> documentation, I mean structured documentation, not free-form
> >> English. If
> >> so, could someone please point me to it.  If not, it would be a
> >> very good
> >> idea to do some comprehensive documentation on these subjects.  I
> >> believe
> >> there is a lot of potential for non-browser based clients for
> >> Sakai, but it
> >> is difficult to do anything at all if it is necessary to go searching
> >> through the code base for .jws files, and reading source code to
> >> write a
> >> client.  It should simply be a matter of reading the documentation
> >> and
> >> writing the code for accessing the Web Services - knowledge of
> >> Java should
> >> not necessarily be a prerequisite.
> >>
> >> Secondly, I feel it would be very useful to have a set of Web
> >> Services
> >> delegates for any applications that come as standard with the
> >> Sakai core.  I
> >> understand that using Web Services with Apache Axis is a
> >> relatively simple
> >> procedure, however the code is completely repetitive, and it
> >> requires Java
> >> developers to learn how Apache Axis works (not a bad thing in and
> >> of itself,
> >> but it does take time and might put off some people).  Also, every
> >> coder
> >> writing Java code to access Sakai web services will write
> >> essentially the
> >> same thing, albeit with small differences which increase the
> >> possibility of
> >> errors.  I feel it would make more sense to standardise the client-
> >> side code
> >> used to access the web services with some simple Java classes that
> >> do all
> >> the Web-Service-specific coding.  This will also facilitate the
> >> sharing of
> >> client-side code amongst developers.
> >>
> >> As a small aside, the main reason I post this is because I tried
> >> to convince
> >> some 4th year Computer Science students to take on a final-year
> >> project to
> >> write a Java-based Sakai Web Service client, but the lack of
> >> information and
> >> the perceived lack of  serious support for non-browser access to
> >> Sakai put
> >> them off.  I can only imagine that this occurence is not unique,
> >> and that a
> >> lot of useful work on Sakai is not being done for the same reason.
> >>
> >> So, what do people think?
> >>
> >> Thanks
> >>
> >> Shane O'Sullivan
> >> [see attachment: "message0.html", size: 2947 bytes]
> >>
> >>
> >> Attachments:
> >>
> >> message0.html
> >> http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/

body:
Jon,

Here is the trick at a high level.  Your applet needs to know the  
Sakai Session.   You can get the session in the tool that writes out  
the applet tag and pass it into the applet.

Write out the session is as one of the <applet> parameters.

Session s = SessionManager.getCurrentSession();
(check for null)
System.out.println("Session = " + s.getId()) ;

Then have the applet append the session to your servlet url as follows:

http://sakai.ust.hk/my-fun-servlet?sakai.session=FF1234565789899

The code that is now redirecting you (RequestFilter) will see this  
parameter and go right past the login processing and establish the  
servlet with the right identity.  This is useful for things that  
don't handle cookies.

Some applets share cookie space with their hosting browser and others  
do not.  Switching to the use of session based launch effectively  
guarantees that things will work regardless of applet vagaries.

Sakai session based launching (I think) was not in 2.0 or 2.0.1 but  
the patch is really small and easy to apply.  Look in the  
RequestFilter code.  But this is in 2.1 and the trunk.  If you want  
this to work with a 2.0.x based Sakai do a diff of

./kernel/request/src/java/org/sakaiproject/util/RequestFilter.java

Between the version you are using and the trunk in SVN.

/Chuck

On Dec 21, 2005, at 3:45 AM, Jon Hui wrote:

> Hi all
>
> I have a Sakai tool which hosts an applet, and the applet in turn  
> posts data to a servlet, which is packaged in the tool's war. This  
> was working fine in Sakai 1.0 and 1.5, but now it wouldn't work in  
> Sakai 2.0. The URL of my servlet now invokes Sakai's LoginTool  
> servlet, which would complain of null user ID and password. Even  
> when I added the 'eid' and 'pw' parameters, as required by  
> LoginTool, to the request in my applet, they'll still appear to be  
> null when the request comes to LoginTool.
>
> I wonder if I could somehow post to my servlet without the  
> LoginTool being invoked? Any help would be appreciated.
>
> cheers.
> -Jon
>

body:
Hi All

I'm trying to add functionality to the SPML module to support profile
information. Basically at this stage I want to populate a users profile
after the user object is created with UserDirectoryService.addUser().
Due to the way the SPML runs it is not tightly integrated with Sakai,
but runs similarly to other webservices.

So far I have tried various but the most successful (i.e. got the
furthest before I get a nullpointer exception) is:

ProfileManager prm = new ProfileManagerImpl();
SakaiPersonImpl thisUser = new SakaiPersonImpl();
thisUser.setUid(userid);
thisUser.setGivenName(firstname);
thisUser.setSurname(lastname);
thisUser.setMail(email);
//create the profile from the object
Profile profile = new ProfileImpl(thisUser);
prm.save(profile);

Where it all works till the last step.  Am I going about this the right
way, or is there a simpler better way of doing this? I'm trying to avoid
writing directly to the database.

Thanks in advance

David


-- 
"It remains that, from the same principles, I now demonstrate the frame
of the System of the World." - Newton "Pricipia Mathematica"

body:
Shane,

That is totally cool.  Using and adopting is as much a contribution  
as writing code.

I fully understand the cost-benefit of trying to get permission to  
contribute directly.   Paperwork for this type of thing is either  
easy or impossible :)

Perhaps as you bust through the murky learning curve and into the  
clear blue skies of Sakai web services, you could post a note or two  
to the list and someone else could update a wiki or something so your  
effort will not be in vain - those who follow in your footsteps will  
be thankful.  :)

/Chuck

body:
Nuno Fernandes wrote:

> There is no problem of including the code! If you are interested, 
> after I clean up the code, I can send you a copy of our 
> Synchroniztion Job (adds users, profiles, sites, sections, sites and 
> sections memberships) in a few days.

Can I recommend that you make it available (somewhere) to the wider 
community?

Ideally, I'd like to see institutional examples for providers, Quartz 
jobs, sakai.properties files, etc.  made available for people to look 
over, etc. assuming that there aren't any institutional or legal 
obstacles. Checking out how other people have done things is often 
very useful before/during/after you try to tackle your own situation.

Perhaps a good place to collect these might be in the Enterprise 
group's Confluence area? That way questions/comments could be made.

Seth

body:
Hi Beth,

I followed your indications in order to test the dynamic language 
preferences. My host is using locale 'pt_PT' and I'm having the 
following errors:
- there is no drop-down language selector in preferences;
- when selecting Timezone I get the exception: "Innapropriate object 
class for LocaleComparator"

Note: there is no pt resource bundle (yet).
Anyone having this kind of errors?

Nuno Fernandes.

Beth Kirschner wrote:

> I've checked in a new, cool feature into subversion that allows users  
> to dynamically change their language locale (without affecting other  
> users). Kudos go to Tatsuki Sugiura for developing the ResourceLoader  
> class that implements this. Details can be found at http:// 
> collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1117804916661-111798/ 
> sakai-dynamic-locales.doc.
>
> All legacy tools have been converted to use the new ResourceLoader  
> class, _but_ work still needs to be done to implement these changes  
> in the following tools:
>
> sakai/sample-tools/
> sakai/gradebook
> sakai/metaobj/
> sakai/rwiki/
> sakai/sam/
> sakai/sections/
> # sakai/tbd/  (any future tools should use the ResourceLoader too)
>
> The changes are lightweight and easy to do -- I just don't feel I'm  
> the best person to implement and test these, since I don't have prior  
> experience using/modifying these tools. So I send this humble request  
> to the hordes of Sakai developers out there who would be in a better  
> position than me to make these changes. Please let me know if you  
> have any questions -- I'd be happy to help.
>
> If you want to see how it works, build the current version from the  
> trunk, go to Preferences and change your language to "Dutch" (which  
> is the most complete translation to date).
>
> - Beth
>
> ----------------------
> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab 
> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development site.
> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > 
> Preferences.

body:
On Dec 21, 2005, at 11:08 AM, Seth Theriault wrote:

> Nuno Fernandes wrote:
>
>> There is no problem of including the code! If you are interested,  
>> after I clean up the code, I can send you a copy of our  
>> Synchroniztion Job (adds users, profiles, sites, sections, sites  
>> and sections memberships) in a few days.
>
> Can I recommend that you make it available (somewhere) to the wider  
> community?
>
> Ideally, I'd like to see institutional examples for providers,  
> Quartz jobs, sakai.properties files, etc.  made available for  
> people to look over, etc. assuming that there aren't any  
> institutional or legal obstacles. Checking out how other people  
> have done things is often very useful before/during/after you try  
> to tackle your own situation.
>
> Perhaps a good place to collect these might be in the Enterprise  
> group's Confluence area? That way questions/comments could be made.

This is a great idea.  It is the Enterprise groups primary intent and  
purpose to facilitate this type of communication about how to  
install, configure, and maintain Sakai.

Also we do make SVNs in contrib if/when interest builds to the point  
where this nuggets need source control.

We have SVNs in contrib for Virginia, UNISA, etc already - these are  
most interesting to these sites, but it makes it really easy for  
other's to take a look at what is there, versions, etc.

/Chuck

body:
Thanks Zach.  

This is indeed a nice holiday/Christmas present.

Luke

>>> "Zach A. Thomas" <zach.thomas@txstate.edu> 12/20/2005 11:59:04 PM
>>>
Hi everybody.

Just in time for Christmas: After a comically difficult voiceover  
process* the Quicktime version of my conference presentation is  
available in Confluence.
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/download/attachments/9662/ 
developing_for_sakai.tar.gz

The title is "Developing for Sakai: Getting Started" and is the
first  
of what I hope will be a series of Sakai developer-to-developer  
training materials.

I welcome any feedback or requests for new topics.

ho ho ho,
Zach A. Thomas
Software Engineer
Texas State University
http://www.txstate.edu 

* in case you're tempted to try it, I don't recommend recording a  
full-resolution screen movie with audio of a full-resolution screen  
movie running in Powerpoint.

body:
Hi Beth,
I will checkout the most updated code! I couldn't find where to change 
the locale (that's why I referenced as "drop-down language selector") - 
probably it was in the TimeZone?!
I will checkout with the new version.

Thank you Beth!
Nuno Fernandes.

Beth Kirschner wrote:

> Nuno,
>
> The error with the timezone was fixed late yesterday -- I'd refresh 
> your checkout. I'm not sure what you mean by a drop-down language 
> selector in preferences, can you elaborate?
>
> - Beth
>
> On Dec 21, 2005, at 6:18 AM, Nuno Fernandes wrote:
>
>> Hi Beth,
>>
>> I followed your indications in order to test the dynamic language 
>> preferences. My host is using locale 'pt_PT' and I'm having the 
>> following errors:
>> - there is no drop-down language selector in preferences;
>> - when selecting Timezone I get the exception: "Innapropriate object 
>> class for LocaleComparator"
>>
>> Note: there is no pt resource bundle (yet).
>> Anyone having this kind of errors?
>>
>> Nuno Fernandes.
>>
>> Beth Kirschner wrote:
>>
>>> I've checked in a new, cool feature into subversion that allows 
>>> users  to dynamically change their language locale (without 
>>> affecting other  users). Kudos go to Tatsuki Sugiura for developing 
>>> the ResourceLoader  class that implements this. Details can be found 
>>> at http:// 
>>> collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1117804916661-111798/ 
>>> sakai-dynamic-locales.doc.
>>>
>>> All legacy tools have been converted to use the new ResourceLoader  
>>> class, _but_ work still needs to be done to implement these changes  
>>> in the following tools:
>>>
>>> sakai/sample-tools/
>>> sakai/gradebook
>>> sakai/metaobj/
>>> sakai/rwiki/
>>> sakai/sam/
>>> sakai/sections/
>>> # sakai/tbd/  (any future tools should use the ResourceLoader too)
>>>
>>> The changes are lightweight and easy to do -- I just don't feel I'm  
>>> the best person to implement and test these, since I don't have 
>>> prior  experience using/modifying these tools. So I send this humble 
>>> request  to the hordes of Sakai developers out there who would be in 
>>> a better  position than me to make these changes. Please let me know 
>>> if you  have any questions -- I'd be happy to help.
>>>
>>> If you want to see how it works, build the current version from the  
>>> trunk, go to Preferences and change your language to "Dutch" (which  
>>> is the most complete translation to date).
>>>
>>> - Beth
>>>
>>> ----------------------
>>> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab 
>>> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development 
>>> site.
>>> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > 
>>> Preferences.
>>>
>>>
>>
>> ----------------------
>> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab 
>> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development site.
>> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > 
>> Preferences.
>>

body:
For those of you think (like me) more chronologically, I have 
re-organized the Austin Conference confluence page into several large 
table organized by date and time.  I've also included who the presenters 
were, so now you can page-search to find your favorite author!  Chuck 
mentioned that we should flag those entries that have presentation or 
audio materials.  I've done a few just to show you how it can be done, 
but ya'll are gonna have to help do the rest.  As it is, this page took 
a couple ofhours to build.

*http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/winterconf2005/Conference+By+Day

*- Mark Norton*
*

body:
Hi Seth,

I am currently working on the code so, as soon as I finish, I will clean 
up code and provide all the code to the community. This will take 
sometime yet but I will publish here when it is done!

Thank you,
Nuno Fernandes.

Seth Theriault wrote:

> Nuno Fernandes wrote:
>
>> There is no problem of including the code! If you are interested, 
>> after I clean up the code, I can send you a copy of our 
>> Synchroniztion Job (adds users, profiles, sites, sections, sites and 
>> sections memberships) in a few days.
>
>
> Can I recommend that you make it available (somewhere) to the wider 
> community?
>
> Ideally, I'd like to see institutional examples for providers, Quartz 
> jobs, sakai.properties files, etc.  made available for people to look 
> over, etc. assuming that there aren't any institutional or legal 
> obstacles. Checking out how other people have done things is often 
> very useful before/during/after you try to tackle your own situation.
>

body:
Hi all

I have a Sakai tool which hosts an applet, and the applet in turn posts 
data to a servlet, which is packaged in the tool's war. This was working 
fine in Sakai 1.0 and 1.5, but now it wouldn't work in Sakai 2.0. The 
URL of my servlet now invokes Sakai's LoginTool servlet, which would 
complain of null user ID and password. Even when I added the 'eid' and 
'pw' parameters, as required by LoginTool, to the request in my applet, 
they'll still appear to be null when the request comes to LoginTool.

I wonder if I could somehow post to my servlet without the LoginTool 
being invoked? Any help would be appreciated.

cheers.
-Jon

body:
Hi,
I am currently trying to create batch jobs that create course sites by 
uploading the course information from our SIS into Sakai using the 
Scheduler tool. I am using Sakai 2.1.

I have been getting permission exceptions when the batch job runs. The 
logs display the following error message

Creating individual course sites
PermissionException -> org.sakaiproject.exception.PermissionException 
user=null lock=site.add resource=/site/2006,SPRING,BIS,001
Ending the Course Sync for Spring 2006

The error is thrown at the following line in the code

Site siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(bannerSiteId, "course");

I have created the site Id of the course as a comma-separated string of 
values.

I initially thought that the error was because of some abnormal locks. I 
cleared the locks on any sites by clearing the records from the 
SAKAI_LOCKS table, but that did not solve the issue.

Any suggestions on how to resolve the issue would be highly invaluable

Regards,
Vishwak
UC Merced

----------------------

body:
Vish,

Don't be misled by the word "lock" in the log message - it should say  
"function"  It is lock because the code is "unlocking" something.

user=null is your real problem - you need to make sure the thread is  
running as admin.  Not being an expert in Quartz - I have no  
particular advice :)

/Chuck

body:
Vishwak,

As Chuck mentioned, you need a session going for the thread and log  
in a user.  Place something like this at the top of your jobs:

//  set the user information into the current session
Session sakaiSession = SessionManager.getCurrentSession();
sakaiSession.setUserId("admin");
sakaiSession.setUserEid("admin");

// establish the user's session
UsageSession session = UsageSessionService.startSession("admin",  
"127.0.0.1", "Quartz_Session");

// update the user's externally provided realm definitions
AuthzGroupService.refreshUser("admin");

// post the login event
EventTrackingService.post(EventTrackingService.newEvent 
(UsageSessionService.EVENT_LOGIN, null, true));



Andrew

body:
Grace,

There's a project underway called 'openwebfolder' (see 
http://openwebfolder.mozdev.org/) to add WebDAV capabilities to 
Firefox/Mozilla.

Looks like it would only work for Windows users since it "just adds 
hooks so that Microsoft's WebDAV client can be invoked in a similar way 
like in IE."

Other OSes, e.g., Mac OS X, would have to follow different instructions 
on setting up WebDAV, tho there is no particular reason why Apple Safari 
could not tie into WebDAV if you are on OS X 10.4 (Tiger). OS X 10.4 
supports WebDAV HTTPS (SSL), while earlier versions only supported HTTP.

- Ian

In-Reply-To: <27207869.1135253053685.JavaMail.tomcat5@sharkfin.ds.itd.umich.edu>
X-Content-Type-Outer-Envelope: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/249>
body:
If as admin you visit a My Worspace (or any worksite really), then go to 
the Resources tool there and click Revise Properties, there is a field 
which can be changed to specify the site quota, and override whatever 
default you have in place.

I don't know of any way to prevent a user from having a My Workspace. If 
they don't have one, it is created when they next login.

You can control what is in a particular type of user's my workspace 
using !user template sites. A user account has a type, and when that 
account first logs in, it gets a copy of the worksite associated with 
it's type. The associated worksite it gets is named like 
!user.<accounttype>. The account type is set when the account is created 
(the Type field on the account when creating a new user). If there is no 
!user.<accounttype> site to match the account type of a user, then they 
get a copy of the !user site for their my workspace.  So you can control 
what tools a particular type of user sees in their my workspace by 
editing the associated !user template worksite. Once their acount is 
created though, they have a my workspace of their own and changes to the 
!user template site wouldn't affect them.

I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype> template 
site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the quota, and everyone 
with that account type would then get that new quota, but it didn't seem 
to work when I tried.

So, those more versed in sakaiscript can respond as to whether you can 
play with quotas that way.

John

Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:

>I want to give some students larger resources section quotas than
>others, and would like to remove the resources section from some 'My
>Workspaces' entirely.
>
>Is it possible to remove the 'My Workspace' from some accounts?
>Is it possible to create or modify 'My Workspace' accounts to have
>different quotas?
>
>I have a lot of accounts, and would like some automated way of doing
>this - is it possible in sakaiscript?
>
>Thanks to everyone in sakai-dev for all there help. Hope you all have a
>great Christmas and New Year.
>
>Cheers,
>
>Paul
>
>----------------------
>This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development site.
>You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > Preferences.
>
>
>
>  
>

body:
Right -I wasn't clear - I shold have said "...and every new account from 
then on would then get that new quota..."  But I don't think those new 
account who login and get the revised template will pick up a quota 
override set in the template when their new my workspace is created. So 
to set the my workspace quota in my workspaces for a particular account 
type would take a sakaiscript at this point I think.
thanks,
John


Stephen Marquard wrote:

> John Leasia wrote:
>
>> I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype> template 
>> site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the quota, and 
>> everyone with that account type would then get that new quota, but it 
>> didn't seem to work when I tried.
>
> The crude way of getting !user.* template changes to propagate is to 
> delete all the individual my workspace sites in the db (usual warnings 
> apply). SQL code for doing this was posted to sakai-dev a while ago 
> (by Cheryl Woghan initially I think). This is the mysql version (the 
> only copy we kept):
>
> -- optional: drop all user myWorkspaces, so they get new ones (with 
> new stuff)
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_USER where site_id like '~%' and site_id != 
> '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL_PROPERTY where site_id like '~%' and 
> site_id != '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL where site_id like '~%' and site_id != 
> '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_PAGE where site_id like '~%' and site_id != 
> '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE where site_id like '~%' and site_id != '~admin';
>
> Users will then get new My Workspaces from the template when they 
> login again.
>
> Cheers
> Stephen
>

----------------------

body:
Yep, that code looks right for deleting the workspaces for users, but 
any user who has added custom items such as Web Content pages or News 
pages will be lost when their My Workspace site is deleted, so do this 
with caution.

Cheryl

Stephen Marquard wrote:

> John Leasia wrote:
>
>> I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype> template 
>> site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the quota, and 
>> everyone with that account type would then get that new quota, but it 
>> didn't seem to work when I tried.

> The crude way of getting !user.* template changes to propagate is to 
> delete all the individual my workspace sites in the db (usual warnings 
> apply). SQL code for doing this was posted to sakai-dev a while ago 
> (by Cheryl Woghan initially I think). This is the mysql version (the 
> only copy we kept):

> -- optional: drop all user myWorkspaces, so they get new ones (with 
> new stuff)
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_USER where site_id like '~%' and site_id != 
> '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL_PROPERTY where site_id like '~%' and 
> site_id != '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL where site_id like '~%' and site_id != 
> '~admin';
> delete from SAKAI_SITE_PAGE where site_id like '~%' and site_id !=

body:
Charles Severance wrote:

> One more thing.  It is likely that you could check it out as a unit  
> and add it to your 2.1 source and deploy it kind of like melete.   
> That is all up to IU in the short term.
>
> /Chuck

That's exactly what we're doing here at UCB.  I'll forward on a few 
tidbits we've gleaned by merging the app with our local codebase and 
asking IU lots of questions:

* Message Center's DB tables are not finalized yet.  Jarrod Lannan 
"would wait to execute the DDL until tomorrow (23rd) at the earliest."

* Message Center uses its own permission setup, rather than relying on 
the framework's AuthzGroups.  It's pretty heavily integrated in the UI.

* It's unclear (to us, at least) how default permissions are set up.

* The code is still in flux, so proceed with caution.

With all of that said, the tool looks really sharp, and it's easy to 
deploy (it just dropped into our Sakai source and auto-ddl did its magic).

We're sending lots of positive vibes toward Indiana, and wishing them luck!

Josh

-- 
Josh Holtzman
Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
jholtzman@berkeley.edu
510.643.7380

body:
Hello,

Which code base are you guys using in production?  The choices are to  
run the maintenance branch or release tag code.  It seems a bit  
easier to just use the maintenance branch code base to get frequent  
updates, but then they may not be QAed until a release tag is  
created. Any comments and or recommendations on this best practices  
issue?

Best,

Thomas Amsler
Programmer
IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
W: (530) 754-5198
M: (916) 803-2226

body:
The quota can be set at any level of collections by admin in  
Resources tool now. Is that necessary? I guess my question is whether  
the quota value should be set as an Resources tool attribute instead  
of attribute for multi-level collections.

It quota is a tool attribute, we could add the "site root collection  
quota" as a configuration variable into sakai.resources.xml file, so  
that it could be set from Admin Sites tool for ! 
user.template.ANY_TYPE, and used as default setting for new  
MyWorkspace site of ANY_TYPE users.

thanks,

- Zhen
On Dec 22, 2005, at 7:49 AM, John Leasia wrote:

> Right -I wasn't clear - I shold have said "...and every new account  
> from then on would then get that new quota..."  But I don't think  
> those new account who login and get the revised template will pick  
> up a quota override set in the template when their new my workspace  
> is created. So to set the my workspace quota in my workspaces for a  
> particular account type would take a sakaiscript at this point I  
> think.
> thanks,
> John
>
>
> Stephen Marquard wrote:
>
>> John Leasia wrote:
>>
>>> I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype>  
>>> template site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the  
>>> quota, and everyone with that account type would then get that  
>>> new quota, but it didn't seem to work when I tried.
>>
>> The crude way of getting !user.* template changes to propagate is  
>> to delete all the individual my workspace sites in the db (usual  
>> warnings apply). SQL code for doing this was posted to sakai-dev a  
>> while ago (by Cheryl Woghan initially I think). This is the mysql  
>> version (the only copy we kept):
>>
>> -- optional: drop all user myWorkspaces, so they get new ones  
>> (with new stuff)
>> delete from SAKAI_SITE_USER where site_id like '~%' and site_id !=  
>> '~admin';
>> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL_PROPERTY where site_id like '~%' and  
>> site_id != '~admin';
>> delete from SAKAI_SITE_TOOL where site_id like '~%' and site_id !=  
>> '~admin';
>> delete from SAKAI_SITE_PAGE where site_id like '~%' and site_id !=  
>> '~admin';
>> delete from SAKAI_SITE where site_id like '~%' and site_id !=  
>> '~admin';
>>
>> Users will then get new My Workspaces from the template when they  
>> login again.
>>
>> Cheers
>> Stephen
>>
>

> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development  
> site.
> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace >  
> Preferences.

body:
Seth,

Correct me if I am wrong, but CAS only provides authentication correct?
This is compared to say LDAP where we adjust the UserDirectoryProvider
to give up email address and other information.

Kevin


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Seth Theriault [mailto:slt@columbia.edu]
> Sent: Friday, December 09, 2005 9:17 PM
> To: Kevin Carpenter
> Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
> Subject: Re: CAS and Sakai 1.5
> 
> Kevin Carpenter wrote:
> 
> > Do I understand it correctly, that when setting up CAS with Apache
> > using a mod_cas configuration that I do NOT need to make changes or
> > update any existing Sakai code?  If so, how is the userid passed
> > into Sakai?  Is that done because of setting 'container.auth=true'
> > in the sakai.properties file?  As well as the changes in the
> > login.vm?
> 
> If you are using mod_cas, you only need to make the changes to
> httpd.conf, Tomcat, and the login.vm UI as listed. Sakai will use the
> value of REMOTE_USER as the userid. The login.vm changes are optional
> but make it easy for you to still login as "admin" if needed.
> 
> (For those interested, the xlogin.* properties introduced in 2.0.0+
> were partially inspired by some of UI work done in conjunction with
> CASification.)
> 
> If you want to use a servlet filter, the steps are similar but
> different. I have a 1.5 instance running with a servlet filter, so
> feel free to contact me if you go this way.
> 
> Seth
> 
> ----------------------
> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab
> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development

body:
UC Berkeley will be deploying off of the Maintenance branch for its  
spring production pilot. We will do a final merge on 1/2/06.

The reasoning behind our decision is simple. We know there are there  
are post 2.1 fixes we need for the spring, and we can't wait for  
2.1.1. Just as importantly, IU has QA'ed post 2.1 code to their  
satisfaction in preparation for a full, Maintenance branch based  
production release. They are in it deeper than we are :-).

Oliver

On Dec 22, 2005, at 10:03 AM, Thomas Amsler wrote:

> Hello,
>
> Which code base are you guys using in production?  The choices are  
> to run the maintenance branch or release tag code.  It seems a bit  
> easier to just use the maintenance branch code base to get frequent  
> updates, but then they may not be QAed until a release tag is  
> created. Any comments and or recommendations on this best practices  
> issue?
>
> Best,
>
> Thomas Amsler
> Programmer
> IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
> tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
> tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
> W: (530) 754-5198
> M: (916) 803-2226
>

body:
I was getting the PermissionsException because I was not making sure 
that the thread is running as admin. Adding the code that Andrew posted 
solved the problem.

Thanks to Andrew and Chuck , for pointing out the problem and helping me 
to resolve the issue.

- Vishwak

Andrew Poland wrote:

> Vishwak,
>
> As Chuck mentioned, you need a session going for the thread and log  
> in a user.  Place something like this at the top of your jobs:
>
> //  set the user information into the current session
>     Session sakaiSession = SessionManager.getCurrentSession();
>     sakaiSession.setUserId("admin");
>     sakaiSession.setUserEid("admin");
>
>     // establish the user's session
>     UsageSession session = UsageSessionService.startSession("admin",  
> "127.0.0.1", "Quartz_Session");
>     
>     // update the user's externally provided realm definitions
>     AuthzGroupService.refreshUser("admin");
>
>     // post the login event
>     EventTrackingService.post(EventTrackingService.newEvent 
> (UsageSessionService.EVENT_LOGIN, null, true));
>
>
>
> Andrew
>
>
> On Dec 21, 2005, at 8:03 PM, Vishwak Rajgopalan wrote:
>
>> Hi,
>> I am currently trying to create batch jobs that create course sites  
>> by uploading the course information from our SIS into Sakai using  
>> the Scheduler tool. I am using Sakai 2.1.
>>
>> I have been getting permission exceptions when the batch job runs.  
>> The logs display the following error message
>>
>> Creating individual course sites
>> PermissionException ->  
>> org.sakaiproject.exception.PermissionException user=null  
>> lock=site.add resource=/site/2006,SPRING,BIS,001
>> Ending the Course Sync for Spring 2006
>>
>> The error is thrown at the following line in the code
>>
>> Site siteEdit = SiteService.addSite(bannerSiteId, "course");
>>
>> I have created the site Id of the course as a comma-separated  string 
>> of values.
>>
>> I initially thought that the error was because of some abnormal  
>> locks. I cleared the locks on any sites by clearing the records  from 
>> the SAKAI_LOCKS table, but that did not solve the issue.
>>
>> Any suggestions on how to resolve the issue would be highly invaluable
>>
>> Regards,
>> Vishwak
>> UC Merced
>>
>> ----------------------
>> This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab  
>> (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development  
>> site.
>> You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace >  
>> Preferences.
>>
>

body:
Hi,
I apologize if this question has already been answered,  and since I am 
really not very familiar with the Mercury site myself, this might seem 
trivial for some of you :-(.
I've noticed the following behavior: a 'maintain' user that has just been 
added logs in and has access to 2 sites : MyWorkspace and Mercury. The 
question is why does the mercury site come in, given that it doesn't for 
all the other users I've created? (admin has it, of course). A possible 
related point is that this user has logged in several times before given 
that there's LDAP access in this Sakai instance, and so he could log in 
without having an explicit user object in Sakai.
(when I configured my provider, I didn't set it to create new users in 
Sakai if they didn't already exist).
Is this the expected behavior?
-Patricia

Patricia Goldweic
pgoldweic@northwestern.edu

body:
It turns out that the user that was getting access to the 'mercury' site 
apparently automatically, had actually joined the site in one of the 
previous logins :-(. So please ignore my previous email with the question 
about access to the Mercury site).
Thanks,


Patricia Goldweic
pgoldweic@northwestern.edu

body:
I did this recently in a sandbox server to try it out. The message  
center is very easy to add to Sakai 2.1, but as of a week ago, it  
threw an error when I tried to add a new topic.

We'll be following it quite closely at Texas State.

Zach A. Thomas
Software Engineer
Texas State University
http://www.txstate.edu

body:
Hi,

Good idea. Is it possible to merge the archive into the remaining  
sakai-dev list so all the email is is one, searchable place?

Cheers for the holidays,

Jim



On Dec 22, 2005, at 11:48 AM, Charles Severance wrote:

> I would like to mothball the SEPP Development Group.  I would  
> propose the following:
>
> - Reroute the sepp-devel@collab.sakaiproject.org alias/mail to  
> sakai-dev for upwards compatibility
>
> - Make membership "public" for SEPP Development so anyone can join
>
> - Mark the SEPP Development site as Archive-Only and redirect  
> people to Sakai Development
>
> A quick check suggests that there is about one thread per month on  
> the group.  I think that its existence is confusing to folks.
>
> Comments?
>
> /Chuck
