body:
I think you are describe the characteristics of a Learning Management 
System, Chuck.  A good LMS allows a student to register, view content, 
sequence material based on assessments, track progress, etc.

Sakai isn't really designed to do that at this time, though it is an 
interesting avenue for exploration.  Sakai is intended to support 
classroom learning and foster on-line collaboration for both learning 
and projects.

- Mark Norton

Chuck Whiteman wrote:

>I am considering building an online course to deliver SCUBA instruction and am investigating Sakai as a platform for doing so. Before I proceed, I was hoping to get some feedback on whether Sakai is a good fit for the application.
>
>Here are some of our requirements:
>
>1) Deliver multi-media content in the form of Java Applets & QuickTime clips.
>
>2) Create an "audit trail" of time spent on each section and quiz question answers.
>
>3) Create a pool of questions that all test the same concept. This is required since we require 100% Correct answers prior to moving on to the next section of the course. We will continue to test the student until they achieve 100%.
>
>4) Ideally, would like to deliver the same course with unique branding elements depending on the url the course was initially accessed from. In other words, include the logo for a marketing partner that is using the platform to train students.
>
>5) Dynamically register students after they have paid for the class. Currently, we automatically send the student an email with a unique access code (dynamically pulled from a table of pre-made access codes) right after they complete the purchase of the class.
>
>6) Allow the student to come back and "review" the course material after "graduation" whenever they feel like it.
>
>Other than these requirements, I think that our needs are pretty basic.
>
>If you have a moment to respond to this post, I'd really appreciate it.

body:
Sakai has per - site quota management within content hosting...

- Glenn

Glenn R. Golden
Sakai Framework Architect
University Of Michigan
ggolden@umich.edu


On Jan 4, 2006, at 4:38 PM, Casey Dunn wrote:

> Glenn R. Golden wrote:
>
>> The code that forms the path is in the content hosting service   
>> implementation, either the base or the db version.  If you need  
>> to  change it, you should be able to extend the class and replace  
>> the  pathing code with your own version, then register the new  
>> code as the  content hosting service implementation.
>>
>> But... don't think that you can change it so that you can "tie in"  
>> to  an existing set of AFS space that the user already has.  This  
>> will  not work.  Sakai needs a private file system to store the  
>> body bytes  of the files in content hosting - this is really a  
>> mixed store, with  the meta data in the database and the bytes in  
>> files in the file  system.  This private file system must be  
>> private to Sakai; the Sakai  servers must have credentials to work  
>> in there, and no other process  should be creating or deleting  
>> files from this private file system.
>>
>> Specifically, if you have end-user AFS space, this cannot be tied   
>> into in Sakai with the content hosting service we currently  
>> have.   Not to say that it can't be written... problems include  
>> proxying the  end-user's credentials through the Sakai server to  
>> access the data,  and synchronizing the meta data in the Sakai  
>> database with changes   made by other applications to the file area.
>>
>> - Glenn
>
> I'm still thinking about this for our needs, Scott and Glenn - the  
> key looks to be implementing a Hands Off security model. The  
> content must remain immune to end-user tinkering.
>
> In our current offering we do this by close setting of the AFS  
> ACLs. Members of a course have access to the course AFS space
> with the exception of the contained CourseWork managed  
> 'subdirectories.'
>
> The real win for us is in per-course (dept, etc) Quota Management.  
> ka-CHING$$$!!
>
>

body:
thanks, I'm sorry I should have read it first. I checked and the questions were copied form a MS Word file which brought a lot of MS tags; I guess this should be avoided also. Feliz Ed Smiley wrote: > Just replace " " with "&160;" using any text editor. >=20 > See: sam/docs/README.import_export.txt >=20 > /"....For well-known unicode entities you can replace them with their=20 > numbered > XML entity equivalents (see=20 > http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/entities.html). >=20 > For example, (FORALL) x (SUCH THAT) x (IS GREATER THAN) (SQUAREROOT OF) x >=20 > could be rendered as >=20 > > =E2=88=80 x : x > =E2=88=9A x > "/ >=20 > Feliz Gouveia wrote: >=20 >> >> One of our colleagues had this error while exporting a test: >> >> XML Parsing Error: undefined entity >> Location: https://fernando.ufp.pt/samigo/jsf/qti/exportAssessment.xml >> Line Number 2611, Column 33: em: super computadores=20 >> e microcomputadores.

>> --------------------------------^ >> >> we're running 2.1, CentOS, MySQL. >> >> There's text outside the us-ascii charset just in case this matters. >> I can send the saved xml file if needed. >> >> Any help is apreciated, >> Thanks >> Feliz >> >> >> >> >=20 >=20 --=20 Feliz Ribeiro Gouveia Universidade Fernando Pessoa www.ufp.pt Centro de Recursos Multimediaticos Tel 351-22.507.13.06 M.I.N.D. body:
Chuck,

Below is my informal assessment of what Sakai can and can't do for you
with respect to your needs.  Some of the features you are looking for
are found in major vendor LMSs.  Many in the Sakai community would like
to see these features incorporated into Sakai as well and given the
momentum it won't be very long before we get there.  

Luke

>>> Chuck Whiteman <cwhiteman@holidaydiver.com> 01/04/06 1:52 PM >>>
I am considering building an online course to deliver SCUBA instruction
and am investigating Sakai as a platform for doing so. Before I proceed,
I was hoping to get some feedback on whether Sakai is a good fit for the
application.

Here are some of our requirements:

1) Deliver multi-media content in the form of Java Applets & QuickTime
clips.

Sakai can host this content and make it easily accessible within a
course.  You can choose to author the content in whatever your favorite
html/multimedia editors are and then upload them to Sakai. 
Alternatively you could integrate an authoring tool like Melete or LAMS
into Sakai to help out with the authoring within Sakai proper.

2) Create an "audit trail" of time spent on each section and quiz
question answers.

I'm not aware of these utilities existing in Sakai yet although I'd
expect that they have been entered as requirements.  They certainly
exist in products like WebCT and I'd hazard that a significant portion
of the Sakai community would like to see them in Sakai as well.  I'm
delivering my first course in Sakai this semester and will miss
comprehensive audit trails as they existed in my WebCT course (that's
not to say that there aren't other wonderful things in Sakai that make
up for this deficit).


3) Create a pool of questions that all test the same concept. This is
required since we require 100% Correct answers prior to moving on to the
next section of the course. We will continue to test the student until
they achieve 100%.

Sakai has a Quizzing tool that will allow you to author and deliver
question banks.  It doesn't at this time allow you to perform what the
major LMS vendor refers to as "Selective Release" (although again, I'd
expect that Sakai will eventually have this as well).  Selective release
is another feature I will miss just a little bit in my Sakai course.

4) Ideally, would like to deliver the same course with unique branding
elements depending on the url the course was initially accessed from. In
other words, include the logo for a marketing partner that is using the
platform to train students.

I'm not sure about this.....there are skinning features in Sakai that
may allow you to accomplish these things.

5) Dynamically register students after they have paid for the class.
Currently, we automatically send the student an email with a unique
access code (dynamically pulled from a table of pre-made access codes)
right after they complete the purchase of the class.

Out of the box Sakai doesn't do this nor for that matter does a
commercial LMS vendor like WebCT.  However, both can do this if you
integrate them with a registration system.  

6) Allow the student to come back and "review" the course material after
"graduation" whenever they feel like it.

Sakai can do this. 

Other than these requirements, I think that our needs are pretty basic.

If you have a moment to respond to this post, I'd really appreciate it.
**********************************************************************************************

body:
I've not done any extensive searching on the subject yet, but I've been 
following the ongoing dev
discussions here with an eye to integrating sakai with SCT Luminis / 
banner as a replacement for
webct.  I'm assuming that I'll be able to sell Edison on the project, at 
which point I've already
been planning on taking a stab at this myself.  If anyone else is 
already working on this, or can
provide insight into possible related projects (Uportal integration 
springs to mind), I'd be delighted
to see what material is available.

That's not entirely on topic with your question, Carlos, but I'm 
thinking we may be going down somewhat
similar paths here.

Zack

Carlos R. Solis Ph.D. wrote:

>Good day
>
>As Rice prepares to move into full deployment of Sakai by July 1st, 2006, we
>are looking at using data from the Banner (ver. 7.1) system to populate
>courses and accounts.  EW are running oracle as our database system for
>Sakai.  Are there any other institutions who have successfully integrated
>Banner into their systems.  We face the additional task of enabling non-Rice
>people to access courses and collaboration spaces.
>
>Many thanks
>
>Carlos
>  
>

body:
To use ldap/Novell password authentication you may first had to contact the
ldap admin person on campus to allow sakai server access. Then you just need
to alter a couple of files before rebuilding.

NB - Changes detailed here are from my own documentation, so things may be
very specific to my situation and different for
yours. I understand that you can connect to a test server at nldap.com
[Novell default] but I could never connect to it - possibly firewall[?]).


Alter $SAKAI-SRC\providers\component\src\webapp\WEB-INF\components.xml:
Comment out:
<bean id="org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.user.UserDirectoryProvider"
class="org.sakaiproject.component.legacy.user.SampleUserDirectoryProvider"
init-method="init"
destroy-method="destroy"
singleton="true">
</bean>
and un-comment part starting with:
<bean id="org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.user.UserDirectoryProvider"
class="edu.amc.sakai.user.JLDAPDirectoryProvider"
init-method="init"
destroy-method="destroy"
singleton="true">
Replace:
<!-- property name="ldapHost"><value>nldap.com</value></property -->
with
<property
name="ldapHost"><value>ldap-server.your-university.ac.uk</value></property>
[NB: for dns problems try the IP address instead of
ldap-server.your-university.ac.uk]

And replace
<!--property
name="basePath"><value>ou=sakai-ldap,ou=user,o=novell</value></property-->
With (this bit is probably very specific to my establishment)
<property name="basePath"><value>ou=People, dc=ldapauth</value></property>

And replace
<!--entry key="login"><value>cn</value></entry-->   
With (this bit is also probably very specific to my establishment)
<entry key="login"><value>uid</value></entry>


Amend: $sakai-src\providers\component\project.xml:
Un-comment:
<!-- Needed for the JLDAP Provider
<dependency>
<groupId>sakaiproject</groupId>
<artifactId>sakai-jldap-provider</artifactId>
<version>${pom.currentVersion}</version>
<properties>
<war.bundle>true</war.bundle>
</properties>
</dependency>
-->

Then rebuild sakai and create a user with an existing ldap username, but no
password, and you should be able to login via ldap.

Hope this helps.



-----Original Message-----
From: shaik lateef [mailto:send2lateef@yahoo.co.in] 
Sent: 04 January 2006 17:45
To: Glenn R. Golden; Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167
Cc: sakai-dev
Subject: Re LDAP


Hi

We are having Sakai 2.1.0 version running very fine
with Oracle server. 

We have to include LDAP for this SAKAI, means we are
having Active Directory Server we have to authenticate
with this server.
Can you tell me the procedure how to setup LDAP.

Thanks & Regards,
lateef

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Jan 2006 17:02:45.0742 (UTC) FILETIME=[D96560E0:01C61219]
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/350>
body:
Melete is not working in any course sites in our Sakai 2.1 install. It
works fine in the project sites. I tried following the instructions
below but I have no idea what 4.2 b is referring to (what is the site
helper script?).
I have already checked the melete permissions for group.template.course
(instructor and TA) and site.template.course (instructor and TA) and
site.user, user.template, site.template, group.template, site.helper,
and user.template.maintain (maintain).
Help?
-AZ


4. Update Sakai Roles (under realms) to include JForum permissions

4.1 Check appropriate Melete permissions under the roles in
!site.template.course.

* Check melete.author for teacher, instructor, faculty
types of roles (maintain).
* Check melete.student for student types of custom roles
that you have (access).

4.2. If you have project sites and related roles in
!site.template.project, appropriate
permissions (jforum.manage or jforum.member) need to be
checked as defined above.

CAUTION:

a. IF YOU FAIL TO CHECK THE MELETE.STUDENT AND
MELETE.AUTHOR PERMISSIONS FOR YOUR
ROLES, MELETE WILL NOT WORK PROPERLY.
b. IF YOU ADD MELETE TO _EXISTING SITES_, USERS WILL NOT
HAVE THE MELETE PERMISSIONS
THAT YOU CHECKED. YOU WILL NEED TO USE
!SITE.HELPER OR OTHER SCRIPT TO PROPAGAGE
THE CHANGES.

--
Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech

----------------------

You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > Preferences.

body:
The 4.2.b below mentions the site helper or a script - it's not really a 
site helper script.  Site helper refers to the !site.helper realm, which 
can be used to transmit permissions to existing site realms. So if the 
problem is that Melete isn't working in sites you created before you 
added Melete to the mix, then !site.helper may work. You need to update 
any pre-existing site's realm to add Melete  permissions since adding 
them to !site.template.course only affects sites created after the 
change to !site.template.course.
There a doc  about site.helper in the Sakai Dev Resources -
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/group/1097928811887-22636/Architecture%20Docs/Sakai%202/helper_realm.pdf

If you have made appropriate changes to !site.template.course and then 
create a new course site, and Melete isn't working, then something else 
is going on and maybe the Melete folks can figure it out.

John

Zeckoski, Aaron wrote:

>Melete is not working in any course sites in our Sakai 2.1 install. It
>works fine in the project sites. I tried following the instructions
>below but I have no idea what 4.2 b is referring to (what is the site
>helper script?).
>I have already checked the melete permissions for group.template.course
>(instructor and TA) and site.template.course (instructor and TA) and
>site.user, user.template, site.template, group.template, site.helper,
>and user.template.maintain (maintain).
>Help?
>-AZ
>
>
>4. Update Sakai Roles (under realms) to include JForum permissions
>
>4.1 Check appropriate Melete permissions under the roles in
>!site.template.course.
>
>* Check melete.author for teacher, instructor, faculty
>types of roles (maintain).
>* Check melete.student for student types of custom roles
>that you have (access).
>
>4.2. If you have project sites and related roles in
>!site.template.project, appropriate
>permissions (jforum.manage or jforum.member) need to be
>checked as defined above.
>
>CAUTION:
>
>a. IF YOU FAIL TO CHECK THE MELETE.STUDENT AND
>MELETE.AUTHOR PERMISSIONS FOR YOUR
>ROLES, MELETE WILL NOT WORK PROPERLY.
>b. IF YOU ADD MELETE TO _EXISTING SITES_, USERS WILL NOT
>HAVE THE MELETE PERMISSIONS
>THAT YOU CHECKED. YOU WILL NEED TO USE
>!SITE.HELPER OR OTHER SCRIPT TO PROPAGAGE
>THE CHANGES.
>
>--
>Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
>Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech

I would recommed starting by exploring the sample JSF tools in the 
module "sample-tools/" in the sakai source dir. You can try this samples

much further for now...

Nuno Fernandes.

body:
What are the consequences of not running this script?   At the Austin
presentation "Sakai for the little guy" I gathered that I needed to make
backups through MySQL Administrator but that for a small installation
not much else was necessary MySQL-wise.

Cheers,

Luke 

>>> "Nielsen, Peter" <pnielsen@ucla.edu> 1/5/2006 3:33 PM >>>
For our 2.0.1/mysql pilot we periodically run the following script,
based on recommendations that I think came from this list.

Is this script still appropriate for Sakai 2.1.0?

/* find all sessions still open from closed servers */
select session_server, session_id, session_user, session_ip,
CONVERT(session_start, CHAR) AS 'session_start'
from SAKAI_SESSION
where SESSION_START = SESSION_END
and SESSION_SERVER not in(select SERVER_ID from SAKAI_CLUSTER);

/* find all open sessions more than 1 day old */
select session_server, session_id, session_user, session_ip,
CONVERT(session_start, CHAR) AS 'session_start'
from SAKAI_SESSION where SESSION_START = SESSION_END and
(CURRENT_TIMESTAMP > (SESSION_START + INTERVAL 1 DAY));

/* and close them */
update SAKAI_SESSION set SESSION_END = CURRENT_TIMESTAMP where
SESSION_START = SESSION_END and (CURRENT_TIMESTAMP > (SESSION_START +
INTERVAL 1 DAY));

/* find all the presence records still around from closed sessions */
select * from SAKAI_PRESENCE where SESSION_ID not in(select SESSION_ID
from SAKAI_SESSION where SESSION_START = SESSION_END);

/* delete all the presence records still around from closed sessions
*/
delete from SAKAI_PRESENCE where SESSION_ID not in(select SESSION_ID
from SAKAI_SESSION where SESSION_START = SESSION_END);

/* delete entries older than 1 day from SAKAI_EVENT */
DELETE FROM SAKAI_EVENT WHERE (CURRENT_TIMESTAMP > (EVENT_DATE +
INTERVAL 1 DAY));

body:
I have been doing some research into building my own Sakai tools. So far
I have been able to build a simple tool using a basic HttpServlet based
class.

While this works great for simple things, I want to use JSF for the more
complex stuff.



I have made a second tool that does exactly the same as my first tool,
but makes use of JSF.

There's a problem with this tool, it gives me an errormessage:



ERROR: Servlet.service() for servlet jsp threw exception (2006-01-05
18:25:02,151 http-8080
Processor23_org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.[Catalina].[localhost
].[/sakai-helloworld-tool].[jsp])

org.apache.jasper.JasperException: The absolute uri:
http://sakaiproject.org/jsf/sakai cannot be resolved in either web.xml
or the jar files deployed with this application at
org.apache.jasper.compiler.DefaultErrorHandler.jspError(DefaultErrorHand
ler.java:50)



This is weird, because none of the samples I have seen need to have the
custom tag to be configured in the web.xml

Anyone can enlighten me why the custom tags don't work?



Best regards,



W.Meints 

CII Portal team

Saxion Hogeschool

[see attachment: "message0.html", size: 4881 bytes]

message0.html
http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/d7fc9868-9a38-4661-8048-9afec5f16df2/message0.html

body:
I narrowed down the problem to a specific taglibrary that doesn't
function at the moment:

<%@ taglib uri="http://sakaiproject.org/jsf/sakai" prefix="sakai" %>

This line takes care of including the sakai UI tags, but appearantly its
referencing the wrong library.
Removing this line enables my tool and it works correctly now :)

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Nuno Fernandes [mailto:nuno@ufp.pt] 
Verzonden: donderdag 5 januari 2006 18:54
Aan: Willem Meints
CC: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Onderwerp: Re: Building a JSF Tool

Hi Willem,
I would recommed starting by exploring the sample JSF tools in the 
module "sample-tools/" in the sakai source dir. You can try this samples

by adding the tools to a site (using "Site" and not "WorkSite Setup").
I am too doing my first researches on tool development so can't help you

much further for now...

Nuno Fernandes.

body:
They are using the Apache license so using the jar should not be an issue.
L

________________________________

Lance Speelmon
Acting Manager Online Development
Indiana University

-----Original Message-----
From: Dave Ross [mailto:dave.ross@gmail.com] 
Sent: Thursday, December 29, 2005 2:38 PM
To: sakai-dev
Subject: BasicNewsService patch

I took a few minutes and modified the BasicNewsService to use the ROME
syndication api... the news tool seems to accept more rss urls and now
ATOM as well, but I've only done limited testing. You'll need to
manually add rome-0.7.jar to your maven repo.

Chuck, I haven't looked at the license for ROME in detail but here's the
site:

https://rome.dev.java.net/

-Dave
[see attachment: "BasicNewsService-ROME.patch", size: 9366 bytes]

body:
Luis,

This usually is a small configuration error or a bad database  
connection.

The quick suggestion is to go back through the install process  
carefully.

One thing I always check is to make sure my ~/build.properties has a  
trailing slash for the maven.tomcat.home

maven.repo.remote = http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven,http:// 
www.ibiblio.org/maven
maven.tomcat.home = /Users/csev/dev/jakarta-tomcat-5.5.9/

But this one sounds more like a bad database connection.

/Chuck

error:

https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/trunk/oncourse/src/scheduler/scheduler-c
omponent-shared/src/java/org/sakaiproject/component/app/scheduler/jobs/Updat
eProfilePhotoJob.java

Indiana University





-----Original Message-----
From: David Horwitz [mailto:dhorwitz@ched.uct.ac.za] 
Sent: Friday, January 06, 2006 7:55 AM
To: Nuno Fernandes
Cc: sakai-dev
Subject: Re: StaleObjectStateException updating profile



Hi Nuno,



I seem to get this if I try to do the setJpegPhoto call in a script. I

don't seem to get it if I don't try to set the users photo. If I don't

make this call I don't see the error.  Also that call doesn't seem to

work to set the photo (though that could be an error in my script) - is

SakaiPerson.setJpegPhoto() the way one should be getting institutional

photos into Sakia?



Regards



David

> 

> Anyone with the same behavior?

> thanks,

body:
Hi all,

Everytime an user tries to update their profile two consecutive 
exceptions are thrown:

WARN: An operation failed due to stale data
net.sf.hibernate.StaleObjectStateException: Row was updated or deleted 
by another transaction (or unsaved-value mapping was incorrect) for 
org.sakaiproject.component.common.edu..person.SakaiPersonImpl instance 
with identifier: 414

and

ERROR: Could not synchronize database state with session

Anyone with the same behavior?
thanks,
Nuno.

 boundary="------------090504020900020803090601"
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/365>
body:
Hi Aaron,

We had the same permissions problem because melete was added after the 
sites creation. As John Leasia said, you can workaround using the 
sakai.help or you can use a script to update the sakai db.

Using sakai.helper you are creating rule exceptions because you are not 
adding the permission to each user realm but, overlapping each user 
realm with the specified in sakai.helper. We opted to do it using a 
script, updating directly each user realm.
I have attached such script (in perl) wich you can customize for your 
needs. I have also commented the script for better understanding. If you 
use it, please let me know if you need further help!

Hope it helps.
Nuno Fernandes.

Zeckoski, Aaron wrote:

>Melete is not working in any course sites in our Sakai 2.1 install. It
>works fine in the project sites. I tried following the instructions
>below but I have no idea what 4.2 b is referring to (what is the site
>helper script?).
>I have already checked the melete permissions for group.template.course
>(instructor and TA) and site.template.course (instructor and TA) and
>site.user, user.template, site.template, group.template, site.helper,
>and user.template.maintain (maintain).
>Help?
>-AZ
>
>
>4. Update Sakai Roles (under realms) to include JForum permissions
>
>4.1 Check appropriate Melete permissions under the roles in
>!site.template.course.
>
>* Check melete.author for teacher, instructor, faculty
>types of roles (maintain).
>* Check melete.student for student types of custom roles
>that you have (access).
>
>4.2. If you have project sites and related roles in
>!site.template.project, appropriate
>permissions (jforum.manage or jforum.member) need to be
>checked as defined above.
>
>CAUTION:
>
>a. IF YOU FAIL TO CHECK THE MELETE.STUDENT AND
>MELETE.AUTHOR PERMISSIONS FOR YOUR
>ROLES, MELETE WILL NOT WORK PROPERLY.
>b. IF YOU ADD MELETE TO _EXISTING SITES_, USERS WILL NOT
>HAVE THE MELETE PERMISSIONS
>THAT YOU CHECKED. YOU WILL NEED TO USE
>!SITE.HELPER OR OTHER SCRIPT TO PROPAGAGE
>THE CHANGES.
>
>--
>Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
>Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech
>

body:
For those of you using the production maintenance branch, I highly
recommend you change your procedures.  Two things are occurring that
will warrant this change:



1.	We are about to potentially destabilize /branches/sakai_2-1/
(the current production maintenance branch) in order to prepare for the
future Sakai 2.1.2 release which will include many commits from HEAD
that are currently missing from the branch.  This statement will of
course naturally lead you to the next point...
2.	The preparations for the Sakai 2.1.1 release are beginning to
get underway.  To support this effort I have copied the current
production maintenance branch to /branches/sakai_2-1-1/ as of r5139.
For those of you running production releases off of the maintenance
branch, you should switch your builds to this new branch immediately.
Moving forward, only fixes that are deemed "worthy" for the 2.1.1
release will be merged into this branch so it will remain quite stable
and receive relatively few deltas.  In a few days, we will be creating
the first sakai_2-1-1_001 tag from this new branch.



Cheers, L



PS - IU will be running /branches/sakai_2-1-1@5139 this coming Thursday
12 January 2006.  



_____  

Lance Speelmon

Acting Manager Online Development

Indiana University

body:
Paul,
As stated below I don't know of a  way to selectively set quotas on 
sites of a particular type other than by running some script.

The different tool lists for different types of accounts can be 
accomplished by creating site templates for each type of user. 
!site.template.Undergrad_student, !site.template.Postgrad_student, etc.  
Edit each of those sites and put in whatever pages/tools you want, and 
then when a new account logs in, they get a My Workspace according to 
the associated template.  This would affect only accounts which logged 
in for the first time after you established those templates.

There is  no step by step manual at this point. See the ppt presentation 
made at the Austin conference at
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=9638
for an overview which includes a bit of information about site.templates.

Many have used scripts to do similar things to existing sites using 
scripts. Maybe someone can supply one and you could set that up as a 
quartz job I suppose.
John

Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:

>I would like to create some different user account types, and modify the
>tools / quota's for these account types. However I am unclear of
>where-abouts in the administration worksite I should be making these
>changes. Sorry for these rather basic questions, but it really isn't
>clear to me how I should do this, and would really appreciate it if
>someone could spare the time to point me in the right direction.
>
>Specifically, I would like to:
>- create three account types: Undergrad_student , Postgrad_student and
>Tutor.
>- set different default sizes for there workspace quota's, for example
>Undergrads - 1mb , Postgrads  - 2mb and Tutors - 10mb.
>- provide different tool lists in the "my workspace", depending on the
>account type.
>- set the resources size of project sites.
>
>Is there a step-by-step guide somewhere that explains how to go about
>these tasks?
>
>Also in worksite setup, I cannot see user "My Workspace" sites, clicking
>on View "My Workspace sites", simply gives a message "No sites were
>found in the view of "My Workspace", despite their being existing user
>workspace's (with content).
>
>I'm using Sakai 2.1.0 (maintenance branch:
>https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/branches/sakai_2-1/), with MySQL 4.1
>.
>
>Cheers,
>
>Paul
>
>  
>
>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: John Leasia [mailto:jleasia@umich.edu] 
>>Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 12:30 PM
>>To: Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167
>>Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
>>Subject: Re: Assigning different 'My Workspace' resources quota
>>
>>If as admin you visit a My Worspace (or any worksite really), 
>>then go to 
>>the Resources tool there and click Revise Properties, there is a field 
>>which can be changed to specify the site quota, and override whatever 
>>default you have in place.
>>
>>I don't know of any way to prevent a user from having a My 
>>Workspace. If 
>>they don't have one, it is created when they next login.
>>
>>You can control what is in a particular type of user's my workspace 
>>using !user template sites. A user account has a type, and when that 
>>account first logs in, it gets a copy of the worksite associated with 
>>it's type. The associated worksite it gets is named like 
>>!user.<accounttype>. The account type is set when the account 
>>is created 
>>(the Type field on the account when creating a new user). If 
>>there is no 
>>!user.<accounttype> site to match the account type of a user, 
>>then they 
>>get a copy of the !user site for their my workspace.  So you 
>>can control 
>>what tools a particular type of user sees in their my workspace by 
>>editing the associated !user template worksite. Once their acount is 
>>created though, they have a my workspace of their own and 
>>changes to the 
>>!user template site wouldn't affect them.
>>
>>I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype> template 
>>site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the quota, 
>>and everyone 
>>with that account type would then get that new quota, but it 
>>didn't seem 
>>to work when I tried.
>>
>>So, those more versed in sakaiscript can respond as to whether you can 
>>play with quotas that way.
>>
>>John
>>
>>Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:
>>
>>    
>>
>>>I want to give some students larger resources section quotas than

body:
This procedure seems a bit strange to me as well, but I am sure that  
there is a good reason for doing this.

I am wondering why Sakai is using a little different approach of  
managing trunk, branches, and tags?  The following is a widely  
practice process:

In trunk happens all the development. There are usually a few  
scenarios when branches are created from trunk:
1. Trying something new/experimental

2. Trunk is "NEARING" a project release quality
-- Trunk is tagged along with alpha, beta, RC1, ..
-- There are cases where one creates a Release/Maintenance branch  
rather earlier then later depending on the development environment so  
it may happen that one creates a maintenance branch at beta or RC  
stage so that rapid development can continue in trunk.
-- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g. Sakai  
v2.1.z . Then this branch is brought up to release quality, which may  
see some tagging e.g. v2.1.0-RC2, etc. Once that branch reaches  
release quality, an official release tag  e.g. Sakai v2.1.0 is created

3. Trunk is "AT" project release quality
-- Trunk has been tagged with alpha, beta, RC1, ..., tags and reaches  
release quality
-- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g. Sakai  
v2.1.z . At the same time, an official release tag is created of the  
maintenance branch e.g. Sakai v2.1.0

Once a release/maintenance branch is created, ONLY bug fixes will be  
applied. This allows folks to run release tags of the maintenance  
branch and not actually the maintenance branch code, which may  
contain bug-fixes that ore not quite tested yet.

So the above process description may look like this:

e.g. Sakai v2.1.0 release

1. trunk: development and tagging with v2.1.0-a1, ...,  v2.1.0- 
b1, ..., v2.1.0-RC1, ... (Lots of Q/A)
2. trunk is reaching v2.1.0 release quality: create maintenance  
branch v2.1.z
3. create official release tag v2.1.0 off maintenance branch v2.1.z
4. continue development in trunk towards v2.2.0 or whatever version  
number is appropriate (See note below)
5. apply bug-fixes to v2.1.z maintenance branch and create tag  
releases if Q/Aed v2.1.1, v2.1.2 etc. (During the Q/A process it may  
be appropriate to create test tags of the maintenance branch so we  
may have v2.1.1-RC1, etc. before release tag v2.1.1 is created.


NOTE:

We have discussed this earlier at the UofM boot camp, but it would  
make sense to go a step further  in the way we manage our release  
numbers.  In my opinion, it would make a lot of sense to adopt a  
Linux style version numbering schema where odd and even numbers are  
used to differentiate between development and production code.

Development:
v1.1.z
v1.2.z
...
v2.1.z
v2.3.z
etc.

Production:
v1.0.z
v1.2.z
...
v2.0.z
v2.2.z
etc.

Comments?


Thomas Amsler
Programmer
IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
W: (530) 754-5198
M: (916) 803-2226



On Jan 6, 2006, at 10:39 AM, Bill Crosbie wrote:

> I'm forwarding this brief exchange with Lance for the benefit of  
> others like myself who were slightly confused by the forward path.
>
> ----------------
> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>
>> For those of you using the production maintenance branch, I highly
>> recommend you change your procedures.  Two things are occurring that
>> will warrant this change:
>>
>>
>>
>> 1.    We are about to potentially destabilize /branches/sakai_2-1/
>> (the current production maintenance branch) in order to prepare  
>> for the
>> future Sakai 2.1.2 release which will include many commits from HEAD
>> that are currently missing from the branch.  This statement will of
>> course naturally lead you to the next point...
>
>
> Lance,
>
> Maybe I'm misunderstanding this.  Isn't the idea of the maintenance  
> branch is that it is supposed to be a stable build for those of us  
> not running off of head?
>
> I guess what I'm asking is this - is it easier for the developers  
> to change their tools to point to a new branch for the next point  
> release or is it easier to ask the community to change their  
> established procedures for rolling out the software?
>
> Bill
>
>
> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
>
> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>
>> Bill,
>>
>> The problem we are trying to solve is that we have some production  
>> folks
>> that need newer stable code that are willing to assume some more  
>> risk.
>> Others need to be a bit more conservative plus we need a place for
> the 2.1.1
>> release changes to occur.  The approach we have taken solves both
> problems
>> and keeps those at the tip of the spear happy while keeping those  
>> a bit
>> behind the tip happy as well.  We think this will be a normal
> occurrence as
>> we do dot releases.  If you have other suggestions, I would be glad
> to hear
>> them.  Keep in mind that some of this process is working the way  
>> that svn
>> works if you know what I mean.  :P  L
>
>
> Lance,
>
> Thanks for the reply.  I was just asking because we are going to  
> try to run as close to the tip of the spear** as we can, given our  
> small staff. (Yes, you convinced me to just suck it up and do it on  
> the ride back from the reception at UT Austin.)
>
> So if I am hearing you correctly - the proper branch to pull for a  
> spring release is now the 2-1-1 if we need/want the current latest  
> and greatest code that is *reasonably* stable.  is this correct?
> Bill
>
>
>
> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
> Bill,
>
> That is right.  The sakai_2-1-1 branch will be the best thing to  
> use for
> about six weeks.  We will then move everyone back to the sakai_2-1  
> branch.
> Sorry if this is confusing, but sakai_2-1 will also be stable but  
> will be
> considered tip of the spear, while sakai_2-1-1 will be just behind  
> the tip.
> Once sakai 2.1.1 is released the sakai_2-1-1 branch will go away.   
> This will
> likely be the procedure we follow as we do formal dot releases.  L
>
> ________________________________
>

body:
Thomas,

I can tell you that we will likely have a M2 release ready by the end of
next week (13 January 2006) which will add group capabilities.  We are also
working on a document that outlines via a timeline when additional
capabilities will be added.  When this document is ready, I will share it
with the community.

Thanks, L

________________________________

Lance Speelmon
Acting Manager Online Development
Indiana University

Do you guys have some schedule or estimate on when the next release  
tags (M2, ...)  will be created?

Best,

Thomas Amsler

body:
Chuck,


On Jan 6, 2006, at 12:03 PM, Charles Severance wrote:
>
> We are getting ready to release 2.1.1 so we need to make a place  
> (branch) that is focused on stabilizing, QAing, and releasing 2.1.1  
> - at the same time, there is a branch that is on track to become  
> 2.1.2 and a branch that is on track to become 2.2.
Well, getting ready for the 2.1.1 release should all happen in the  
already existing v2.1.z branch, there is no need for a new branch.

>
> We do one thing a little differently than other projects.  Some  
> sites agressively deploy from the trunk of the maintenance branch  
> right into production on a regular basis.  This is not recommended  
> for any sites unless the site has staff watching the maintenance  
> branch carefully.  Also sometimes folks doing small pilots just  
> grab the tip of the maintenance branch.
So folks who need maintenance branch bug fixes earlier could either  
dangerously deploy off the maintenance branch or apply specific SVN  
revisions that correlate to JIRA issues.


-- Thomas

>
> Lance is telling these "aggressive deploy" folks stick with the  
> 2.1.1 branch for the next few weeks and not follow down the 2.1.2  
> branch until he says that it is again in good shape.
>
> These are all moving targets, and these little tactical bits only  
> affect folks who are rolling to production from the maintenance  
> branch, some on a weekly basis.  Normal sites should stick with the  
> numbered and QA'd releases and ignore all of this talk about branches.
>
> /Chuck
>
> On Jan 6, 2006, at 2:28 PM, Thomas Amsler wrote:
>
>> This procedure seems a bit strange to me as well, but I am sure  
>> that there is a good reason for doing this.
>>
>> I am wondering why Sakai is using a little different approach of  
>> managing trunk, branches, and tags?  The following is a widely  
>> practice process:
>>
>> In trunk happens all the development. There are usually a few  
>> scenarios when branches are created from trunk:
>> 1. Trying something new/experimental
>>
>> 2. Trunk is "NEARING" a project release quality
>> -- Trunk is tagged along with alpha, beta, RC1, ..
>> -- There are cases where one creates a Release/Maintenance branch  
>> rather earlier then later depending on the development environment  
>> so it may happen that one creates a maintenance branch at beta or  
>> RC stage so that rapid development can continue in trunk.
>> -- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g.  
>> Sakai v2.1.z . Then this branch is brought up to release quality,  
>> which may see some tagging e.g. v2.1.0-RC2, etc. Once that branch  
>> reaches release quality, an official release tag  e.g. Sakai  
>> v2.1.0 is created
>>
>> 3. Trunk is "AT" project release quality
>> -- Trunk has been tagged with alpha, beta, RC1, ..., tags and  
>> reaches release quality
>> -- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g.  
>> Sakai v2.1.z . At the same time, an official release tag is  
>> created of the maintenance branch e.g. Sakai v2.1.0
>>
>> Once a release/maintenance branch is created, ONLY bug fixes will  
>> be applied. This allows folks to run release tags of the  
>> maintenance branch and not actually the maintenance branch code,  
>> which may contain bug-fixes that ore not quite tested yet.
>>
>> So the above process description may look like this:
>>
>> e.g. Sakai v2.1.0 release
>>
>> 1. trunk: development and tagging with v2.1.0-a1, ...,  v2.1.0- 
>> b1, ..., v2.1.0-RC1, ... (Lots of Q/A)
>> 2. trunk is reaching v2.1.0 release quality: create maintenance  
>> branch v2.1.z
>> 3. create official release tag v2.1.0 off maintenance branch v2.1.z
>> 4. continue development in trunk towards v2.2.0 or whatever  
>> version number is appropriate (See note below)
>> 5. apply bug-fixes to v2.1.z maintenance branch and create tag  
>> releases if Q/Aed v2.1.1, v2.1.2 etc. (During the Q/A process it  
>> may be appropriate to create test tags of the maintenance branch  
>> so we may have v2.1.1-RC1, etc. before release tag v2.1.1 is created.
>>
>>
>> NOTE:
>>
>> We have discussed this earlier at the UofM boot camp, but it would  
>> make sense to go a step further  in the way we manage our release  
>> numbers.  In my opinion, it would make a lot of sense to adopt a  
>> Linux style version numbering schema where odd and even numbers  
>> are used to differentiate between development and production code.
>>
>> Development:
>> v1.1.z
>> v1.2.z
>> ...
>> v2.1.z
>> v2.3.z
>> etc.
>>
>> Production:
>> v1.0.z
>> v1.2.z
>> ...
>> v2.0.z
>> v2.2.z
>> etc.
>>
>> Comments?
>>
>>
>> Thomas Amsler
>> Programmer
>> IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
>> tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
>> tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
>> W: (530) 754-5198
>> M: (916) 803-2226
>>
>>
>>
>> On Jan 6, 2006, at 10:39 AM, Bill Crosbie wrote:
>>
>>> I'm forwarding this brief exchange with Lance for the benefit of  
>>> others like myself who were slightly confused by the forward path.
>>>
>>> ----------------
>>> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>>>
>>>> For those of you using the production maintenance branch, I highly
>>>> recommend you change your procedures.  Two things are occurring  
>>>> that
>>>> will warrant this change:
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> 1.    We are about to potentially destabilize /branches/sakai_2-1/
>>>> (the current production maintenance branch) in order to prepare  
>>>> for the
>>>> future Sakai 2.1.2 release which will include many commits from  
>>>> HEAD
>>>> that are currently missing from the branch.  This statement will of
>>>> course naturally lead you to the next point...
>>>
>>>
>>> Lance,
>>>
>>> Maybe I'm misunderstanding this.  Isn't the idea of the  
>>> maintenance branch is that it is supposed to be a stable build  
>>> for those of us not running off of head?
>>>
>>> I guess what I'm asking is this - is it easier for the developers  
>>> to change their tools to point to a new branch for the next point  
>>> release or is it easier to ask the community to change their  
>>> established procedures for rolling out the software?
>>>
>>> Bill
>>>
>>>
>>> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
>>>
>>> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>>>
>>>> Bill,
>>>>
>>>> The problem we are trying to solve is that we have some  
>>>> production folks
>>>> that need newer stable code that are willing to assume some more  
>>>> risk.
>>>> Others need to be a bit more conservative plus we need a place for
>>> the 2.1.1
>>>> release changes to occur.  The approach we have taken solves both
>>> problems
>>>> and keeps those at the tip of the spear happy while keeping  
>>>> those a bit
>>>> behind the tip happy as well.  We think this will be a normal
>>> occurrence as
>>>> we do dot releases.  If you have other suggestions, I would be glad
>>> to hear
>>>> them.  Keep in mind that some of this process is working the way  
>>>> that svn
>>>> works if you know what I mean.  :P  L
>>>
>>>
>>> Lance,
>>>
>>> Thanks for the reply.  I was just asking because we are going to  
>>> try to run as close to the tip of the spear** as we can, given  
>>> our small staff. (Yes, you convinced me to just suck it up and do  
>>> it on the ride back from the reception at UT Austin.)
>>>
>>> So if I am hearing you correctly - the proper branch to pull for  
>>> a spring release is now the 2-1-1 if we need/want the current  
>>> latest and greatest code that is *reasonably* stable.  is this  
>>> correct?
>>> Bill
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
>>> Bill,
>>>
>>> That is right.  The sakai_2-1-1 branch will be the best thing to  
>>> use for
>>> about six weeks.  We will then move everyone back to the  
>>> sakai_2-1 branch.
>>> Sorry if this is confusing, but sakai_2-1 will also be stable but  
>>> will be
>>> considered tip of the spear, while sakai_2-1-1 will be just  
>>> behind the tip.
>>> Once sakai 2.1.1 is released the sakai_2-1-1 branch will go  
>>> away.  This will
>>> likely be the procedure we follow as we do formal dot releases.  L
>>>
>>> ________________________________
>>>
>>> [see attachment: "bcrosbie.vcf", size: 458 bytes]
>>>
>>>
>>> Attachments:
>>>
>>> bcrosbie.vcf
>>> http://collab.sakaiproject.org/access/content/attachment/2e7a9ade- 
>>> f67c-4973-00da-979544569e28/bcrosbie.vcf

body:
Kevin,
We found this on the dev-list.
Have you resolved this issue?
We just encountered the same problem in our production setup.
We did not have this issue in the past so we're not sure what to make of it.
This is the first time we're using a hardware loadbalancer to forward 
smtp from 25 to 1025.
Could that be causing this problem somehow?
Kyong

At 12:49 PM -0400 9/27/05, Kevin Chan wrote:
>I can confirm that UC Berkeley has also seen this problem. We have 
>not addressed it as we are trying to resolve a separate issue where 
>incoming emails are causing Sakai to crash and burn. As I was not 
>sure if the connection issue was related, I have not brought it up 
>in these mailing lists.
>
>The "warning" that we are getting in the James logs (in 
>~TOMCAT_HOME/sakai/logs/) is as follows:
>
>14/07/05 23:59:58 WARN  connections: Maximum number of open 
>connections exceeded
>- refusing connection.  Current number of connections is 30
>
>Once this limit is reached, we have found that we are unable to send 
>any further emails to the server.
>
>We are running Sun OS 5.9 with Java 1.4.2_09.
>
>Kevin Chan
>
>Systems Administrator
>Educational Technology Services
>University of California, Berkeley
>
>
>
>Anthony Atkins wrote:
>
>>Hello:
>>
>>We're starting to see a problem in our production environment (Debian
>>sarge + Oracle) where processing of incoming messages to worksites stops
>>working.
>>
>>Looking at the output of netstat -anl | grep 8025, I can see that James
>>has the maximum number of connections open.
>>
>>My theory is that James at some point either stops releasing connections
>>altogether or periodically is unable to release one or more
>>connections.  Eventually, the maximum number of available connections is
>>reached, and no additional mail can be processed.  A restart of sakai is
>>usually our solution, but obviously we want to know what's really going
>>on and put a better fix in place.
>>
>>In my reading, I came across this thread:
>>

body:
I'm forwarding this brief exchange with Lance for the benefit of others 
like myself who were slightly confused by the forward path.

----------------
Speelmon, Lance D wrote:

> For those of you using the production maintenance branch, I highly
> recommend you change your procedures.  Two things are occurring that
> will warrant this change:
>
>
>
> 1.    We are about to potentially destabilize /branches/sakai_2-1/
> (the current production maintenance branch) in order to prepare for the
> future Sakai 2.1.2 release which will include many commits from HEAD
> that are currently missing from the branch.  This statement will of
> course naturally lead you to the next point...


Lance,

Maybe I'm misunderstanding this.  Isn't the idea of the maintenance 
branch is that it is supposed to be a stable build for those of us not 
running off of head?

I guess what I'm asking is this - is it easier for the developers to 
change their tools to point to a new branch for the next point release 
or is it easier to ask the community to change their established 
procedures for rolling out the software?

Bill


---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---

Speelmon, Lance D wrote:

> Bill,
>
> The problem we are trying to solve is that we have some production folks
> that need newer stable code that are willing to assume some more risk.
> Others need to be a bit more conservative plus we need a place for 
the 2.1.1
> release changes to occur.  The approach we have taken solves both 
problems
> and keeps those at the tip of the spear happy while keeping those a bit
> behind the tip happy as well.  We think this will be a normal 
occurrence as
> we do dot releases.  If you have other suggestions, I would be glad 
to hear
> them.  Keep in mind that some of this process is working the way that svn
> works if you know what I mean.  :P  L


Lance,

Thanks for the reply.  I was just asking because we are going to try to 
run as close to the tip of the spear** as we can, given our small staff. 
(Yes, you convinced me to just suck it up and do it on the ride back 
from the reception at UT Austin.)

So if I am hearing you correctly - the proper branch to pull for a 
spring release is now the 2-1-1 if we need/want the current latest and 
greatest code that is *reasonably* stable.  is this correct?
Bill



---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
Bill,

That is right.  The sakai_2-1-1 branch will be the best thing to use for
about six weeks.  We will then move everyone back to the sakai_2-1 branch.
Sorry if this is confusing, but sakai_2-1 will also be stable but will be
considered tip of the spear, while sakai_2-1-1 will be just behind the tip.
Once sakai 2.1.1 is released the sakai_2-1-1 branch will go away.  This will
likely be the procedure we follow as we do formal dot releases.  L

________________________________

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/387>
body:
I've been working with our DBAs to track down the excessive number of 
Oracle connections we're seeing in our local sakai instance.  With the 
following configuration in sakai.properties:

initialSize@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
maxActive@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
maxIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
minIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5

we would expect to see only 5 connections, but we consistently see 15.  
It looks like both rWiki and Samigo create their own datasource by 
extending the javax.sql.BaseDataSource bean.  This leads to a tripling 
of the number of connections.  With lots of app servers in the cluster, 
this has the potential to cause problems with our Oracle instance.

We're going to dial down the number of connections in rWiki and Samigo 
by changing the spring configs in each of the tools, so this isn't going 
to cause us any problems... I just want folks out there in the community 
know what we've found w.r.t. DB connections.

I'm also curious if there a specific reason these tools have chosen to 
use their own datasources.  I saw some comments in the rWiki config 
files that made me think this was an intentional choice (possibly for 
using a custom session factory with hibernate triggers?).

Thanks,
Josh

-- 
Josh Holtzman
Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
jholtzman@berkeley.edu
510.643.7380

body:
Charles Severance wrote:

> The jar is already up on ibiblio so we don't have to add it to the 
> Sakai maven repo

The latest rome jar on ibiblio is 0.5:

http://www.ibiblio.org/maven/rome/jars/

People who want to use Dave's patch have to add the latest version 
(0.7) to their local repo. It looks like 0.7 is really a beta, so it 
hasn't been put up yet into ibiblio.

Seth

body:
Hi Nuno,

I seem to get this if I try to do the setJpegPhoto call in a script. I
don't seem to get it if I don't try to set the users photo. If I don't
make this call I don't see the error.  Also that call doesn't seem to
work to set the photo (though that could be an error in my script) - is
SakaiPerson.setJpegPhoto() the way one should be getting institutional
photos into Sakia?

Regards

David

body:
Afternoon everyone:

I am trying to track down a error we are seeing in Apache logs for CAS.
This is not Sakai specific, but I wanted to see if anyone in the list
has experienced the same.  The error is:

[error] mod_cas: certificate error: bad cert or verisignserverca.pem is
not available.

Now as this person said in January (who has similar problem but I found
no resolution
http://tp.its.yale.edu/pipermail/cas/2005-January/000993.html) this
error seems very obvious.  However it escapes me as well.

We are using Apache 2.0.53 on Solaris 9, against Sakai 1.5.1 and Tomcat
5.0.28.  I am passed to the CAS server, authenticate etc, but when
passed back through Apache, this is the error that is returned in the
logs.  The CAS server is a 2.0 version.  

I have read notes that the mod_cas is not compatible with the 2.0
version.  Further, I have tried various certificates in the required
location.  Including the servers specific and the servers CA (Thawte).

Any pointers are appreciated.

Thanks,

Kevin

----------------------

body:
Tom,

To some degree this is exactly what is happening.

We are getting ready to release 2.1.1 so we need to make a place  
(branch) that is focused on stabilizing, QAing, and releasing 2.1.1 -  
at the same time, there is a branch that is on track to become 2.1.2  
and a branch that is on track to become 2.2.

We do one thing a little differently than other projects.  Some sites  
agressively deploy from the trunk of the maintenance branch right  
into production on a regular basis.  This is not recommended for any  
sites unless the site has staff watching the maintenance branch  
carefully.  Also sometimes folks doing small pilots just grab the tip  
of the maintenance branch.

Lance is telling these "aggressive deploy" folks stick with the 2.1.1  
branch for the next few weeks and not follow down the 2.1.2 branch  
until he says that it is again in good shape.

These are all moving targets, and these little tactical bits only  
affect folks who are rolling to production from the maintenance  
branch, some on a weekly basis.  Normal sites should stick with the  
numbered and QA'd releases and ignore all of this talk about branches.

/Chuck

On Jan 6, 2006, at 2:28 PM, Thomas Amsler wrote:

> This procedure seems a bit strange to me as well, but I am sure  
> that there is a good reason for doing this.
>
> I am wondering why Sakai is using a little different approach of  
> managing trunk, branches, and tags?  The following is a widely  
> practice process:
>
> In trunk happens all the development. There are usually a few  
> scenarios when branches are created from trunk:
> 1. Trying something new/experimental
>
> 2. Trunk is "NEARING" a project release quality
> -- Trunk is tagged along with alpha, beta, RC1, ..
> -- There are cases where one creates a Release/Maintenance branch  
> rather earlier then later depending on the development environment  
> so it may happen that one creates a maintenance branch at beta or  
> RC stage so that rapid development can continue in trunk.
> -- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g.  
> Sakai v2.1.z . Then this branch is brought up to release quality,  
> which may see some tagging e.g. v2.1.0-RC2, etc. Once that branch  
> reaches release quality, an official release tag  e.g. Sakai v2.1.0  
> is created
>
> 3. Trunk is "AT" project release quality
> -- Trunk has been tagged with alpha, beta, RC1, ..., tags and  
> reaches release quality
> -- At that point a Release/Maintenance branch is created, e.g.  
> Sakai v2.1.z . At the same time, an official release tag is created  
> of the maintenance branch e.g. Sakai v2.1.0
>
> Once a release/maintenance branch is created, ONLY bug fixes will  
> be applied. This allows folks to run release tags of the  
> maintenance branch and not actually the maintenance branch code,  
> which may contain bug-fixes that ore not quite tested yet.
>
> So the above process description may look like this:
>
> e.g. Sakai v2.1.0 release
>
> 1. trunk: development and tagging with v2.1.0-a1, ...,  v2.1.0- 
> b1, ..., v2.1.0-RC1, ... (Lots of Q/A)
> 2. trunk is reaching v2.1.0 release quality: create maintenance  
> branch v2.1.z
> 3. create official release tag v2.1.0 off maintenance branch v2.1.z
> 4. continue development in trunk towards v2.2.0 or whatever version  
> number is appropriate (See note below)
> 5. apply bug-fixes to v2.1.z maintenance branch and create tag  
> releases if Q/Aed v2.1.1, v2.1.2 etc. (During the Q/A process it  
> may be appropriate to create test tags of the maintenance branch so  
> we may have v2.1.1-RC1, etc. before release tag v2.1.1 is created.
>
>
> NOTE:
>
> We have discussed this earlier at the UofM boot camp, but it would  
> make sense to go a step further  in the way we manage our release  
> numbers.  In my opinion, it would make a lot of sense to adopt a  
> Linux style version numbering schema where odd and even numbers are  
> used to differentiate between development and production code.
>
> Development:
> v1.1.z
> v1.2.z
> ...
> v2.1.z
> v2.3.z
> etc.
>
> Production:
> v1.0.z
> v1.2.z
> ...
> v2.0.z
> v2.2.z
> etc.
>
> Comments?
>
>
> Thomas Amsler
> Programmer
> IET Mediaworks, UC Davis
> tpamsler@ucdavis.edu
> tamsler@cal.berkeley.edu
> W: (530) 754-5198
> M: (916) 803-2226
>
>
>
> On Jan 6, 2006, at 10:39 AM, Bill Crosbie wrote:
>
>> I'm forwarding this brief exchange with Lance for the benefit of  
>> others like myself who were slightly confused by the forward path.
>>
>> ----------------
>> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>>
>>> For those of you using the production maintenance branch, I highly
>>> recommend you change your procedures.  Two things are occurring that
>>> will warrant this change:
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> 1.    We are about to potentially destabilize /branches/sakai_2-1/
>>> (the current production maintenance branch) in order to prepare  
>>> for the
>>> future Sakai 2.1.2 release which will include many commits from HEAD
>>> that are currently missing from the branch.  This statement will of
>>> course naturally lead you to the next point...
>>
>>
>> Lance,
>>
>> Maybe I'm misunderstanding this.  Isn't the idea of the  
>> maintenance branch is that it is supposed to be a stable build for  
>> those of us not running off of head?
>>
>> I guess what I'm asking is this - is it easier for the developers  
>> to change their tools to point to a new branch for the next point  
>> release or is it easier to ask the community to change their  
>> established procedures for rolling out the software?
>>
>> Bill
>>
>>
>> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
>>
>> Speelmon, Lance D wrote:
>>
>>> Bill,
>>>
>>> The problem we are trying to solve is that we have some  
>>> production folks
>>> that need newer stable code that are willing to assume some more  
>>> risk.
>>> Others need to be a bit more conservative plus we need a place for
>> the 2.1.1
>>> release changes to occur.  The approach we have taken solves both
>> problems
>>> and keeps those at the tip of the spear happy while keeping those  
>>> a bit
>>> behind the tip happy as well.  We think this will be a normal
>> occurrence as
>>> we do dot releases.  If you have other suggestions, I would be glad
>> to hear
>>> them.  Keep in mind that some of this process is working the way  
>>> that svn
>>> works if you know what I mean.  :P  L
>>
>>
>> Lance,
>>
>> Thanks for the reply.  I was just asking because we are going to  
>> try to run as close to the tip of the spear** as we can, given our  
>> small staff. (Yes, you convinced me to just suck it up and do it  
>> on the ride back from the reception at UT Austin.)
>>
>> So if I am hearing you correctly - the proper branch to pull for a  
>> spring release is now the 2-1-1 if we need/want the current latest  
>> and greatest code that is *reasonably* stable.  is this correct?
>> Bill
>>
>>
>>
>> ---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---+++---
>> Bill,
>>
>> That is right.  The sakai_2-1-1 branch will be the best thing to  
>> use for
>> about six weeks.  We will then move everyone back to the sakai_2-1  
>> branch.
>> Sorry if this is confusing, but sakai_2-1 will also be stable but  
>> will be
>> considered tip of the spear, while sakai_2-1-1 will be just behind  
>> the tip.
>> Once sakai 2.1.1 is released the sakai_2-1-1 branch will go away.   
>> This will
>> likely be the procedure we follow as we do formal dot releases.  L
>>
>> ________________________________
>>
>> [see attachment: "bcrosbie.vcf", size: 458 bytes]
>>
>>
>> Attachments:

body:
Good Day

We are looking at trying to set up a back up mechnism for the  
resources sectiions of users, projects and courses.  It seems like  
the web dav interface might be a workable solution if we were able to  
get mappings for resources sections and to have the back-up software  
pull files from those folders.  Is it possible to access the web dav  
mappings for resources in the database to resource folders to create  
a back-up script?

I am currently backing up my resources section on my desktop using  
this procedure but I obviously know the address to the folder and  
this is not a changing or growing constanly.

Thanks

Carlos


----------------------
Carlos R. Solis Ph.D.
Manager, Educational Technologies
Rice University
(713)348-5687

body:
I'm not sure I understand what "SakaiSession" is.  These are the key lines:

<property name="dataSource">
<ref local="sakai-sam.javax.sql.DataSource" />
</property>

Samigo seems to be using its own sessionFactory (bean 
id="sakai-sam.sessionFactory") with the Sakai SessionFactoryBase as its 
parent, but it uses its own datasource (bean 
id="sakai-sam.javax.sql.DataSource") rather than using the one provided 
by the SessionFactoryBase.

Josh

Daisy Flemming wrote:

> Hi Josh & Lance,
>  
> I think samigo is using SakaiSession, are we not? See line19
> ~/trunk/sakai/sam/component/src/java/org/sakaiproject/spring/applicationContext.xml
>  
> This part is kindly set up by Lance.
>  
> *Lance*, can you verify it? Thanks.
>  
> Daisy
>  
>
>   <!-- Use the Sakai session factory, pre-configured, instead of one 
> local to Samigo -->
>   <bean id="sakai-sam.sessionFactory"
>     class="org.springframework.orm.hibernate.LocalSessionFactoryBean "
>     
> parent="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.SessionFactoryBase">
>
>     <property name="dataSource">
>       <ref local="sakai-sam.javax.sql.DataSource" />
>     </property>
>
>
>
>  
> On 1/6/06, *Josh Holtzman* <jholtzman@berkeley.edu 
> <mailto:jholtzman@berkeley.edu>> wrote:
>
>     I've been working with our DBAs to track down the excessive number of
>     Oracle connections we're seeing in our local sakai instance.  With
>     the
>     following configuration in sakai.properties:
>
>     initialSize@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
>     maxActive@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
>     maxIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
>     minIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
>
>     we would expect to see only 5 connections, but we consistently see
>     15.
>     It looks like both rWiki and Samigo create their own datasource by
>     extending the javax.sql.BaseDataSource bean.  This leads to a tripling
>     of the number of connections.  With lots of app servers in the
>     cluster,
>     this has the potential to cause problems with our Oracle instance.
>
>     We're going to dial down the number of connections in rWiki and Samigo
>     by changing the spring configs in each of the tools, so this isn't
>     going
>     to cause us any problems... I just want folks out there in the
>     community
>     know what we've found w.r.t. DB connections.
>
>     I'm also curious if there a specific reason these tools have chosen to
>     use their own datasources.  I saw some comments in the rWiki config
>     files that made me think this was an intentional choice (possibly for
>     using a custom session factory with hibernate triggers?).
>
>     Thanks,
>     Josh
>
>     --
>     Josh Holtzman
>     Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
>     jholtzman@berkeley.edu <mailto:jholtzman@berkeley.edu>
>     510.643.7380

body:
I would like to create some different user account types, and modify the
tools / quota's for these account types. However I am unclear of
where-abouts in the administration worksite I should be making these
changes. Sorry for these rather basic questions, but it really isn't
clear to me how I should do this, and would really appreciate it if
someone could spare the time to point me in the right direction.

Specifically, I would like to:
- create three account types: Undergrad_student , Postgrad_student and
Tutor.
- set different default sizes for there workspace quota's, for example
Undergrads - 1mb , Postgrads  - 2mb and Tutors - 10mb.
- provide different tool lists in the "my workspace", depending on the
account type.
- set the resources size of project sites.

Is there a step-by-step guide somewhere that explains how to go about
these tasks?

Also in worksite setup, I cannot see user "My Workspace" sites, clicking
on View "My Workspace sites", simply gives a message "No sites were
found in the view of "My Workspace", despite their being existing user
workspace's (with content).

I'm using Sakai 2.1.0 (maintenance branch:
https://source.sakaiproject.org/svn/branches/sakai_2-1/), with MySQL 4.1
.

Cheers,

Paul

>-----Original Message-----
>From: John Leasia [mailto:jleasia@umich.edu] 
>Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 12:30 PM
>To: Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167
>Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
>Subject: Re: Assigning different 'My Workspace' resources quota
>
>If as admin you visit a My Worspace (or any worksite really), 
>then go to 
>the Resources tool there and click Revise Properties, there is a field 
>which can be changed to specify the site quota, and override whatever 
>default you have in place.
>
>I don't know of any way to prevent a user from having a My 
>Workspace. If 
>they don't have one, it is created when they next login.
>
>You can control what is in a particular type of user's my workspace 
>using !user template sites. A user account has a type, and when that 
>account first logs in, it gets a copy of the worksite associated with 
>it's type. The associated worksite it gets is named like 
>!user.<accounttype>. The account type is set when the account 
>is created 
>(the Type field on the account when creating a new user). If 
>there is no 
>!user.<accounttype> site to match the account type of a user, 
>then they 
>get a copy of the !user site for their my workspace.  So you 
>can control 
>what tools a particular type of user sees in their my workspace by 
>editing the associated !user template worksite. Once their acount is 
>created though, they have a my workspace of their own and 
>changes to the 
>!user template site wouldn't affect them.
>
>I thought you might be able to create a !user.<accounttype> template 
>site, then edit the site's resources tool and up the quota, 
>and everyone 
>with that account type would then get that new quota, but it 
>didn't seem 
>to work when I tried.
>
>So, those more versed in sakaiscript can respond as to whether you can 
>play with quotas that way.
>
>John
>
>Beckett Paul Mr (ITCS) s167 wrote:
>
>>I want to give some students larger resources section quotas than
>>others, and would like to remove the resources section from some 'My
>>Workspaces' entirely.
>>
>>Is it possible to remove the 'My Workspace' from some accounts?
>>Is it possible to create or modify 'My Workspace' accounts to have
>>different quotas?
>>
>>I have a lot of accounts, and would like some automated way of doing
>>this - is it possible in sakaiscript?
>>
>>Thanks to everyone in sakai-dev for all there help. Hope you 
>all have a
>>great Christmas and New Year.
>>
>>Cheers,
>>
>>Paul
>>

>(http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai

body:
On Jan 6, 2006, at 3:16 PM, Thomas Amsler wrote:

> Chuck,
>
>
> On Jan 6, 2006, at 12:03 PM, Charles Severance wrote:
>>
>> We are getting ready to release 2.1.1 so we need to make a place  
>> (branch) that is focused on stabilizing, QAing, and releasing  
>> 2.1.1 - at the same time, there is a branch that is on track to  
>> become 2.1.2 and a branch that is on track to become 2.2.
> Well, getting ready for the 2.1.1 release should all happen in the  
> already existing v2.1.z branch, there is no need for a new branch.

2.2, 2.1.1 and 2.1.2 are all moving targets with different people  
working on them.  We cannot stop 2.1.2 for for the few weeks it will  
take to QA 2.1.1 because 2.1.2 needs to be ready mid-February.

>> We do one thing a little differently than other projects.  Some  
>> sites agressively deploy from the trunk of the maintenance branch  
>> right into production on a regular basis.  This is not recommended  
>> for any sites unless the site has staff watching the maintenance  
>> branch carefully.  Also sometimes folks doing small pilots just  
>> grab the tip of the maintenance branch.
> So folks who need maintenance branch bug fixes earlier could either  
> dangerously deploy off the maintenance branch or apply specific SVN  
> revisions that correlate to JIRA issues.

Stick with numbered releases if you want to run code that has been  
QA'd.  If you choose to run from the maintenance branch straight into  
production - you should stay in touch with the person who is moving  
things to the maintenance branch.

Our goal is to get numbered releases out often enough to make it so  
people are not tempted to go to the maintenance branch.  Hence 2.1.1.  
in the first weeks of January.

/Chuck

body:
When following the instructions below to install the sakai plug-in permanently 
in maven I encountered a few situations that require an explanation:

1) the operation ultimately failed because maven could not sucessfully download
common.jelly.jars from cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven/  
is this failure due to the reorganization of the CVS tree due to branch/trunk maintenance? I could download the required .jars from another source, is this the best course of action?  if so, where is maven putting the dowbloaded . jar files ?

2) Does this build procedure work for Maven version 2 or 
only Maven version 1? Has maven version 2 been tested at all for the Sakai project? ( I dont think so because I ran into a multitude of issues )

thank you,
Nancy Yeager
Web Architect, Catholic University of America

________________________________

From: Zach A. Thomas [mailto:zach.thomas@txstate.edu]
Sent: Wed 1/4/2006 12:07 PM
To: Sharrie
Cc: sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org
Subject: solving the error: Goal "sakai:build" does not exist in this project



This is something that's not really explained in the presentation:
The maven goals used by Sakai are only available if the maven sakai 
plugin is available. The plugin is available in two ways:
1) if you run maven against a project.xml file that has the sakai 
plugin as a dependency. See the project.xml file in the top-level 
Sakai source directory for an example of this.
2) if you install the Sakai plugin permanently into your maven 
installation. This is performed with the command maven 
plugin:download -DartifactId=sakai -DgroupId=sakaiproject -
Dversion=2.1 -Dmaven.repo.remote=http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven/

In practical terms, this means that if you run maven in the same 
directory as the top level of the Sakai source code, you won't get 
the 'Goal "sakai:build" does not exist in this project.' error. On 
the other hand, if you just install the Sakai plugin for maven, you 
can run maven in any directory and it will know about all the maven 
sakai goals.

For your reference, here is a list of all the goals in the Sakai 
plugin for maven:
sakai ............................................ clean then build 
then deploy
sakai:build  ................................. compile and package 
the build
sakai:clean ................................. cleanup from prior builds
sakai:clean_build  ..................... clean and then build
sakai:clean_build_deploy  ...... clean then build then deploy
sakai:deploy  ............................. deploy to the local tomcat
sakai:deploy-report  ................. Report on what jars Sakai 
deploys - which
projects 
deploy what to where
sakai:deploy-zip  ...................... deploy to the 
maven.deploy.home and zip a
tomcat 
overlay structure
sakai:undeploy  ....................... remove from the local tomcat

regards,
Zach A. Thomas
Software Engineer
Texas State University
On Jan 4, 2006, at 12:27 AM, Sharrie wrote:

> Hi, the presentation does really help me a lot. It is really a 
> great job:).
> I followed your presentation to build sakai. Everything went 
> smoothly, but when I type
> maven sakai:build...
> it said ,"Goal "sakai:build" does not exist in this project."
> and I checked maven.xml, there are no such goal in it.
> I think maybe I get the wrong version or I should myself write 
> these goals.
>
> If you can send me a copy of this file or just give me some example 
> when you are convienient,
> I should be very appreciated.
>
>
> Best Regards!
> --
> Sharrie

body:
Yeager, Nancy wrote:

>When following the instructions below to install the sakai plug-in permanently 
>in maven I encountered a few situations that require an explanation:
>
>1) the operation ultimately failed because maven could not sucessfully download
>common.jelly.jars from cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven/  
>is this failure due to the reorganization of the CVS tree due to branch/trunk maintenance? 
>

>I could download the required .jars from another source, is this the best course of action?  
>
Dependencies identified in Maven project files are resolved by JARs and 
WARs built locally as part of the Sakai build process, from the 
sakaiproject.org repository or from iBiblio.com.

>if so, where is maven putting the dowbloaded . jar files ?
>  
>
Maven creates a local repository on your computer system in 
~/.maven/repository, where ~ is your home directory.

>2) Does this build procedure work for Maven version 2 or 
>only Maven version 1? Has maven version 2 been tested at all for the Sakai project? ( I dont think so because I ran into a multitude of issues )
>  
>
Sakai only works with Maven 1.0 at this time.  Do not use Maven 2.x.

- Mark Norton

body:
I'm sorry Nancy. In the command you saw, I assumed you had some  
dependencies that you don't have. This command should work:
maven plugin:download -DartifactId=sakai -DgroupId=sakaiproject \
-Dversion=2.1 -Dmaven.repo.remote=http://www.ibiblio.org/ 
maven/,http://cvs.sakaiproject.org/maven/

The only difference is I added in the ibiblio remote maven repository  
in addition to the sakaiproject remote maven repository.

regards,
Zach

body:
I have just installed a new instance of 2.1

I first started with the HSQL to make sure the deployment was good.

I then setup and converted the instance to use MYSql, turning on auto
ddl and the convert string.

I verified the system was reading against the db by changing the admin
password and seeing the field change in the db.

I then tried to add a new site. The site will "attempt" to add but not
appear to finish. The site, in Worksite setup, will have the long guid
number name (6743a223-9a79-4778-8007-bc5889f63648 ). This will also
appear on the name in the tab. If I look in Sakai_Site table, it is
there but with the guid name not the one I provided. Also when I try to
access the site I get "site not avialable"

Looking at the Tomcat log I see this error:
INFO:
org.sakaiproject.component.legacy.content.DbContentService@1ecfeb.init()
: tables: CONTENT_COLLECTION CONTENT_RESOURCE
CONTENT_RESOURCE_BODY_BINARY locks-in-db: false bodyPath: e:\Program
Files\Apache Software Foundation\Tomcat 5.5\sakai\content (2006-01-06
17:18:50,307 

It appears the path is bad, but that is in fact the path on the Windows
file system. 

I have these two lines from the Sakai properties file:
bodyPath@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingService =
${sakai.home}\content\
bodyVolumes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingServic
e = vol1,vol2,vol3

I have not changed the Sakai default "home" location.

If I archive one of the built in sites, it works and creates the folder
and contents.

Any ideas?



___________________________________________________

Dan Cotton

Manager Davis SOM Information Services

daniel.cotton@ucdmc.ucdavis.edu

http://ismed.ucdavis.edu

530-754-5761 Phone

530-792-7996 Pager

body:
Hi all,

I have been around the email archive on the past days and noticed the 
following behaviors/issues which you may hopefuly help me:

1. Although site members receive email notifications from the 
Announcements tool, new member notifications (when an user is added to a 
site) are not sent;

2. There is no postmaster@yyyy.xxx configuration is sakai (at least, I 
was unable to find). My workaround was setting an alias postmaster for 
the "Administration Workspace" and then join me as a member: this lead 
to the point below:

3. If "Email archive" is added to "Administration Workspace", email is 
not sent to its members (member have configured to receive these mails);

4. The most strange situation:
- there are 2 maintain users added to Site A: user#1 was created by 
the java API, user#2 was created by the User tool;
- all have "mail.delete.any" function in their realms;
- the button "Delete" (on Email Archive) appears to both users when 
logged;
- #2 is able to delete sucessfuly any email;
- #1 is presented with "Please confirm the removal of this email 
archive message:" (normal) but after pressing Delete the following 
appears: "Alert: You do not have permission to remove this message."
I have searched through the Sakai tables searching for some unusual 
or unset permission (function) but found nothing. Does anyone have a 
clue about what's going on?

Thank you all,
Nuno Fernandes.

----------------------
This automatic notification message was sent by Sakai Collab (http://collab.sakaiproject.org/portal) from the Sakai Development site.
You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > Preferences.
