body:
Hi all, it is Saturday morning and I am sitting here with my cup of  
coffee so it is probably time for a status update.  Hope you all had  
good holidays and took some time off.  I had a great time learning  
Cocoa and Eclipse on my days off.

We have Sakai 2.2 penciled in for July 15 - we will likely need a  
longer QA period for 2.2 than any other previous version of Sakai  
because we will be integrating a number of new software from the  
community.  We may need to do QA from May 15 through July 15.

Sakai 2.1.1 is already in the works - we should tag this soon and  
begin QA.  Hopefully the 2.1.1 QA will be pretty straightforward.   
The maintenance branch code which makes up 2.1.1 is already in  
production at IU, so at some level the key element for community QA  
for 2.1.1 is to make sure we have no regressions from 2.1.

Sakai 2.1.2 is also in the works.  This is scheduled for freeze for  
2.1.2 in mid February and QA after that.  If all goes well, Sakai  
2.1.2 will be the base for OSP 2.1 and we will (finally) be at the  
point where the OSP and Sakai code bases are synchronized.  The nice  
thing about 2.1.2 is that the OSP team will be doing QA on Sakai so  
we will have a more significant QA effort on the 2.1.2+OSP package.   
The hope is that folks can go to 2.1.2 Sakai and then "drop in OSP".   
It might not be that simple when it all works out - but that is the  
hope.

In terms of personnel, you have probably heard by now that Carol  
Dippel resigned as Sakai QA Director back in December.  She will  
still be involved - just not as the QA lead.  Carol did a great job  
for the Sakai project and she produced outstanding results in a  
challenging environment.    We miss her leadership already.

We really cannot go for long without a QA Director - we are working  
on Carol's replacement and hope to have it all worked out and  
announced in time for the new director to lead the 2.1.1 QA effort.

Some big follow on work after the Austin conference is the Sakai  
Community Practices group.  This is in the process of forming a  
charter.  See http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/SCP/ 
Charter for more details.

Another important area is the Requirements Group.  There is now a  
really cool requirements form in JIRA.  Go to http:// 
bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira, Create New Issue, Project: Sakai  
Requirements, Issue Type: Requirement.  The Requirements DG is going  
to lead a process where the community enters requirements, then  
prioritizes these requirements, and then we use the resulting list  
and try to find resources between now and   May 15 to work on those  
requirements that the community wants the most.  Of course the best  
way to get your favourite requirement worked on is to work on it  
yourself :)

/Chuck

----------------------

You can modify how you receive notifications at My Workspace > Preferences.

body:
We've started moving to 2.1. We're starting to move the Rutgers  
patches listed in Jira 2505 from 2.0.1 to 2.1. Other Rutgers staff  
will do most of this. I'm doing AccessServlet. It's been refactored,  
so most of the changes to into BaseContentService.java. Because I'm  
giving you only the changes to those modules, some feature are only  
half there. They depend upon changes to other files, which will have  
to come from other people. [However I believe that they can be easily  
adapted from the 2.0.1 patches, which you can find from Jira 2505.]

These changes are in a tar file attached to Jira 3442.

Implements 4 features. (These features are completely implemented by  
this patch. See below for the ones that are partly implemented.)

1) Aliases. If you create a mail alias for a site, you can access its  
resource section with the same alias, e.g. http://server/access/myalias
2) Content view. If you access a folder (as opposed to an individual  
resource)  via /access/content, normally you get an error. With this  
patch you will get a directory listing in a format that is  
appropriate for end users. It shows the description of the folder and  
each item, so it looks a lot like a Melete organizer page.
3) If you specify ?basedir=xxx or ?sbasedir=xxx [for Sferyx],  
directory listings have a special format intended to support pick  
lists in HTML editors. Our users want to be able to insert images  
easily in HTML. Part of that is for the HTML editor to be able to  
show them a listing on their /images directory and make it easy to  
pick an image. This is the server side of that. The basedir format  
should be easy to use in any Javascript code. The sbasedir format is  
tuned specifically for Sferyx' file picker.
4) implemented file upload via HTTP POST operations. This is also  
intended for HTML editors, to let them upload images. Sferyx uses  
this technique, and I believe other HTML editors do as well.

Interaction with other patches. I don't yet have 2.1.0 versions of  
our other patches. However I believe the 2.0.1 versions may port  
fairly easily except for this patch. (This one was hard because  
AccessServlet was refactored for 2.1.0.) See Jira entry 2505 for a  
list of our 2.0.1 patches.

1) Users without write access to resources are prevented from seeing  
inside a directory whose name starts with "protected." Other parts of  
this feature are in  ResourcesAction.java, chef_resources_list.vm,  
chef_resoures_newlist.vm. If you don't want this feature, look for  
"protected" (with the quote marks) in BaseContentService.java, and  
remove the whole paragraph (surrounded by blank lines).

2) Users can change the order of entries in resources. This patch  
uses the proper order in displaying directories, but ResourcesAction  
and the vm files [same list as (1)] need to be changed to let the use  
change the order, and to use the proper order in the Resources tool.

body:
Dan, you should leave the body path un-set unless your intent is for  
Sakai to store the blobs in the file system.

I am guessing that you are running this all on a PC as a test - so it  
makers perfect sense that

${sakai.home} ends up being the path to the tomcat running on your PC.

Storing bodies on the file system is a petty advanced feature.     It  
is in the file system where Tomcat is running - not the filesystem on  
the mysql server.

/Chuck

On Jan 6, 2006, at 8:33 PM, Cotton, Dan wrote:

> I have just installed a new instance of 2.1
>
> I first started with the HSQL to make sure the deployment was good.
>
> I then setup and converted the instance to use MYSql, turning on auto
> ddl and the convert string.
>
> I verified the system was reading against the db by changing the admin
> password and seeing the field change in the db.
>
> I then tried to add a new site. The site will "attempt" to add but not
> appear to finish. The site, in Worksite setup, will have the long guid
> number name (6743a223-9a79-4778-8007-bc5889f63648 ). This will also
> appear on the name in the tab. If I look in Sakai_Site table, it is
> there but with the guid name not the one I provided. Also when I  
> try to
> access the site I get "site not avialable"
>
> Looking at the Tomcat log I see this error:
> INFO:
> org.sakaiproject.component.legacy.content.DbContentService@1ecfeb.init 
> ()
> : tables: CONTENT_COLLECTION CONTENT_RESOURCE
> CONTENT_RESOURCE_BODY_BINARY locks-in-db: false bodyPath: e:\Program
> Files\Apache Software Foundation\Tomcat 5.5\sakai\content (2006-01-06
> 17:18:50,307
>
> It appears the path is bad, but that is in fact the path on the  
> Windows
> file system.
>
> I have these two lines from the Sakai properties file:
> bodyPath@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingService 
>  =
> ${sakai.home}\content\
> bodyVolumes@org.sakaiproject.service.legacy.content.ContentHostingServ 
> ic
> e = vol1,vol2,vol3
>
> I have not changed the Sakai default "home" location.
>
> If I archive one of the built in sites, it works and creates the  
> folder
> and contents.
>
> Any ideas?
>
>
>

>

To: Johan van den Berg <vdberj@unisa.ac.za>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.746.2)
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/397>
body:
Johan,

There is not a current activity (that I know of) to search out and  
find all of these.

My suggestion is to file a JIRA on this and send in a patch.   Keep  
the JIRA specific to the problem you see (i.e. don't file a JIRA that  
says - "look through all the code and...").

A few people (Lance, Chuck, Glenn, and John E) have discussed the  
notion having someone go through and look at every single catch block  
in Sakai and review them for appropriateness.  At least some type of  
logging might want to be added at places.

This is a pretty hard task because in a layered architecture low  
level routines are called from many contexts and sometimes it is hard  
to discern whether this failed SQL query was just the query to check  
to see if the connection was still up or if this was a critical query  
whose failure needed to be placed in the log and someone needs to  
have a pager message sent immediately.

So at times, it is not a good idea to log everything right at the  
moment it is enoucntered, but instead throw it and catch it farther  
up where code is more aware of what is going on.  But when this is  
done, sometimes API changes percolate upward - and at times there are  
abstraction boundaries where we need exceptions to be generic - so it  
is a fine art.

So we need to record these and fix them.  Jim Eng has been working on  
adding a lot of error checking in content hosting - especially in the  
store body on disk code - perhaps we need to take your patches and  
merge them into Jim's work on the store bodies in the DB side.

*******

That brings up another question - why are you storing bodies in the  
DB at all?  UNISA is a BIG site - this is not a small pilot.  Storing  
resource bodies in MySql will likely bring your system to its knees  
*very quickly*.  Within a few months, you may not even be able to get  
a backup of MySql to run because it will become so large so quickly.

/Chuck

On Jan 8, 2006, at 5:17 AM, Johan van den Berg wrote:

> Ok, so today, one day before going live with 2.0.1, we suddenly see  
> that
> all our batch imports for resources are succeeding, but looking at the
> data through the portal, the files are there but have no content.
>
> Upon further investigation, it became apparent that our MySQL ran  
> out of
> space on the content body table, and was returning an error in the
> insert, but the content service blatantly ignored the error and came
> back with a false positive upon resource import.
>
> This concerns me for all the obvious reasons...
>
> Looking deeper into sakai, it appears that there are several scenarios
> (not just resources) whereby an exception is wrongly discarded, and  
> the
> caller does not get notified of a failure.
>
> Any patch/fix that will stop things like this from happening again?
>
> Concerned user nr 1.
> Johan van den Berg
>

body:
Luke FERNANDEZ wrote:

> This is probably more of an account admin or Web services question then a developer question: 
> 
> I added student enrollments to a site using the existing Web Services methods and then, a little later, deleted these student accounts through the Sakai GUI * as one would expect the students no longer showed up in the GUI as enrolled in the course.
> 
> But when I ran a customized Web Services method that returns the enrollments (using SiteService.getSite.getMembers as coded below) it returns the original enrollments even though I deleted these accounts in the GUI.  Is there a simple explanation for this or perhaps a doc that explains why this occurs?

The GUI "delete user" only does a very minimal delete operation, and leaves 
intact all sorts of user information, recorded in JIRA as:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-655
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-1456
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-1535

There was a sakai-dev thread on this which moved to framework in Dec 05. This is 
either a bug or a design issue, depending on your point of view. Personally I 
think there's room for improvement in the default behaviour.

Regards
Stephen

-- 
Stephen Marquard
Learning Technologies Co-ordinator, Centre for Educational Technology
Centre for Higher Education Development, University of Cape Town
Email: marquard@ched.uct.ac.za IM: xmpp:marquard@ched.uct.ac.za
Cell: +27-83-500-5290

body:
Ok, so today, one day before going live with 2.0.1, we suddenly see that
all our batch imports for resources are succeeding, but looking at the
data through the portal, the files are there but have no content.

Upon further investigation, it became apparent that our MySQL ran out of
space on the content body table, and was returning an error in the
insert, but the content service blatantly ignored the error and came
back with a false positive upon resource import.

This concerns me for all the obvious reasons...

Looking deeper into sakai, it appears that there are several scenarios
(not just resources) whereby an exception is wrongly discarded, and the
caller does not get notified of a failure.

Any patch/fix that will stop things like this from happening again?

Concerned user nr 1.
Johan van den Berg

Aaron - Sorry for the delay in replying. We have been buried in production
setup work for spring classes; we've been unable to get to our email. 

It looks like John L and Nuno F provided you with prompt, pointed feedback
(thanks, you two!). This does sound like a permissions problem. Either
approach (sakai's helper) or Nuno's perl script will do the trick (propagate
the melete permissions down to your existing sites). 

Let us know if there are any pending issues with your Melete installation. 

Vivie

--
Vivian 'Vivie' Sinou
Dean, Learning Technology & Innovations
Foothill College


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Zeckoski, Aaron [mailto:aaronz@vt.edu] 
> Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 9:03 AM
> To: sakai-dev
> Subject: Melete permissions problem
> 
> Melete is not working in any course sites in our Sakai 2.1 
> install. It works fine in the project sites. I tried 
> following the instructions below but I have no idea what 4.2 
> b is referring to (what is the site helper script?).
> I have already checked the melete permissions for 
> group.template.course (instructor and TA) and 
> site.template.course (instructor and TA) and site.user, 
> user.template, site.template, group.template, site.helper, 
> and user.template.maintain (maintain).
> Help?
> -AZ
> 
> 
> 4. Update Sakai Roles (under realms) to include JForum permissions
> 
> 4.1 Check appropriate Melete permissions under the roles in 
> !site.template.course.
> 
> * Check melete.author for teacher, instructor, faculty types 
> of roles (maintain).
> * Check melete.student for student types of custom roles that 
> you have (access).
> 
> 4.2. If you have project sites and related roles in 
> !site.template.project, appropriate permissions 
> (jforum.manage or jforum.member) need to be checked as defined above.
> 
> CAUTION:
> 
> a. IF YOU FAIL TO CHECK THE MELETE.STUDENT AND MELETE.AUTHOR 
> PERMISSIONS FOR YOUR ROLES, MELETE WILL NOT WORK PROPERLY.
> b. IF YOU ADD MELETE TO _EXISTING SITES_, USERS WILL NOT HAVE 
> THE MELETE PERMISSIONS THAT YOU CHECKED. YOU WILL NEED TO USE 
> !SITE.HELPER OR OTHER SCRIPT TO PROPAGAGE THE CHANGES.
> 
> --
> Aaron Zeckoski (aaronz@vt.edu)
> Lead Developer - Learning Technologies - Virginia Tech
>

body:
OK - as I noted I have been fighting Apache's mod_cas and mod_cas
stating I have an invalid certificate.  I know I have the exact
certificate for the CA as I have installed it directly from them (in
this case Thawte).  I confirmed by viewing my CAS server that it is the
correct CA certificate as well (Thawte has multiple).  However it still
tells me the cert is invalid etc etc.

So my next question is can you use CASFilter with Sakai 1.5.1?
Everything I see shows it only with Sakai 2.0.  Just would like to get a
confirmation before I start down another path.

Thanks in advance,

Kevin

body:
Quoting Kevin Carpenter <kevin.carpenter@rsmart.com>:

> So my next question is can you use CASFilter with Sakai 1.5.1?

Yes, you can. I successfully used a CAS-like filter for a 1.5
installation that I just decommissioned. It's very similar to
applying a filter on 2.x

You'll find a lot of 1.5-related CAS information at the bottom of
the Confluence entry about CAS-ification:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/confluence/display/ENTR/CASifying+Sakai

I'll poke around tomorrow for the exact files.

Seth

body:
Hello,

I've done a braindump of possible things to include for 
SakaiScript/WebServices in Sakai 2.2.  Attached is the document.  It's 
also available in the resources area of the Web Services collab group.

This is based off discussions and suggestions recieved from various 
folks on mailing lists, and things I personally want to do.  I'm the 
only person who's seen this, so I'm expecting there will be a lot of 
comments, suggestions, and corrections.  I'm guessing these should go to 
the webservices list.

Also on the WS Collab group, I've created a short survey you can take.  
It's only 13 questions, and lets you rate the Line Items from 1 (not 
important) to 5 (totally radical), as well as give written input.  It 
will be available for a week, after which I'll compile and publish the 
results.

If you are interested in working on any of the line items, you can email 
the Web Service list or myself... or just start coding/documenting and 
collaborate/experiment.

I'm looking forward to the 2.2 release. I think we have enough time to 
do some really cool stuff. As usual, some things may make this release, 
others may have to wait, and some may always live in contrib.

Thanks,
Steve


-- 
Steven Githens, Chicago IL
s-githens@northwestern.edu
http://www.githens.org
[see attachment: "sakaiscript2.2planning_v1.pdf", size: 738909 bytes]

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/408>
body:
Some comments on these patches.

On Jan 7, 2006, at 12:27 PM, Charles Hedrick wrote:

> We've started moving to 2.1. We're starting to move the Rutgers  
> patches listed in Jira 2505 from 2.0.1 to 2.1. Other Rutgers staff  
> will do most of this. I'm doing AccessServlet. It's been  
> refactored, so most of the changes to into BaseContentService.java.  
> Because I'm giving you only the changes to those modules, some  
> feature are only half there. They depend upon changes to other  
> files, which will have to come from other people. [However I  
> believe that they can be easily adapted from the 2.0.1 patches,  
> which you can find from Jira 2505.]
>
> These changes are in a tar file attached to Jira 3442.
>
> Implements 4 features. (These features are completely implemented  
> by this patch. See below for the ones that are partly implemented.)
>
> 1) Aliases. If you create a mail alias for a site, you can access  
> its resource section with the same alias, e.g. http://server/access/ 
> myalias
> 2) Content view. If you access a folder (as opposed to an  
> individual resource)  via /access/content, normally you get an  
> error. With this patch you will get a directory listing in a format  
> that is appropriate for end users. It shows the description of the  
> folder and each item, so it looks a lot like a Melete organizer page.
> 3) If you specify ?basedir=xxx or ?sbasedir=xxx [for Sferyx],  
> directory listings have a special format intended to support pick  
> lists in HTML editors. Our users want to be able to insert images  
> easily in HTML. Part of that is for the HTML editor to be able to  
> show them a listing on their /images directory and make it easy to  
> pick an image. This is the server side of that. The basedir format  
> should be easy to use in any Javascript code. The sbasedir format  
> is tuned specifically for Sferyx' file picker.
> 4) implemented file upload via HTTP POST operations. This is also  
> intended for HTML editors, to let them upload images. Sferyx uses  
> this technique, and I believe other HTML editors do as well.

I feel that these modifications are effectively upwards compatible  
and add good features that cause no harm to any of the current ways  
that code works.  I would like to simply move these patches into  
trunk so Chuck does not have to maintain these.  But I would like to  
hear from others who like these patches or think that these patches  
should not just become part of Sakai.

These features need documenting.  We need a document ~dev/sakai/docs/ 
architecture/sakai_access.doc  that describes these features of  
access servlet in a style similar to the other documents in this  
directory.  There is not a current document on access servlet so one  
should be started.  To me documenting these features for posterity is  
an important aspect to getting these features into the code base.   
The simplest would be for Chuck H to write up the document - if not  
it will wait until someone else gets around to writing the document.   
I don't want to hold up the progress on moving this to trunk with a  
demand for documentation - but it is a strong desire that we don't go  
too far without writing the internal developer documentation so that  
folks can use these features.  It is always easier to write up basic  
documentation while things are fresh in people's minds.

> Interaction with other patches. I don't yet have 2.1.0 versions of  
> our other patches. However I believe the 2.0.1 versions may port  
> fairly easily except for this patch. (This one was hard because  
> AccessServlet was refactored for 2.1.0.) See Jira entry 2505 for a  
> list of our 2.0.1 patches.
>
> 1) Users without write access to resources are prevented from  
> seeing inside a directory whose name starts with "protected." Other  
> parts of this feature are in  ResourcesAction.java,  
> chef_resources_list.vm, chef_resoures_newlist.vm. If you don't want  
> this feature, look for "protected" (with the quote marks) in  
> BaseContentService.java, and remove the whole paragraph (surrounded  
> by blank lines).

This feature is something that needs to be discussed.  Security by  
naming convention is a quick way to add a feature but can result in  
brittle code.  Chuck H - lets keep this one separate and keep talking  
about this.  My concern with this feature is its design approach from  
a technical level - so we need to keep working on this.

So I would suggest that you make a separate JIRA item - call it  
something like "Adding protected folders and files to Content  
Hosting" and publish a patch.  Perhaps this is best done as a  
requirement because it really is a request for new feature which also  
happens to have a patch.

> 2) Users can change the order of entries in resources. This patch  
> uses the proper order in displaying directories, but  
> ResourcesAction and the vm files [same list as (1)] need to be  
> changed to let the use change the order, and to use the proper  
> order in the Resources tool.

I think that this is a feature that many would like.  I would also  
like to keep this patch separate from the others.  My concern here is  
two-fold - first we need to look at how this is done storage-wise and  
whether the approach used for storage of the ordering information  
will perform at scale (we had a performance problem on the first  
implementation of tab ordering).  The second concern I have is the  
user interface.   Lots of people have opinions about how the  
Resources user interface is supposed to look and when the resources  
tool user interface is changed we need to get a lot of eyes on the  
proposed changes.  So before we go forward on this I would like to  
see some kind of design proposed and made available for folks to look  
at.

We don't really have a good "procedure" for how we do this "hey take  
a look at this design" and give comments.  I would propose that in  
lieu of waiting for a formal process that we come up with a  
confluence page which takes some screenshots of the current modified  
tool running at Rutgers in 2.0, add some descriptive text and get  
some discussion around the changes so we can get some agreement from  
the Resource tool stakeholders before going forward.

I would also suggest that you make a separate JIRA called something  
like "Ordering items in the Resource Tool" and publish your patches  
here for folks to play with.  Also entering a requirement would be a  
good idea. Perhaps this is really just a requirement...

As Jim Eng has said separately this code (Resources Tool) is a real  
moving target right now.  The end-user interface is not changing much  
at all, but it is being re factored in terms of *how* things are done  
internally for 2.1.2.  It is going from a monolithic tool to a set of  
cooperating helper tools.  SO expect that you will have to end up  
with a 2.1, 2.1.2, and possibly even a 2.1.1 version of this patch.   
Chances are good that the code won't change too much (similar to the  
Access Servlet refactor above) but it will be in different places and  
different files.

Since you are deploying 2.1 - the only patch that matters for you is  
the 2.1 versions of the patch (for now).

---- To the community ----

We all have a responsibility to take a look at these modifications -  
one of the best ways to know that folks "like" a particular patch and  
that the patch is high quality is for more than one site to  
successfully run it in production.  This pattern worked very well for  
things like the SU tool - since several sites had already run it  
successfully it dropped into the release with barely  a ripple.  So I  
will be looking for some community reaction to and investment in  
these patches.  If community simply say "yes do them all", that is  
fine input, but the speed at which these patches move forward depends  
solely on when folks from IU and UM have time.

It is much better input when the folks in the community say "I ran  
all of this in production for several months - it ran fast and  
reliably and my users loved it".  :)

---- Summary  -----

Please separate this into three thrusts.

The Access Servlet stuff can likely fold in nicely to trunk - I  
looked this code over in 2.0 and actually tried to get it into 2.1  
but ran out of time - since the Access code refactor is already done  
in 2.1 - your patches should be solid for all 2.1 and 2.1.x versions  
giving us time to get them into trunk so you don't have to separately  
maintain these.

The ContentHosting stuff has some design issues.  Keep it separate -  
use it at Rutgers - when we get some time, we need to talk about the  
right way to do this for the long term.  This should probably become  
a "requirement" where the need is expressed in end-user terms.

The Resources tool ordering just needs some eyes to look at the GUI  
changes and "sign off" - this code is in the midst of refactor so  
keep these patches nice and separate and expect to have to keep  
moving the patches around through 2.1.2 - work with Jim Eng and  
perhaps we can smooth out some of the refactor bumps.  At a minimum,  
since Jim knows about these patches, Jim can let you know when things  
have settled down so that you can work together to make the patches  
work in 2.1.2 while the refactor is fresh in Jim's mind.

----------------------

subject: re: tools extending javax.sql.basedatasource
headers:
From news@gmane.org Tue Mar 04 03:33:20 2003
From: Andrew Thornton <andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk>
Subject: Re: Tools extending javax.sql.BaseDataSource

body:
Josh Holtzman wrote:
> I've been working with our DBAs to track down the excessive number of 
> Oracle connections we're seeing in our local sakai instance.  With the 
> following configuration in sakai.properties:
> 
> initialSize@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> maxActive@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> maxIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> minIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> 
> we would expect to see only 5 connections, but we consistently see 15.  
> It looks like both rWiki and Samigo create their own datasource by 
> extending the javax.sql.BaseDataSource bean.  This leads to a tripling 
> of the number of connections.  With lots of app servers in the cluster, 
> this has the potential to cause problems with our Oracle instance.

argh! oops, I'll take a look at that!

Lance/Glenn, I take it we should be using the javax.sql.Datasource?

andy

-- 
Andrew Thornton
andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk / andrew@cbcl.co.uk

On Jan 9, 2006, at 8:44 AM, Charles Severance wrote:

> Some comments on these patches.
>
> On Jan 7, 2006, at 12:27 PM, Charles Hedrick wrote:
>
>> We've started moving to 2.1. We're starting to move the Rutgers  
>> patches listed in Jira 2505 from 2.0.1 to 2.1. Other Rutgers staff  
>> will do most of this. I'm doing AccessServlet. It's been  
>> refactored, so most of the changes to into  
>> BaseContentService.java. Because I'm giving you only the changes  
>> to those modules, some feature are only half there. They depend  
>> upon changes to other files, which will have to come from other  
>> people. [However I believe that they can be easily adapted from  
>> the 2.0.1 patches, which you can find from Jira 2505.]
>>
>> These changes are in a tar file attached to Jira 3442.
>>
>> Implements 4 features. (These features are completely implemented  
>> by this patch. See below for the ones that are partly implemented.)
>>
>> 1) Aliases. If you create a mail alias for a site, you can access  
>> its resource section with the same alias, e.g. http://server/ 
>> access/myalias
>> 2) Content view. If you access a folder (as opposed to an  
>> individual resource)  via /access/content, normally you get an  
>> error. With this patch you will get a directory listing in a  
>> format that is appropriate for end users. It shows the description  
>> of the folder and each item, so it looks a lot like a Melete  
>> organizer page.
>> 3) If you specify ?basedir=xxx or ?sbasedir=xxx [for Sferyx],  
>> directory listings have a special format intended to support pick  
>> lists in HTML editors. Our users want to be able to insert images  
>> easily in HTML. Part of that is for the HTML editor to be able to  
>> show them a listing on their /images directory and make it easy to  
>> pick an image. This is the server side of that. The basedir format  
>> should be easy to use in any Javascript code. The sbasedir format  
>> is tuned specifically for Sferyx' file picker.
>> 4) implemented file upload via HTTP POST operations. This is also  
>> intended for HTML editors, to let them upload images. Sferyx uses  
>> this technique, and I believe other HTML editors do as well.
>
> I feel that these modifications are effectively upwards compatible  
> and add good features that cause no harm to any of the current ways  
> that code works.  I would like to simply move these patches into  
> trunk so Chuck does not have to maintain these.  But I would like  
> to hear from others who like these patches or think that these  
> patches should not just become part of Sakai.


I fully agree that an overall document on the access servlet would be  
very useful and I agree that the waiting until one exists before the  
code can get integrated will slow progress.  A pragmatic middle  
ground would be to require good javadocs for code that changes.   The  
javadocs should be there anyway, they don't require updating other  
documents, they don't require finding a place to put the  
documentation, they can be a great aid to anyone looking at the code,  
and if it turns into a big task to describe what is going on, that  
doesn't bode well for the maintainability of the code.


- Dave

> These features need documenting.  We need a document ~dev/sakai/ 
> docs/architecture/sakai_access.doc  that describes these features  
> of access servlet in a style similar to the other documents in this  
> directory.  There is not a current document on access servlet so  
> one should be started.  To me documenting these features for  
> posterity is an important aspect to getting these features into the  
> code base.  The simplest would be for Chuck H to write up the  
> document - if not it will wait until someone else gets around to  
> writing the document.  I don't want to hold up the progress on  
> moving this to trunk with a demand for documentation - but it is a  
> strong desire that we don't go too far without writing the internal  
> developer documentation so that folks can use these features.  It  
> is always easier to write up basic documentation while things are  
> fresh in people's minds.

Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/412>
body:
A tool should let the datasource be configurable unless there are  
very compelling reasons not to .  An installation should be able to  
let tools use their main Sakai datasource, but the installation  
should also be able to choose to use a different one.  For example,  
an installation might want to have provisional tools use a separate  
database instance to limit the possible impact of a bug found in  
tools that have not yet been widely used.

- Dave

------------------
David Haines
dlhaines@umich.edu
Sakai Developer
Digital Media Commons
Duderstadt Center
University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48109
(734) 615-2556



On Jan 6, 2006, at 5:32 PM, Josh Holtzman wrote:

> I've been working with our DBAs to track down the excessive number  
> of Oracle connections we're seeing in our local sakai instance.   
> With the following configuration in sakai.properties:
>
> initialSize@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> maxActive@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> maxIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
> minIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5
>
> we would expect to see only 5 connections, but we consistently see  
> 15.  It looks like both rWiki and Samigo create their own  
> datasource by extending the javax.sql.BaseDataSource bean.  This  
> leads to a tripling of the number of connections.  With lots of app  
> servers in the cluster, this has the potential to cause problems  
> with our Oracle instance.
>
> We're going to dial down the number of connections in rWiki and  
> Samigo by changing the spring configs in each of the tools, so this  
> isn't going to cause us any problems... I just want folks out there  
> in the community know what we've found w.r.t. DB connections.
>
> I'm also curious if there a specific reason these tools have chosen  
> to use their own datasources.  I saw some comments in the rWiki  
> config files that made me think this was an intentional choice  
> (possibly for using a custom session factory with hibernate  
> triggers?).
>
> Thanks,
> Josh
>
> -- 
> Josh Holtzman
> Educational Technology Services, UC Berkeley
> jholtzman@berkeley.edu
> 510.643.7380

body:
Seth Theriault wrote:

> I'll poke around tomorrow for the exact files.

I have done some poking. You will need to place the CAS Filter on the 
sakai-dispatch app that resides in /usr/local/sakai. Specifically, you 
need to add the appropriate XML to:

/usr/local/sakai/sakai-real/sakai-dispatch/WEB-INF/web.xml

I chose to do this around line 100. Here's a snippet:

[...]
<url-pattern>/*</url-pattern>
</filter-mapping>
-->

<!-- CAS Filter -->
<filter>
<filter-name>CAS Filter</filter-name>
<filter-class>edu.yale.its.tp.cas.client.filter.CASFilter</filter-class>

<init-param>
<param-name>edu.yale.its.tp.cas.client.filter.loginUrl</param-name>
<param-value>https://secure.its.yale.edu/cas/login</param-value>
</init-param>

<init-param>
<param-name>edu.yale.its.tp.cas.client.filter.validateUrl</param-name>
<param-value>https://secure.its.yale.edu/cas/serviceValidate</param-value>
</init-param>

<init-param>
<param-name>edu.yale.its.tp.cas.client.filter.serverName</param-name>
<param-value>your server name and port (e.g., www.yale.edu:8080)</param-value>
</init-param>

<init-param>
<param-name>edu.yale.its.tp.cas.client.filter.wrapRequest</param-name>
<param-value>true</param-value>
</init-param>

</filter>

<filter-mapping>
<filter-name>CAS Filter</filter-name>
<url-pattern>/tunnel/sakai-chef-tool/authn</url-pattern>
</filter-mapping>

<!-- =========================== -->

<!-- Now setup tunnel servlets for the different requests.
[...]

The wrapRequest setting allows the container auth to work and URL 
pattern given above is correct (you may wish to experiment with /* 
depending on your set up). The rest is a generic example that I stole 
from:

http://www.ja-sig.org/wiki/display/CAS/Using+CASFilter

which is a good reference.

Once you have made the above edits and placed the CAS jar in an 
accessible place, you will still need to edit the Tomcat server.xml, 
sakai.properties, and most likely the Login UI.

Seth

body:
Hi,

>5) Logged in as user:
>	1) No photo was visible despite "Use University Id Picture" being true
>(no error returned)
>  
>
I also noticed this error and submitted to JIRA (reported as 
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-3297):
"(...) entries in SAKAI_PERSON_T table are created with the key pair 
(agent_uuid, type_uuid) and, in my experiments, type_uuid of user's 
profiles are always of 'UserMutableType'. But in the referenced method, 
an entry of (agent_uuid, SystemMutableType) must NOT return null in 
order to display picture!"

>	2) when the user tries to edit their profile Sakai throws the
>hibernate.StaleObjectStateException
>
>Perhaps this could be a Mysql specific error if the code works fine for
>Indiana?
>  
>
I'm runnig MySql too and I have used a similar script to 
"UpdateProfilePhotoJob.java" that runs without errors!
Not quite sure of this but, the thrown exception could mean that the 
object (Profile) being saved to db is obsolete (it was opened, modified 
and saved in other place, meanwhile)?...

Nuno.

>(I'll do some more research and see if I can find out where it is)
>
>David

body:
On Jan 9, 2006, at 8:44 AM, Charles Severance wrote:

>
> This feature is something that needs to be discussed.  Security by  
> naming convention is a quick way to add a feature but can result in  
> brittle code.  Chuck H - lets keep this one separate and keep  
> talking about this.  My concern with this feature is its design  
> approach from a technical level - so we need to keep working on this.
>
> So I would suggest that you make a separate JIRA item - call it  
> something like "Adding protected folders and files to Content  
> Hosting" and publish a patch.  Perhaps this is best done as a  
> requirement because it really is a request for new feature which  
> also happens to have a patch.

I've already commented separately that I don't think this is the way  
to do this. I do patches differently when I know I'm going to have to  
put them in every release than if I were the implementor. If I were  
the implementor I would create a permission for doing a directory  
listing, or I would provide a place to store items separate from the  
resources area (the attachments directory is an example of this) that  
the instructor could browse but not the students. However the HTML  
editor's file picker would have to be able to browse it.

I've submitted a requirement about this and other features needed to  
support HTML editors.

I'm not in a position to submit a patch yet because portions of the  
code (in files I didn't look at) haven't been moved to 2.1 yet.

----------------------

body:
Hi, George. Thanks for saying my movie is a blockbuster, though I  
don't think I'll be getting any calls from the Academy.

Anyway, getting Eclipse to build everything perfectly is more of an  
art than a science. Or not even art; you pretty much have to hit it  
over the head repeatedly until everything works properly. I neatly  
sidestepped this whole problem in my demo. If you'll notice, right  
before I import all the Sakai modules into Eclipse, I go to the  
Project menu and uncheck "Build Automatically." This prevents Eclipse  
from even *attempting* to build everything itself.

All those errors about missing dependencies are the result of maven  
having not yet built up your local repository. You have to run a full  
maven build of Sakai at least once for all the necessary dependencies  
to be in the .maven/repository directory.

And as far as all the errors about projects not building because  
projects that depend on them haven't been built, you should try  
building the modules one at a time by using the "Clean" command under  
the Project menu. Do the util module first, then kernel, then try the  
others in no particular order.

But bear in mind that getting Eclipse to behave is not strictly  
necessary. That's why I could switch off automatic builds in Eclipse  
with no consequences. All the building and deploying ultimately  
happens at the command line with maven.

regards,
Zach A. Thomas
Software Engineer
Texas State University
http://www.txstate.edu
On Jan 7, 2006, at 10:06 AM, George P. Pipkin wrote:

> Hi -
>
> I have been watching Zach Thomas's new blockbuster movie, and I
> was able to build Sakai from source and the thing appears to run  
> fine.  Then I got to
> the part where I import all the source files into Eclipse.  I set  
> the MAVEN_REPO
> classpath variable to:
>
> C:/Documents and Settings/gpp8p/.maven/repository
>
> Note - I am runnint Eclipse 3.1.1 with the MyEclipse plugin - the  
> milestone 2
> release (that's a beta release of MyEclipse).
>
> I do the import, and everything comes in fine.  However, there are  
> a slew of errors:
>

body:
Hi,

I can now definitely confirm this on TRUNK running on MySQl:

1) Started with clean database
2) created a user
3) used a script to set the the users profile including setJpegPhoto()
4) checked that the profile existed in the DB and that the photo was
correctly set (by extracting the photo and viewing)
5) Logged in as user:
1) No photo was visible despite "Use University Id Picture" being true
(no error returned)
2) when the user tries to edit their profile Sakai throws the
hibernate.StaleObjectStateException

Perhaps this could be a Mysql specific error if the code works fine for
Indiana?

(I'll do some more research and see if I can find out where it is)

David

body:
Hi George,

I am actually using Eclipe for modules modification/customization etc, 
but do not deploy directly from Eclipse.
This is what I did:
- set MAVEN_REPO classpath variable in Eclipse (DONE);
- set TOMCAT_HOME classpath variable in Eclipse;
- do a "maven sakai:clean_build" (will place most required jars in 
maven repository)

This will (hopefuly) solve most errors!
Maven uses a different way for setting the classpath (project.xml) - in 
Eclipse this is set in ".classpath". The important one for proper 
compilation is the maven classpath - eclipse classpath is stil very 
useful here but is not mandatory.

Not quite sure if these are all the required steps.
Nuno.

	rv:1.7.7) Gecko/20050414 Firefox/1.0.3
X-IMP-Server: 141.211.144.237
X-Originating-IP: 70.191.118.220
X-Originating-User: jimeng
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain;
	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	format="flowed"
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/417>
body:
If the system is configured so each user sees all their sites in the 
file picker, an instructor can place resources in her own workspace and 
then attach them to any assignment/calendar event/discussion item/etc 
without students being able to discover them easily independent of that 
entity.  In 2.1.0, the attachment is a copy of the original resource.  
Soon I expect that we will also enable the attachment of links to the 
original resource.

My point here is that I believe this requirement is already satisfied 
without any need for a patch.  An instructor teaching a course named 
"Course X" could create a "Course X" folder in her own workspace, place 
all the resources for the semester in that folder whenever, and then 
create attachments to those resources or move them into the course 
resources folder whenever she chooses.

I like the idea of eventually adding the capability to set release 
dates and retraction dates on resources. I believe there is a JIRA 
ticket requesting that capability, but we haven't yet come up with a 
design for the user interface or the underlying infrastructure.  That 
may be quite simple, but other issues have higher priority at the 
moment.

Thanks.

Jim




Quoting Charles Hedrick <hedrick@rutgers.edu>:

>
> On Jan 9, 2006, at 8:44 AM, Charles Severance wrote:
>
>>
>> This feature is something that needs to be discussed.  Security by  
>> naming convention is a quick way to add a feature but can result in  
>> brittle code.  Chuck H - lets keep this one separate and keep  
>> talking about this.  My concern with this feature is its design  
>> approach from a technical level - so we need to keep working on this.
>>
>> So I would suggest that you make a separate JIRA item - call it  
>> something like "Adding protected folders and files to Content  
>> Hosting" and publish a patch.  Perhaps this is best done as a  
>> requirement because it really is a request for new feature which  
>> also happens to have a patch.
>
> I've already commented separately that I don't think this is the way  
> to do this. I do patches differently when I know I'm going to have to 
>  put them in every release than if I were the implementor. If I were  
> the implementor I would create a permission for doing a directory  
> listing, or I would provide a place to store items separate from the  
> resources area (the attachments directory is an example of this) that 
>  the instructor could browse but not the students. However the HTML  
> editor's file picker would have to be able to browse it.
>
> I've submitted a requirement about this and other features needed to  
> support HTML editors.
>
> I'm not in a position to submit a patch yet because portions of the  
> code (in files I didn't look at) haven't been moved to 2.1 yet.
>

body:
We need further discussion of the Rutgers change that allows reordering 
in the list view.  It breaks the ability to get an alphabetical listing 
of resources.  I think a better way to achieve the same thing is to 
create a new tool called a ResourceViewer, which is designed 
specifically to enable creation of views such as Charles suggests. I 
think it would be a fairly easy tool to implement and could give 
instructors and other site maintainers much more control over the 
formatting of displays of sets of resources.  That would then let the 
Resources tool itself maintain the file-system metaphor, which most 
users seem to favor.

Jim



Jim Eng
jimeng@umich.edu
734-645-4123

----------------------

body:
My question is where to have this discussion...

Here is my proposal.  Lets make a requirement for "changing the order  
of items in resources". Then make a confluence space for it.  Then  
someone probably Chuck H needs to put in a design proposal into  
Confluence.

Then folks can go round-and-round about this in confluence and when  
consensus happens, report it back to this group and annotate the  
requirement in JIRA.

Just an idea.

/Chuck

On Jan 9, 2006, at 12:53 PM, Jim Eng wrote:

> We need further discussion of the Rutgers change that allows  
> reordering in the list view.  It breaks the ability to get an  
> alphabetical listing of resources.  I think a better way to achieve  
> the same thing is to create a new tool called a ResourceViewer,  
> which is designed specifically to enable creation of views such as  
> Charles suggests. I think it would be a fairly easy tool to  
> implement and could give instructors and other site maintainers  
> much more control over the formatting of displays of sets of  
> resources.  That would then let the Resources tool itself maintain  
> the file-system metaphor, which most users seem to favor.
>
> Jim

 sakai-dev@collab.sakaiproject.org; Mon, 09 Jan 2006 13:12:54 -0500 (EST)

To: Charles Severance <csev@umich.edu>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.746.2)
X-Virus-Scanned: Virus Scanned by NBCS 
X-Content-Type-Message-Body: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; delsp=yes; format=flowed
Archived-At: <http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.comp.cms.sakai.devel/419>
body:
The installation instructions are clear how to remove this.

Originally I tried to pull out individual patches and post them. That  
proved impossible to maintain. The most I can do on an ongoing basis  
is give diffs for source files.

If you want to insert a specific patch in the central source, I'll be  
happy to give you diffs of specific feature, but I can only afford to  
do it once per feature, at a point when I know you will take it.


On Jan 9, 2006, at 12:58 PM, Charles Severance wrote:

> Right - so the key here is for you to keep it nice and separate  
> from the other patches which are likely destined for wide release  
> once we crank through them.
>
> /Chuck
>
> On Jan 9, 2006, at 11:28 AM, Charles Hedrick wrote:
>
>>
>> On Jan 9, 2006, at 8:44 AM, Charles Severance wrote:
>>
>> I've already commented separately that I don't think this is the  
>> way to do this. I do patches differently when I know I'm going to  
>> have to put them in every release than if I were the implementor.  
>> If I were the implementor I would create a permission for doing a  
>> directory listing, or I would provide a place to store items  
>> separate from the resources area (the attachments directory is an  
>> example of this) that the instructor could browse but not the  
>> students. However the HTML editor's file picker would have to be  
>> able to browse it.
>>
>> I've submitted a requirement about this and other features needed  
>> to support HTML editors.
>>
>> I'm not in a position to submit a patch yet because portions of  
>> the code (in files I didn't look at) haven't been moved to 2.1 yet.
>>
>>
>>
>

body:
Charles Hedrick wrote:

> Yes. At this point, rather than creating my own web site, I'm  
> submitting them as patches to jira. I'm concerned that if every site  
> maintains their own web page of changes, it will become impossible to  
> find anything. Jira looks like a good central point. 

Please - and it's what the project has provided for this.
Doing so gives us a better chance of finding patches.
And whoever the trunk-committers are can indicate which 'candidate' 
patches have been moved up into the trunk, and when.

body:
The current "state of the art" if to use the relatively new
AdditionalHibernateMappingsImpl method that John Ellis introduced (many
thanks to John!).  This method has the benefit of having ONE Hibernate
SessionFactory and TransactionManager (both of which are required for
transactions to work across Managers).  Do not worry about transactions
failing subtly; you will get a big fat stack trace if you run into this
problem.



We are recommending that all Hibernate based tools switch to this new
methodology ASAP.  For an example see:

/syllabus/components/src/webapp/WEB-INF/components.xml   e.g.:



<beans>

<bean
id="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.impl.AdditionalHibernateM
appingsImpl.syllabus"


class="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.impl.AdditionalHiberna
teMappingsImpl">

<property name="mappingResources">

<list>

<value>


org/sakaiproject/component/app/syllabus/SyllabusItemImpl.hbm.xml

</value>

<value>


org/sakaiproject/component/app/syllabus/SyllabusDataImpl.hbm.xml

</value>

<value>


org/sakaiproject/component/app/syllabus/SyllabusAttachment.hbm.xml

</value>

</list>

</property>

</bean>



<bean id="org.sakaiproject.api.app.syllabus.SyllabusManager"


class="org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionProxyFactoryBe
an">

<property name="transactionManager">

<ref
bean="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.GlobalTransactionManage
r" />

</property>

<property name="target">

<bean


class="org.sakaiproject.component.app.syllabus.SyllabusManagerImpl"

singleton="true">

<property name="sessionFactory">

<ref


bean="org.sakaiproject.springframework.orm.hibernate.GlobalSessionFactory"
/>

</property>

</bean>

</property>

<property name="transactionAttributes">

<props>

<prop key="*">PROPAGATION_REQUIRED</prop>

</props>

</property>

</bean>



</beans>



Cheers, L



________________________________



Lance Speelmon

Acting Manager Online Development

Indiana University





-----Original Message-----
From: Andrew Thornton [mailto:andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk] 
Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 4:01 AM
To: Josh Holtzman
Cc: sakai-dev
Subject: Re: Tools extending javax.sql.BaseDataSource



Josh Holtzman wrote:

> I've been working with our DBAs to track down the excessive number of 

> Oracle connections we're seeing in our local sakai instance.  With the 

> following configuration in sakai.properties:

> 

> initialSize@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5

> maxActive@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5

> maxIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5

> minIdle@javax.sql.BaseDataSource=5

> 

> we would expect to see only 5 connections, but we consistently see 15.  

> It looks like both rWiki and Samigo create their own datasource by 

> extending the javax.sql.BaseDataSource bean.  This leads to a tripling 

> of the number of connections.  With lots of app servers in the cluster, 

> this has the potential to cause problems with our Oracle instance.



argh! oops, I'll take a look at that!



Lance/Glenn, I take it we should be using the javax.sql.Datasource?



andy



-- 

Andrew Thornton

andrew@caret.cam.ac.uk / andrew@cbcl.co.uk
